base_prompt: I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.
base_prompt_completions: <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. It's hard to say what's best for everyone, so I'd like to hear what you think.I've always enjoyed the Starwood Preferred Guest (SPG) Amex, but I don't have any personal experience with the new Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. So if you could share your thoughts, it would be much appreciated.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. In other words, which card is the king of credit cards?If you've got your favorite in mind, tell me which card it is, and why, in a comment below.Also, if there's a credit card that you think deserves to be on the shortlist but that isn't, tell me what that card is.For the record, this is the card I currently use.Because it has no annual fee, no foreign transaction fees, a great rewards program, and an unbelievable low interest rate, the Citi® Double Cash Card has become my go-to card for daily purchases, like groceries and gas, and travel. In fact, it has become my only card for most of these kinds of purchases.Of course, as good as it is, it's not perfect, and so I'll be paying close attention to your comments to see what it might be missing.How To Find the Best Credit Card for You5 Credit Cards You Should Never GetThe Most Underrated Credit Card PerksCredit Card Applications Decline 7 Percent in 2015</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. If you already have a go-to card, I'd like to hear your reasons why. If not, I encourage you to check out the list below to get a feel for the available options. You may want to click on the individual cards in order to learn more about the rewards, interest rates, annual fees, and other details.I'm using Discover It as my go-to card. I do have the Chase Sapphire Preferred for emergency use and have had the American Express Green (premier) card for a long time.I also have the Chase Freedom Unlimited for all my daily purchases, and a Discover it for rotating categories, and a Blue Cash from American Express for groceries. But I never carry a balance on any of them, and I pay all my balances in full every month, so why have all these credit cards? Because every card has different benefits and the Discover is currently giving me the best overall rewards.While Chase Sapphire Preferred provides the best travel benefits for those who use the card to book hotels and travel, Chase Ink Bold is great if you spend a lot on travel or on things like cell phone bills. It’s one of the few cards to offer 5x on phone bills.I have the AMEX Platinum card and it is a very good card. I don't use it much except for big purchases that I can pay off quickly. They just raised the annual fee to $450 and it will likely go to $550 next year. This is the only reason I am even thinking about dropping it.I use it in the U.S. and around the world. It works in most places without a problem and has the advantage of no foreign transaction fees. You are charged no foreign transaction fees on your credit cards.I just had to drop the AMEX SPG card (for the same reasons). In 2019 it will no longer be useful for me. So I will be looking to find a new credit card.The first card I ever received was a bank credit card when I was 19, so I have had a card for 18 years. I pay it off each month to avoid any interest charges, and I can use the card anywhere Visa is accepted, which covers a lot of stores.It's been 15 years since my first credit card. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I've had two credit cards in the past - the Chase Freedom card which had a few useful perks, but high interest rates (and is now a "Slate" card due to a missed payment). The other was the Citi AAdvantage card that had low interest, and good perks - but I still had to put off travel until my savings accumulated to a sufficient degree.Currently I use a CapitalOne card for my gas purchases and a debit card for the rest, but it seems a credit card would be much more flexible and useful, and possibly cheaper in the long run, especially with an APR of 0% or lower.In your opinion, what's the best current card on the market today?posted by gman to Travel & Transportation around San Francisco, CA (22 answers total) 14 users marked this as a favoriteI second the Barclay's JetBlue card. Great rates and generous benefits (especially in NYC, as it's based on your ZipCode, so it's the only card I need for cabs, discounts at the theater, etc.posted by lester's sock puppet at 10:43 AM on March 26, 2012 [1 favorite]I love my Chase Freedom card, as I've been able to take a 0% loan on it and pay it off with it, and the bonus miles every quarter make it a sweet deal.posted by jenfullmoon at 10:46 AM on March 26, 2012I have the Barclaycard Arrival Plus card, and I like it a lot.1) No yearly fee2) 5% bonus miles for all purchases3) No foreign transaction fee4) No minimum spend required5) 0% interest for 12 months6) 20,000 bonus miles after spending $1,000 in the first 90 daysposted by yukonho at 10:53 AM on March 26, 2012We had the Chase Freedom card, but the 14.99% interest rate was a bit more than we wanted to pay. I'm not sure what the difference is, but we recently switched to the Chase Slate card. I think the biggest difference is that they advertise 0% for 15 months rather than a set amount of time.posted by tacodave at 11:06 AM on March 26, 2012Citi's ThankYou Points Visa is my favorite because of the 3 ThankYou Points you get for every dollar on all purchases, so you can easily redeem them for travel or cash. You can also get a sign-up bonus of 40k points. And it's 0% for 15 months.But that's just what I like.posted by palliser at 11:18 AM on March 26, 2012I love mine!posted by gingerbeer at 11:28 AM on March 26, 2012Best Cash Rewards is the best of the best if you want to get cash back.You might consider opening up a Discover card and using it for gas (it earns you cash back as well).posted by 6550 at 11:37 AM on March 26, 2012CapitalOne has been running a pretty decent offer in the last few months: you get 20,000 points (worth $200 in travel) if you spend $500 in the first three months.And I second the Barclaycard Arrival Plus card. I haven't done any of the other benefits yet.posted by rw at 11:39 AM on March 26, 2012Citi's ThankYou Points Visa is my favorite because of the 3 ThankYou Points you get for every dollar on all purchasesCiti just announced that they're changing to 2x on restaurants and hotels.I love my Citi ThankYou card and I'm sad they're changing the rewards. It's the only place I've found that earns ThankYou Points.If you do apply for it, use this link. It's not a signup bonus or anything.I'm pretty happy with my Chase Freedom card. It gets a high rate on travel purchases (for me), no foreign transaction fees, and a 0% interest rate on balance transfers for 18 months. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The best thing about the credit card world is that it's ever-changing; with each new credit card issuer, a different player tries to take the top spot.My favorite card for 2013 was the American Express Blue Cash Preferred® Card because of its exceptional 6% cash-back rate on all purchases at supermarkets, gas stations, and department stores. However, in this card match-up, the Blue Cash Preferred® Card isn't even in the running.So, if you're looking for a new card, which one should you get?Here are five credit cards I like, each for different reasons.1. Bank of America Cash Rewards® Visa® Credit Card: The Bank of America Cash Rewards® Visa® Credit Card has been around for a while, and it's been a strong competitor in the cash-back field. It has no annual fee and earns an unlimited 3% cash back on gas, 2% cash back on groceries, and 1% cash back on all other purchases. These rates are competitive with other cards on the market.However, one of the biggest strengths of this card is that Bank of America rewards its most loyal customers with the ability to earn 5% cash back at select merchants. There are 30,000 participating merchants in the program, and many of them are popular businesses, like Staples and Best Buy. But, you won't find all of your favorite brands there.On a 200-point scale, this card gets 5 stars from me. It gets 3 stars for cash back rate and 2 stars for rewards program.2. Chase Freedom® Card: If you're looking for one of the best rewards programs in the industry, look no further than the Chase Freedom® Card. With it, you'll earn 5% cash back in rotating quarterly categories, up to $1,500 in spending each quarter. These quarterly categories are announced in January, April, July, and October, and they range from groceries to travel to gas.While the rotating categories offer you an opportunity to earn 5% cash back at the places you spend the most, you may also take advantage of the $100 cash bonus you'll get each year for spending $500 in the first three months after opening your account.The card comes with no annual fee, and you'll receive a sign-up bonus of 5% cash back on your first $1,500 in purchases within three months. You can also get a 1% cash back on all other purchases. The Chase Freedom® Card gets 5 stars on the cash back rate category, 4 stars for rewards program, and 1 star for annual fee.3. Citi ThankYou® Preferred Card: If you want to travel without paying a fee to earn rewards for your purchases, the Citi ThankYou® Preferred Card is a good option. As long as you can pay your balance off in full each month, you'll get 1% cash back on purchases and 1 ThankYou point per dollar spent. However, it's important to understand that you'll get only 1 point per dollar spent if you choose not to pay your balance in full each month. You'll have to pay at least the minimum amount due by the due date or you'll lose the 1% cash-back rate and won't get 1 point per dollar spent.The ThankYou points you'll earn with the card can be used to book travel through Citi at a rate of one cent per point. That means you can save $250 on travel bookings if you've accrued 25,000 points. Alternatively, you can transfer the points to airline and hotel partners. You can save up to 20% off travel purchases when you redeem your points for travel. The card also offers a $50 statement credit for Global Entry or TSA Precheck membership and a sign-up bonus of 20,000 ThankYou points.The Citi ThankYou® Preferred Card gets 4 stars for rewards program and 2 stars for cash back rate and annual fee.4. Wells Fargo Platinum Visa® Card: The Wells Fargo Platinum Visa® Card offers one of the best cash-back rates for new cardholders in 2013. Within the first three months after opening your account, you can get 1.5% cash back on all your purchases, up to $12,500 spent. You'll also get 1.5% cash back for the rest of the year, and you'll get 1% cash back for the rest of your time with the card. There's no annual fee.Besides the cash-back rate, this card gets another 5 stars from me because it offers free FICO® credit scores on monthly statements. There are many cards that offer this feature, but you usually have to pay for it.The Wells Fargo Platinum Visa® Card gets 5 stars for cash back rate, 4 stars for annual fee, and 1 star for rewards program.5. Chase Freedom® Card with the IHG® Rewards Club Select Credit Card: One of the best perks of having this card is the ability to earn a free night with each card anniversary. You'll also get 25,000 bonus points on the first purchase you make with the card. In addition, you'll receive a 10% rebate of IHG points when you redeem them, which can be especially useful if you're trying to book a room at a high-end resort, as it may otherwise cost you many thousands of points.The card comes with a $60 annual fee, but you'll get $120 in free nights after the first anniversary. You'll also get automatic upgrade status and complimentary internet access at IHG hotels. Finally, you'll be given 40,000 IHG points after spending $1,000 in the first three months of card membership.The IHG® Rewards Club Select Credit Card gets 5 stars for cash back rate and annual fee, and 1 star for rewards program.How about you? What are the top credit cards that you like in 2013? Let us know by commenting below or on our Facebook page.To take the challenge to another level, here's the card match-up for the best credit card of 2014!This is a difficult matchup. As of 1/14/14 the Wells Fargo Cash Wise Visa does not have the cash back rates. The Platinum Visa is currently listed as 1.5% cash back for the first 6 months (then revert to 1.25% ongoing).It's still a good card because it is FREE with no annual fee.</s>

If you make at least $1,500 worth of purchases at grocery stores each year, you'll also have the opportunity to earn an extra 3% on all of your grocery store purchases as well as 5% on up to $15,000 in combined purchases at select US restaurants and US drugstores.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I was looking for a card that's a bit similar to what TD has to offer (cash back, 0% intro APR, 5% reward rate) and found Capital One. They offer a card that gives 2% cash back on purchases for new card holders, and have a 0% introductory APR period of up to 20 months.You could apply for the Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card to take advantage of these benefits.I'm curious to know what your thoughts on Capital One are, if you've ever used them in the past, and what you'd recommend. I think it's a really good card, and I hope to use it in the future.How about Chase? Any of their cards, or do you prefer other financial institutions? I know there's a lot of people that really don't like Chase, but I'm curious what you think about the company.I currently have the Discover It® Miles Card, so I guess you could say I lean toward Discover.Were you able to get the 0% intro APR that Capital One offers with your other card, or was it an intro 0% APR?Capital One is fine, but not the best. They do some good things like the 2% cash back. I have a Capital One card and like it ok, but not great. I get more value from my TD card.I don't have one. I have a credit card for the emergency fund but have not used it yet. I can say for sure, Chase is better than Capital One. They were both very high on the credit card scandal list. That makes them suspicious in my book.I use Chase, but I think Chase is just as good or bad as any other. I've never had any issues with Chase and I've had many, many cards.Capital One is fine, but I would never use them if they didn't have an option to cash out and get a check in the mail. I always have to do this with Capital One and I can't stand it. I can't stand any card where it takes like a month to get a check in the mail.Chase and Wells Fargo are my favorites. Capital One is okay, but I like Discover better.I use Wells Fargo. I have the Wells Fargo Cash Wise Visa card and I've been really happy with it. They offer 0% intro APR on balance transfers and have some good rewards. They don't have a sign up bonus, but I'm not really that interested in getting the perks of a sign up bonus. The interest rate is 0% APR for the first 12 months of use, which I find really good.Wells Fargo is my bank of choice. I also like Discover and American Express.I have a Discover card, and I'm very happy with it. They're one of the best cards that I've ever had, and they've got a really good offer that comes with it. They're offering a $150 statement credit if you make any purchase within the first three months.Would you recommend Discover to others?I don't have one. I don't really care what kind of credit card I use.I don't have a credit card. I don't use them because they're a pain. If I could have a credit card that had all the same features as a debit card, I would.What do you think about Discover?What are some of the things that bother you most about using a credit card?I don't have a credit card because they just give you a lot of financial stress. There's so many things that could go wrong, and so many hidden fees.I don't have a credit card because I have an aversion to credit cards. I've never had a credit card before, and I don't like them.I don't have a credit card because I don't want to take out loans and get into financial trouble.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The top three picks from users of our own CreditCards.com Poll of Best Credit Card Providers are:Barclaycard Arrival Plus World Elite MastercardIn each of these cases, it looks as though users preferred cards offering rewards as opposed to cash back, but I am a little surprised that more users didn't pick Chase Sapphire Preferred as the best rewards card, given its stellar rewards structure and lack of foreign transaction fees. The Barclaycard Arrival Plus World Elite Mastercard was only selected as the top pick in 1.3% of user votes, which may indicate that people are unfamiliar with its rewards structure.I wonder what other people think about the best cards offered by each of the above providers. Is there anything about them that makes them stand out from the crowd? Or, if you don't know much about them, would you be interested in learning more about what they offer?Best Cards Offered by Each of the Top 10 ProvidersHow Credit Card Providers Are RatedHow Credit Card Rewards WorkWhat are the best credit cards available for new cardholders?If you're a new credit card applicant, what do you think of when you think of getting a new credit card? Perhaps the first thing you consider is whether or not you will have a credit card limit that is reasonable for the type of card you plan to apply for.With this in mind, what is your pick for the best credit card for new cardholders? The top three answers to this question according to our users were:These results aren't terribly surprising, as Discover is not known for its high credit limits, but rather for offering the highest credit limits to new applicants. On the other hand, Citi offers some high credit limits to new cardholders who qualify, including the Citi® / AAdvantage® Platinum Select® Mastercard® and Citi®/ AAdvantage® Executive World Elite Mastercard®. I guess I don't really know enough about these cards to pick one over the other, but I'm curious to hear what other people think.What is the best credit card for new cardholders?What credit cards do people use most often?We've all got our favorite cards. So, which is your go-to credit card?The top three picks from users of our own CreditCards.com Poll of Best Credit Card Providers are:Barclaycard Arrival Mastercard World EliteOf the three cards listed here, I suppose I would pick the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card for my primary credit card, because I think it is the best travel rewards credit card for new cardholders. On the other hand, I wouldn't pick the Bank of America® Travel Rewards Visa® credit card as my primary card, because I wouldn't want to limit my options for earning rewards in order to earn rewards in a particular category.It seems like most of the credit card users on this board are either frequent fliers or big-time travelers, and I'm curious to know what other people think about these choices. Is there another card that would be a better pick?What is the card you use most frequently?How did the best cards from our top providers change from 2013 to 2014?Now that we know what the best cards are according to our users, it seems like a good time to look at how these cards have changed from 2013 to 2014. Here's what the winners look like according to users of our own CreditCards.com Poll of Best Credit Card Providers:Barclaycard Arrival World MastercardChase Freedom FlexIt's interesting to see that the Chase Freedom Flex and Capital One Venture Card are listed as the best credit cards offered by two of the top three providers, but it's also somewhat surprising to me that the American Express Gold card didn't show up in the list of the best cards for 2014. It was the best rewards credit card for 2013, and it's a strong contender again this year.What do you think about these results? Are you surprised by any of them? How have your favorite cards changed from year to year?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.But I'm not asking which credit card is best for YOU. I want to know which one offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.That is to say, which credit card best reflects the interests of most of the American public?Today's topic is the result of my frustration with my own credit cards. I've tried to be a good cardholder in the past, but with the amount of credit card marketing I see, I've started to wonder: am I being ripped off by my credit card issuer?Based on this, I'd like to offer a little experiment for the readers of Get Rich Slowly.I want to know which card you believe is the best for most people in the U.S.So, what do you say, fellow GRS readers? I challenge you to choose the best credit card (or combination of credit cards) that represents the interest of the majority of Americans.If your choice isn't currently available, what do you think would be the best offer?A few notes about the contest:I don't know that this is possible, but you may choose to answer based on an ideal card. For instance, you could state that the best credit card is a 0% card with low annual fees and no foreign transaction fees.You don't need to specify which card you're talking about, just the general concept. If you're talking about the Chase Sapphire, then be specific. If you're talking about a 0% card, then just say 0%. I won't be able to give a prize to everyone who answers, but I'd like to see people answer to the best of their abilities.I'm not sure I can get prizes, but I'd like to try to give a prize to one lucky winner. If I can't get a prize, then I'll give away something cool that I have, but nothing from a credit card issuer. If you're curious, I can offer a free copy of my book, or an autographed copy. I can even send it as an audio book, which means I could also offer a book for anyone who can't read.If I get no response, then I guess I'll simply pick the American Express card with the lowest interest rate. (I believe this is currently at 9.74%, but I may be wrong.) But I would prefer to give away something for the person who gives me the best answer.If I get 100 responses, I'll choose one winner. If I get less than 100 responses, then I'll pick based on quality and not quantity.In the end, I want to see which credit card is the best for the majority of Americans. This could also lead to a discussion on how many cards one should own, but we'll save that for another time.So, let's see what you've got. Let me know which card you believe is best. You may comment below or you can email me.The contest will end at 5pm on Sunday, July 18th, 2010, Mountain Time. (This is 1pm Pacific Time, 4pm Eastern.) If you need an extra day to get your entry, I'll consider that as well.I'm looking forward to reading your entries and, more importantly, finding the best credit card for most Americans.Ask the Reader / Credit CardsI’m always leery of what credit card offers are all about because they can change at any time. I’ve never had anything but good experiences with my Bank One credit card (I know, I know, Chase), but I always pay in full every month and don’t do any balances transfers or anything so I don’t really care if I have the lowest rates possible. If I ever go into debt, then that’s a different story. I do love the cash back though.If the best credit card for Americans would have the lowest rates possible with no balance transfers or interest, it would be the Discover More card.The current rate is 7.99% for purchases and 7.99% for balance transfers.The interest rate doesn’t change throughout the year.There is no annual fee, but you can get a $25 gift card if you apply through the Gift Card Mall.No annual fee on the card, free for one year with no balance transfer.Beyond that, I think what is best for the majority is the Citi Rewards Card. This card offers two different rewards programs: ThankYou points and AAdvantage miles. The card offers a low interest rate of 6.9% and no annual fee. If I could use a different card as a secondary card, I would pick up one of the rewards cards since they both offer free flights, but there is no point in getting another credit card unless you need the points for a flight.This is my choice, as well. I pay it off every month, and the annual percentage rate has been under 7% since I got it. I’m looking forward to the new Citi Forward card, which will pay off my balance after 12 months, at an interest rate of 0%.I agree. If I could, I’d have one of those cards in my wallet. I’m so happy with my Discover card and can’t wait for it to go away. It’s one of my favorites.My answer is the same as a few others. I use a rewards card for all of my purchases. Right now it’s the Barclaycard Arrival Rewards card which has a 1.5% cash back rate. The only downside is the foreign transaction fee, but I travel so much I haven’t found anything with better rewards.The rewards program is so great that I’m considering not applying for other cards at all and instead use the one I already have. I just haven’t gotten to the point where I’ve used the rewards enough to justify giving up the 2% back I would get with a new card.I use the rewards card because I’m cheap. I don’t want to pay 5-10% in interest every year.As I said on my blog post, I don’t have any credit card debt. So for me, the lowest possible interest rate is the best thing to have. My card, however, is a “rewards” card, so I don’t get that lowest rate.I do love my rewards, but I’d have to say that I don’t know which would be the best card, because there are so many factors at play. If I could only have one card, I’d say I would use a no fee, low-interest card.If I could, I’d use a rewards card and use the rewards to pay off the card in full every month. That way I would get some benefits from a rewards card, and still have a low interest rate.I think I would have to agree with the Discover card with no annual fee and a lower interest rate. I know that I can’t pay off my balance in full every month (I’m too irresponsible) so I think it’s better to pay low interest and avoid paying it in the first place.I’d have to go with the Discover More.My answer is Discover More, too. They have the lowest rate I can find and no annual fee. My husband has the Chase Freedom, which he loves, but since he’s on a fixed income now it’s harder to get his credit line up enough to get the points he was getting. I use a rewards card for all my purchases, but there are times I’ve been overcharged or paid more than I should have and I wish I had a low rate on my purchases. I have the USAA Classic Mastercard which gives me 1.5% back on all purchases. It is paid in full each month. The rate is about 7.7% which is pretty good for a low credit card but not the lowest. I do wish I could pay interest on a card with a lower rate, but I have no debt and don’t need the extra money.Mike, here is my answer…The credit card that I think most people will benefit from in terms of lower interest rates, rewards, etc. is probably the Amex Everyday card that pays 10% cash back at selected places. However, since that is not an option to many people, I would pick the Discover More card as the best all around card because of its low rate, low fees and flexibility.For most Americans the card that’s probably best is the Discover More card. With a 7.99% rate for new card holders, there’s not much better than that. However, if you don’t like Discover because they’re a little too liberal with your card, then a Citi card might be a better option. There are currently a few 0% interest rates out there. But, like I said, those don’t last very long. I know you said “the best card”, but there really isn’t any one card that’s ideal. The best card is going to be a 0% rate if you can get one. However, I think the Discover More is still the card to go with.I like the rewards cards, but I like a good rate, too, so I guess I’ll go with the Discover More Card.I think the best card would be the Capital One Venture card, which offers an annual fee of $0, a variable APR of 9.9%, and no foreign transaction fee. I would choose the Capital One Venture card for the simple reason that it is not a rewards card. The reason for choosing a rewards card over the Capital One Venture card is to be able to get the benefit of the rewards in the form of cash back to pay down the credit card debt.I would recommend the AMEX Blue card. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. You could have started by saying, “What’s your favorite card?” and then I would have said it’s the Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card. But now I have to tell you I’ve stopped carrying that card and I have no idea how to pick a favorite.But it’s worth noting: For most consumers, there is not a one-size-fits-all card. It depends on your credit score, your spending habits, and your income. So before you get too deep in that discussion, you might want to know what I know about you first, and whether you're a “spender” or a “saver.” If you’re a spender, you’re probably paying a higher interest rate than someone with a saver card.And the other thing is, if you’re a traveler who travels often, you may be better served by getting one of the travel cards, because they offer a few more points per dollar spent, so that if you spend a lot of money on travel, you get a lot of points. And for those people, I would definitely recommend a travel card.The cards I’m talking about here are all good cards for most consumers, and are very versatile. They offer 0% APR financing for 12 months and up to 18 months, and they have good cash-back or rewards programs. You also have the ability to transfer your points to frequent flyer miles. If you’re a traveler, that’s the kind of card you want to get.There are other benefits to getting the Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card. In addition to 0% APR financing, you also get a 10,000-point sign-up bonus (worth about $1,250). This card also gives you three times the points per dollar spent at restaurants and travel, which is worth a lot more.The Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card is one of the most flexible, well-rounded cards available to consumers. If you have good credit and spend a lot of money on travel, this card is a great choice.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The most important feature of a credit card, in my mind, is its APR rate (annual percentage rate) because it determines how much money you'll spend over time in interest. If a card has a low rate and no annual fee, it's ideal.My personal favorite, because it offers no annual fee, is the Bank of America Travel Rewards Credit Card, which offers 1.5 points for every dollar spent and a $0 balance transfer fee. This is an excellent travel card because of the free Global Entry application and rewards points that can be redeemed for statement credits, gift cards, and travel.But I'm interested to know if you've discovered any other cards that are just as good as the BofA Travel Rewards card. Feel free to tell me about them in the comments below. I'm looking forward to your feedback!My favorite card is the Wells Fargo Propel American Express. It earns 3x points per dollar on eating, ordering in, and gas station, 1.5x points per dollar on all other purchases, plus a $100 cash reward after spending $1,000 within 3 months. The card also has no annual fee.The Bank of America Travel Rewards Card is the best deal on the market.I have the B of A Travel Rewards card and really like it. But, I also have the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. With the CSP, you can redeem your points for statement credits to cover any travel or dining purchase of $100 or more. So I like to use the Chase for those kinds of things and the BofA card for everything else.I love the Capital One Venture Card.I also have the Sapphire preferred card, and I'd agree with what Jim said.I like that Chase Sapphire Preferred, too!Capital One is pretty awesome, too.I have the Discover It and like it very much.I'm not a big fan of travel rewards cards. I'd rather save my points for airfare and hotels than save a few cents on each purchase I make.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Personally, I'm a fan of the PenFed Pathfinder Rewards credit card because of it's cash-back rewards program. However, I do find the APR a little bit higher than what I would like.The reason why I like the PenFed card is because it's cash-back rewards program is similar to the Amex SimplyCash rewards program (my favorite Amex rewards program).For those of you who don't already know, here are the details.Cash Back Rewards Program: PenFed offers two levels of cash back rewards. Each level varies slightly in the number of rewards points and rewards rate you will receive. For PenFed Platinum credit cardholders (and their immediate family members), you will receive an extra 10% cash back rewards bonus.SimplyCash is the name of the Amex card that has a cash-back rewards program similar to PenFed Platinum. The cash-back rewards are identical to those offered by PenFed.SimplyCash rewards are also similar to the Discover It card, in that you receive 5% cash back on purchases in rotating categories each quarter, up to $1,500 in purchases each quarter.Both Amex and Discover also offer intro APRs on both purchases and balance transfers. However, I do prefer PenFed's cash-back rewards program because it allows you to receive up to 2.5% in cash-back rewards (similar to the Discover It).The reason I like cash-back rewards is because the rewards are usually deposited directly into my checking account.Low APR: The PenFed credit card has a variable APR of 9.99%. The only Amex card that offers a lower APR is the SimplyCash from American Express (9.74%).Low Intro APR: As I mentioned above, the PenFed credit card offers a low intro APR of 0% for 12 months on both purchases and balance transfers.Personal Financial Security: The Federal Credit Union offers financial services to members and non-members alike. However, if you are a member of the Federal Credit Union, you will enjoy lower fees. Additionally, you may qualify for more financial services and lower interest rates.As you can see, the PenFed credit card offers a combination of perks that no other credit card company currently offers.As far as I know, PenFed is the only credit card company that offers cash-back rewards with a low APR and a low intro APR. In addition, PenFed offers low fees for both members and non-members alike.Additionally, the PenFed credit card is easy to qualify for because you do not have to be a member of the Federal Credit Union.What do you think of the PenFed credit card?Do you prefer a low intro APR, a low interest rate, or cash-back rewards?I would say the PenFed card is a good deal. The low APR is important and the cash-back rewards are a bonus. It's a bit more complicated than the Amex SimplyCash though, and it's not as easy to earn the full 5% in rewards.I have the American Express SimplyCash Plus card and I think it is a great product. I would definitely recommend this to someone who's looking for a cash-back rewards card.I think the cash-back rewards program of PenFed is better than the Amex SimplyCash.What type of credit card do you use?I use the PenFed credit card.I use an Amex card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.For my money, I'd have to say the Sapphire Preferred® Card. I know, I know... it's not the best rewards card out there, but that's not why I love it.What's so great about the Sapphire Preferred® Card?You'll love it for its combination of perks and flexibility. Sure, it's not going to get you a huge return on spending. But it offers a ton of other perks that make it worth having in your wallet.Perks are a great way to get more bang for your buck. You'll want to look for a card that offers the biggest return on spending possible for you and your lifestyle. This isn't a card for someone who travels a ton for business. If you're looking for a card like that, check out our guide to the best travel credit cards.This card offers a sign-up bonus of 50,000 bonus points. That's a $500 value when redeemed through the Chase Ultimate Rewards program for travel.The Chase Ultimate Rewards program offers travelers incredible flexibility. You can get cash back, buy gift cards, transfer points to travel partners, or book travel directly through the Chase portal.One of the best ways to maximize your travel rewards is through the Chase portal. You can book just about any hotel, flight, or rental car through the portal. Just keep in mind that you won't be able to get the full 2% cash back rate when using the portal. You can also only book travel using the Chase portal once every 120 days. This makes it great for travelers that use their points in place of miles or redeem points for travel rewards every 6 months or so.The card also has no foreign transaction fees. This makes it great for travelers who are planning to use the card while traveling internationally. This perk will save you a lot of money. I've written an entire article on travel rewards cards, that might help you decide whether this is the right card for you.The card also comes with tons of perks, some of which you can't get on any other card.This card offers free WiFi when you book through the Chase portal. If you're traveling a lot for business, this is a great perk.You also get Priority Pass Select membership for two free years. The Priority Pass Select membership allows you and up to two guests free entrance into over 1,000 airport lounges worldwide. The card also comes with an annual travel protection benefit of up to $1,000 per trip for covered reasons such as theft or injury.Finally, you get car rental insurance, purchase protection, extended warranty, and return protection. All of this is for a $0 annual fee.If you have a large purchase in mind and can't pay it off right away, it's great to have the flexibility of a credit card that doesn't charge a huge APR. That way you can put the purchase on a low APR card, pay it off over time, and still have the cash you need.The Sapphire Preferred® Card comes with a 12-month 0% APR for purchases. You can use this card to make a purchase and pay it off in 12 months without paying interest.That being said, it's best if you pay off the balance in full before the 0% APR expires. Otherwise, you'll be stuck with a huge balance and high APRs.You can read my full Sapphire Preferred® Card review here.How about the Sapphire Reserve® Card?I have a love-hate relationship with this card. I love the sign-up bonus but hate the APRs. If you're interested in this card, check out the full review.Have you had any experience with either card? Let me know in the comments!Disclaimer: Chase Bank is a credit card issuer that compensates us when you click on our links. However, this does not influence our opinions. Our goal is to create the most comprehensive credit card reviews and comparisons to help you make the best financial decisions for your family.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm not a loyalty to one credit card company over another - I'm happy to shop around. However, if you're loyal to a certain company, which card(s) do you carry and why?I love to get the best reward programs, I get a great reward with my Barclaycard and it offers great rates and rewards!I don't know about the best, but I like my citi platinum that I got with the 0% on the balance transfer for the past 2 months.My first card is the Chase Sapphire. I do travel a lot so I enjoy the benefits that I get from it.I just signed up for my first credit card and I will be getting one that has 12 months interest-free.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I recently decided to change from my old credit card to a new one, and I'd love to hear about your experiences.I've been working from home for the past year. I can't count how many times I've tried to order a coffee and realized I didn't have cash with me. I always assumed there were lots of places that took credit cards. But when I looked at the ATM machine, I saw "Cash Only." I was out of cash and without any way to get more. It's hard to imagine my life without ATM access.Throughout the past year, I've been collecting a list of credit cards with low interest rates.While working from home, I find that I get hungry a lot. I like to go out and find something to eat, but I don't always know what's around the corner. To avoid overeating, I often take along a bag of pretzels. I like pretzels that are warm, crunchy, and salty.I used to be in sales, and I remember traveling to conventions and trade shows, where sales reps spent lots of time on the road. They'd get in their car, drive all over the country, and stay in hotels when they got there.If they were in the hospitality business, they'd also have to deal with travel agents. Those guys would be calling all the time, trying to sell them tickets, hotel rooms, and transportation. They needed some way to keep those people away.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Here's my suggestion: If you pay off your balance in full each month and want a card with no annual fee that's designed with that type of consumer in mind, the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card ($0 introductory annual fee for the first year, then $95) should make your shortlist.This card is best for someone who:Makes purchases in the U.S. and doesn't mind foreign transaction fees. (Learn more in our guide on what to look for in a travel credit card.)Is concerned about building their credit score. The Quicksilver card's low interest rates, low APR, and low credit utilization rate are important factors in building credit.A high-earning card that rewards you for paying in fullThe Quicksilver Card from Capital One has a 0% introductory annual percentage rate (APR) for 15 months. It also features a low ongoing APR (13.99%-23.99% variable APR) and an impressive rewards rate. Cardholders earn 1.5% cash back on every purchase.That is a very high earning rate and compares to many other travel rewards cards. The Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card earns 2x miles per dollar spent (up to $50,000 per calendar year; then 1.5x), while the Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card earns 1.25x miles on all purchases. The Capital One® Venture Rewards Card is the only card I recommend for most business travelers, however, because of its large welcome bonus, ability to redeem for any travel purchase at a one-to-one ratio (and no blackout dates), and generous 10,000-mile annual bonus offer after spending $20,000 on the card during a calendar year.But if you prefer a card that rewards you even more than the Venture card, then I recommend the Capital One® Venture® X Rewards Credit Card ($395 annual fee), which features 10x miles on hotels and rental cars booked through Capital One Travel.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card rewards rate applies to all purchases, and you don't have to worry about accruing additional or specialized categories. However, you do need to use the card to make everyday purchases, such as groceries and gas, if you want to earn 1.5% cash back.I don't recommend using the Quicksilver card for any purchases that you could earn more rewards on. And I don't recommend using it to pay for travel expenses if you plan to redeem your miles or cash back for travel, because you'll earn only a fraction of the total rewards value.The Quicksilver card's rewards rate is high compared to many other cards and its ability to earn a substantial return is another reason why it's a solid choice for building your credit.The Quicksilver card doesn't charge an annual fee for the first year and then a $95 annual fee. I prefer this because many cards charge an annual fee and also have an introductory 0% APR offer, which can lure you into the trap of spending money that you'll need to pay interest on after the offer expires.The Capital One Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card's cash-back rewards are pretty simple to understand: 1.5% cash back on every purchase you make, with no caps or limits.Cash rewards are deposited into your account each month as a statement credit. You'll then be able to see your rewards in your account online.I like the simplicity of the Quicksilver card's rewards program. Capital One has a bunch of other cards that offer great perks, such as bonus categories or large welcome bonuses. But those cards can be confusing, especially for beginners, because they have many moving parts.The Capital One Quicksilver Card also has a long introductory APR period and a low ongoing APR, both of which will help you pay off your credit card balance and improve your credit score.When the Quicksilver card's introductory APR period ends, your ongoing APR is 13.99%-23.99% variable APR.The Quicksilver card doesn't have any fees. That includes no foreign transaction fees, which is important if you're looking to redeem the cash rewards for travel.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card does come with some drawbacks.For one, you'll pay foreign transaction fees when you use your card abroad. The fee is 3%, and it will lower the rewards rate you earn. But it's still a great option to use for international travel because it's a no-fee card and you can earn cash back rewards even when you use it outside the U.S.This card also doesn't offer additional or specialized bonus categories. That means you won't earn more points on dining out or gas, which can increase your rewards value.This card also doesn't come with a sign-up bonus or a travel rewards bonus. The lack of a welcome bonus and travel rewards offer makes it a poor choice for someone who frequently uses their credit card for travel, especially if they're looking to redeem the cash rewards for travel.In that case, I recommend Capital One's Venture line of cards. The Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card and the Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card both come with huge bonus offers.Capital One Venture cards also come with the Capital One Wallet app.The Venture card's $95 annual fee is on par with many other travel rewards cards and makes it a great value if you're looking to use it for travel. The VentureOne card has no annual fee and a smaller welcome bonus, but is still a decent choice for someone who's looking to build their credit and start traveling with a credit card.Both the Venture and VentureOne cards come with no foreign transaction fees, 1.25x or 2x miles for every dollar spent (up to $50,000 per year; then 1x), and a 100,000-mile sign-up bonus.If you're just looking for a good rewards card that doesn't charge an annual fee, the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card ($0 introductory annual fee for the first year, then $95) is a great option.It's easy to use because you're able to earn rewards on all of your purchases and the rewards are credited to your account as cash rewards, which can then be used as you see fit.The card's introductory APR of 0% for 15 months is also impressive, and it's not too hard to qualify for this introductory offer if you have good credit. But once the introductory period expires, you'll pay a variable interest rate that ranges from 13.99%-23.99%, which is a little higher than some of its competitors.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card's rewards rate is 1.5% cash back on every purchase you make. You'll also receive a $150 cash-back bonus after you spend $500 on purchases within the first three months.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is a great choice for someone who wants to earn cash rewards with no annual fee.However, it's not a great choice if you want to earn points or miles for travel. Instead, I recommend the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card or the Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card if you want to use your card for travel.I recommend the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card for most travelers, because it's the only card that gives you the opportunity to earn a ton of miles without having to worry about category spending caps.The Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card earns 2x miles on all purchases (up to $50,000 per year; then 1.5x) and has a 0% introductory APR offer for 15 months. It also has no annual fee and a large welcome bonus.The Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card, which I'll talk about more later, is a good choice for beginners because it has a smaller welcome bonus offer.If you're looking for a cash-back rewards card with no annual fee, you might consider the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card. It's a solid choice that gives you the chance to earn a decent amount of cash rewards.But if you want a travel rewards card, I recommend Capital One's Venture line of cards, which include the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card and the Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card.Both the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card and the Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card offer great travel perks.The Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card comes with a 0% introductory APR for 15 months, no annual fee, and a $200 travel credit that is credited to your card annually. It also has a 100,000-mile welcome bonus and is the only card that offers travel rewards for purchases that you make abroad.The Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card is a good choice if you're a beginner and are just starting out with credit cards. It has a smaller welcome bonus and an APR that is slightly higher than the Venture card, but still gives you a chance to earn a lot of miles.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is a good choice for someone who's looking to earn cash rewards.But if you're looking for travel rewards, you should probably look elsewhere.This is a pretty good question. I don't know how to answer this question without knowing what your credit score is.But if you're a beginner with a low credit score and are looking to build your credit, I'd suggest getting a card that offers a low interest rate and low annual fee.These are two of the best cards on the market today, because they have no annual fees and low APRs. The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is a good choice because it offers a 0% introductory APR for 15 months.But if you're looking for a card that will give you more cash-back rewards, I'd recommend the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card. It offers a 0% introductory APR for 15 months and has no annual fee.But if you want to earn cash back, I'd recommend the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card. It's a great card that offers a lot of flexibility and is easy to use.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. When deciding which one to choose, you should always pay attention to their interest rates as they could significantly affect the overall cost of the purchases you make.That being said, if you can pay off your entire balance every month, you shouldn't need to worry about interest rates. However, for those who are not good at keeping up with their credit cards, you may want to consider the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card, which has one of the lowest ongoing interest rates on the market.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is a no annual fee card that offers 1.5% cash back on all purchases. The sign-up bonus is a one-time $200 statement credit after spending $500 on purchases within 3 months of account opening. Plus, you can earn 5% cash back on hotels and rideshare services purchased through Capital One Travel, up to $12,500 spent in a year.For more credit cards that are available, you can see our list of Best Credit Cards.What Credit Cards Offer 5% Cash Back?Although the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is the only one that offers 5% cash back, there are other cards that offer 3% cash back in certain categories, which you can see below.3% cash back on dining, entertainment, popular streaming services, groceries, transit and more.3% cash back on dining, entertainment, travel, gas and more.3% cash back on dining, entertainment, gas and more.3% cash back on dining, entertainment and transit.3% cash back on travel and dining.The information for the Citi Double Cash Card, Bank of America® Customized Cash Rewards credit card, Chase Freedom Unlimited® has been collected independently by The Points Guy. The card details on this page have not been reviewed or provided by the card issuer.How Can I Find the Best Credit Card for Me?Ask yourself what type of spender you are. Are you a foodie that dines out all the time, or a traveler that only uses your credit card at restaurants and airports? The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is perfect for anyone who wants to get 5% cash back on dining, 3% cash back on rideshare services and 1.5% cash back on everything else.If you spend less on travel and dining, then the Discover it® Cash Back is an excellent choice, as you can earn 5% cash back on up to $1,500 in purchases in your first year. If you only use your credit card for gas and groceries, then the Chase Freedom Unlimited® is a fantastic choice as it earns 5% cash back in that category up to $1,500 in purchases in your first year.Do You Want to Get a Sign-Up Bonus?Another factor to consider is whether you want a sign-up bonus or not. If you want to get a sign-up bonus, then you need to make sure that the bonus is worth it to you. Most of the cash back credit cards offer a generous welcome offer.The Bank of America® Customized Cash Rewards Credit Card offers up to $2,600 cash back if you spend $3,000 on purchases in the first 90 days of opening the account.The Citi Custom Cash Card offers $200 back if you spend $750 on purchases in the first 3 months.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card offers a one-time $200 statement credit after spending $500 on purchases within 3 months of account opening.How Much Can You Afford to Pay?The amount you can spend on your credit card should also play a role in your decision. If you do not have a good budget, then you probably won't be able to keep up with your credit card balance. It is important to note that you should always pay off your balance in full every month as interest rates can be quite expensive.Do you want a cash back credit card? Do you like the idea of getting 5% cash back on your dining and travel purchases? If you answered yes to these questions, then the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card may be the best choice for you.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. It is of course subjective but I'd be curious to know what card most people would recommend to someone who is looking for a solid credit card.It is a very broad question and it would depend on a variety of factors. My advice, which I think is very reasonable would be to focus on building up credit first. Then, once you have 6 months to a year of positive history, then you can get a credit card and find one that fits your needs.Credit cards are not that difficult. First you need to have good credit (600+), then you need to find a card that you can qualify for. It sounds like you want to find the best card and I'm not sure you can find it without good credit and a year or so of positive history.Good credit is your starting point.It's a little hard to answer because your definition of what you think is the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility could be completely different from other people.I have a few credit cards, but the two I always use are my American Express Blue Cash Everyday and my Chase Sapphire Preferred. These are both good cards with low interest rates (10% and 15% respectively) and are great for earning cash back. I get the equivalent of about 3% cash back on most of my purchases. For example, I got 5% back for groceries and gas using my Blue Cash Everyday card. Both are very flexible and the rewards don't expire like a lot of rewards cards.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.In 2016, Chase introduced its own no annual fee version of the Sapphire Preferred® Card. The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card now charges a $95 annual fee, but is also available without an annual fee.While I personally love and prefer the no annual fee version of the Sapphire Preferred Card, that doesn’t mean it’s the best credit card for you. Here’s a comparison of the two versions of the Sapphire Preferred.One of the major perks that comes with the Sapphire Preferred Card is the signup bonus. While you’ll get the same signup bonus, the no annual fee Sapphire Preferred earns the bonus faster than its fee-based counterpart. The reason for this is that in order to be eligible for the signup bonus, you must spend a minimum of $4,000 in the first 3 months your account is open.The fee-based Sapphire Preferred card charges $95 per year, and while that fee can be offset by the value you get from the card, it’s still a hassle to pay. As a result, the annual fee is one of the biggest differences between the two cards.The Sapphire Preferred’s signup bonus is $500 when you spend $4,000 in the first three months. That’s a 12.5% return on your spending, and a 1.25% return on all your other spending.The Chase Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card has a much smaller signup bonus.This is a good bonus, but if you spend at least $4,000 in the first three months, it is worth it to pay the annual fee for the Sapphire Preferred. If you don’t spend that much, the $0 annual fee Sapphire Preferred will get you less value from the card, since the signup bonus is worth less than the $0 annual fee.On the other hand, you can always pay the $95 annual fee and use the 50,000 Ultimate Rewards points you get from the bonus. That way, you get a 10% return on your spending.When it comes to rewards, there are two ways to redeem Chase Ultimate Rewards points. You can either redeem them directly for cash, or you can transfer your points to one of Chase’s airline partners. I typically transfer my points to United MileagePlus or Southwest, but I also like that I can book travel through Chase.The Chase Sapphire Preferred no annual fee version of the card offers fewer redemption options than its fee-based counterpart. While the fee-based Sapphire Preferred offers 10 different redemption options, the no annual fee card only offers three redemption options.Here’s the important part: you will only be able to redeem your points for cash if you don’t pay the annual fee on the card. If you pay the annual fee, you can use your points to book travel, or transfer them to one of Chase’s airline partners.It’s easy to see how this change came about. For one thing, it makes sense that a no annual fee credit card would offer fewer redemption options than a fee-based credit card. That’s just the nature of the card. The more benefits a card offers, the more expensive it is. In the case of the fee-based Sapphire Preferred, the card is $95 per year.On the other hand, it makes less sense that the no annual fee version of the card only offers three redemption options. For example, the Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card doesn’t allow you to redeem your points for gift cards, cash, or merchandise. So why not offer all of those redemption options? I guess it’s the same reason that many airline co-branded cards don’t offer the same redemption options as their non-co-branded siblings: co-branded cards typically have lower redemption values than non-co-branded cards. That’s why the fee-based Sapphire Preferred offers the option of redeeming your points for 1.25 cents each, while the Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card doesn’t.Which brings me to my next point: 1.25 cents per point is a bad value.There are three travel redemption options for the Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card. You can redeem your points for travel booked through Chase, for cash, or you can transfer your points to an airline partner.The three airline partners you can transfer your points to are United MileagePlus, Southwest, and British Airways.For comparison, the Sapphire Preferred fee-based card offers more travel redemption options. You can redeem your points for travel booked through Chase, for cash, or you can transfer your points to airline partners.If you’re interested in transferring your Ultimate Rewards points to Southwest, you’ll want to keep in mind that you’ll only earn 1.125 Ultimate Rewards points per dollar spent when you use the Sapphire Preferred card to pay for travel at Southwest.com. If you spend $2,000 on the card and travel exclusively with Southwest Airlines, you’ll get 2,250 points instead of 2,270 points.Overall, you’ll get a better value if you’re transferring your points to an airline partner.As far as rewards rates go, the Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card has a lower base rate than the fee-based Sapphire Preferred.The Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card offers 2 points per dollar spent at restaurants and travel, and 1 point per dollar spent on all other purchases. In comparison, the Sapphire Preferred fee-based card offers 2 Ultimate Rewards points per dollar spent on travel booked through Chase, 2 Ultimate Rewards points per dollar spent on dining, and 1 Ultimate Rewards point per dollar spent on all other purchases.Here’s the important part: there’s no difference in the rewards rates between the Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card and the Sapphire Preferred fee-based card if you use the no annual fee card to pay for travel booked through Chase.So you might be thinking: since there’s no difference in the rewards rates between the no annual fee card and the fee-based card if you use the no annual fee card to pay for travel booked through Chase, why bother paying the annual fee on the fee-based card?For starters, you’ll get more Ultimate Rewards points. And while the rewards rate of the Sapphire Preferred card is identical to that of the Ink Preferred Business card, I prefer to redeem my points for travel instead of for cash.The Chase Sapphire Preferred no annual fee card has the same signup bonus as the fee-based Sapphire Preferred card. The fee-based Sapphire Preferred card has a higher rewards rate, but the rewards rate difference is offset by the fact that the fee-based card offers more redemption options. If you’re going to use the no annual fee card to pay for travel booked through Chase, there’s no difference in the rewards rate between the two cards. But if you’re going to use the no annual fee card to redeem your points for cash, gift cards, or merchandise, you’ll get more value from the fee-based card.Overall, I’d recommend that you sign up for the Sapphire Preferred card with the annual fee. The signup bonus is worth it. However, I wouldn’t recommend the no annual fee Sapphire Preferred card unless you’re only using the card to pay for travel booked through Chase.</s>
