<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I have several, and use them in combination. I think that most people have no idea what kind of perks and rewards are available with credit cards, so I figured that I'd ask, here. What is the one card that you like most?I also like Chase Freedom Rewards. 5% cash back on all purchases and no annual fees. I have a personal credit card and a business credit card through Chase, and I never pay a fee to have them and use them. I like that Chase offers different rewards for different types of purchases. I do most of my shopping at local businesses and I usually take the rewards that best fit my shopping needs.The one I like the best is a Chase Freedom card. I have a Discover card that has been a pain in my you know what, so I'll probably end up canceling it. I don't like Discover anymore, since they changed the terms of the rewards and now it's a pain to get ahold of anyone there.If you're gonna have a credit card, you gotta have the Freedom Rewards card. I do all my credit card shopping through there, and I've gotten some great rewards in the past few months.This is the card that I love to use for online shopping. They have some good rewards, and I'm not paying any fees for having the card, so I like it for that. I use it for all my online shopping needs, which is pretty much everything. They've been pretty good to me so far, so I'm sticking with it for now.I know this card from my mom. She used to have a credit card with that name and used to love to use it to buy things. She always said that she got some great rewards from it, and I believe her. I know that there are many credit card offers that give you a free something for every purchase, or something like that. I think that I'll just sign up for that kind of credit card, since I never pay any fees for having my credit cards.I have a few credit cards, and I use them depending on what kind of thing I'm doing. I like them because they give me a good rate and they always give me a free something with each purchase. It seems like there's always something new and exciting that they offer with each card, so I just keep using them.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I recently received a credit card for a new client. For the most part, I am happy with the offer. However, I wish it included some additional features, such as no foreign transaction fees, no balance transfer fees, and travel and purchase protection.I am currently carrying two credit cards with different interest rates and different levels of financial flexibility. In an ideal world, I'd love to be able to consolidate my payments and be able to enjoy the rewards from one credit card. I've looked at a few travel rewards cards, such as Chase Sapphire Reserve, Citi Prestige, and American Express® Gold Card, but most of these cards are not designed to carry a balance.I believe that one of the most important perks of a credit card is the potential to earn rewards on spending. But I think that one of the most important features of a credit card is the opportunity to consolidate debt and pay down debt quickly.While I have two credit cards right now, I'm curious to see how other credit cards compare in terms of interest rates, rewards, and financial flexibility.Do any other readers use a credit card as a payment system or as a debt consolidation tool? Which credit card offers the best combination of features?I have a very specific reason for asking this question. I'm considering using a new credit card to pay down student loan debt. I currently have two different credit cards. One has a low interest rate and offers no rewards. The other offers 1.5% cash back on every purchase and has a low introductory rate. I am currently considering consolidating my debt on this new credit card.The new card is from Discover. It is called Discover it® – It's Cash Back Rewards. It is a cash back credit card. The cash back rate is 1.5% on all purchases. I don't have a specific reason to choose this credit card. I would like to know which credit cards offer the best combination of rewards, low interest rates, and financial flexibility.In the past, I've been offered rewards cards with great sign up bonuses and rewards. However, I was never happy with the level of flexibility offered by these cards. As a result, I've never been happy with the benefits offered by these cards.I'm interested to know which credit cards offer the best combination of features.Do any of you have any recommendations?Labels: American Express® Gold Card, balances, Citi Prestige, Chase Sapphire Reserve, credit cards, Debt Consolidation, Discover it® – It's Cash Back Rewards, Interest Rates, rewards, student loans, travel rewardsHey Steve, I'm curious to know what are the advantages and disadvantages of a credit card. I don't think a lot of people know about the different types of credit cards. I'm wondering if anyone has experience with credit cards that they can share. I'm especially interested in the pros and cons of a credit card. Are there advantages and disadvantages? Do you know of any other credit cards out there that are worth looking at? I'd like to know what are some of the most important things to consider when deciding whether or not to use a credit card.Labels: Citi Prestige, Chase Sapphire Reserve, credit cards, Debt Consolidation, rewards, student loans, travel rewards</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.If you haven't discovered it already, your credit card is a fantastic tool. It's a personal financial assistant, one that's in your pocket and ready to help you manage your finances when you need it.I'm not talking about the basic features, such as cash back rewards, travel benefits, or insurance protections. Those are nice perks, but you can get those with many other credit cards.I'm talking about the benefits that can help you manage your cash flow and grow your savings over time. The things you can use right now to improve your personal finances.Too often we talk about credit cards and we focus on the cost. We look at how much interest we have to pay and whether or not we're getting cash back or rewards points. These are important questions, but they're only half of the story.The other half is how the credit card impacts your cash flow, and that's what really matters.The best credit cards give you access to financial tools that can grow your savings and help you manage your expenses and cash flow more effectively.This is the kind of credit card that's right for you:It's an open-ended line of credit. That means you can spend up to a pre-approved credit limit.It offers low interest rates, which is important because carrying a balance means you're going to pay interest on your balance each month. That means more money you can spend in other ways.It doesn't charge any balance transfer fees, which is a nice perk.It comes with a 0% interest introductory period, which means you don't have to pay interest on new purchases or balance transfers for a set period of time.It has a rewards program, which gives you a little extra cash back or travel miles for purchases you make.You can use the points to pay for part of your purchase, or you can redeem them for cash back.It has a long 0% interest introductory period, which is great because you can use it to consolidate credit card debt or to make a major purchase.It has a low balance transfer fee, which means you don't have to pay a lot of money to transfer your balance.You can get cash back for your purchases.It has a cash back rewards program, which gives you money back on your purchases.It offers 0% APR financing on your purchases.It has a rewards program that gives you points for spending on your card.It has no annual fee.You can get cash back for your purchases.You can get a low introductory rate on your purchases.It has a rewards program, which gives you cash back on purchases.You can use your points to get cash back on your purchases.You can get a low introductory rate on your balance transfers.It has a 0% APR introductory period on balance transfers.It has a rewards program that gives you points for balance transfers.The best credit cards are the ones that give you the most benefits and perks. They have no annual fees, they offer great rewards programs, and they give you access to financial tools that can grow your savings and help you manage your expenses and cash flow more effectively.The credit card industry is changing and there are a lot of new credit cards that are worth considering. If you're looking for a new credit card, I encourage you to do your research and find the card that's right for you.I'm happy to help you with your credit card questions. You can call me at 800-555-1212 or email me at info@creditcardcomparison.com.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'd like to receive your responses via an email to creditcardquestions@gmail.com, but I'd prefer a phone call. You can also text me at (310) 298-6454 or leave a message at (561) 719-9000.How does the Citi Costco card stack up?I have two Costco credit cards with Citi that I've had for over two years and never have a problem. I have my monthly bill due and paid by the date. And if you are a member you always get the discount of course. I will never ever go back to Costco with out these credit cards.Why are all these questions coming out of your hat? This is the most ridiculous thing I've read today.Having an extra Costco card in the house might actually be a liability. Imagine what would happen if your spouse were to accidentally make a purchase on your card thinking it was theirs.I like having the Citi Costco Visa for the discount. I don't think Citi will be able to compete with AmEx for service. It would be interesting to see who would win if Citi tried to match the AmEx perks.Having an AmEx in your wallet gives me a good feeling. But I would much rather have a low APR, rewards card. I don't use my AmEx for small purchases, so the 2.5% discount wouldn't help me much.The rewards programs are nice, but I would never take a cashback reward over a lower APR.I'd love to know what you have in your wallet. And what you're doing to get that way.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.There are so many different options out there and each of them offers a unique blend of benefits and features, which makes it pretty challenging to decide which one is truly "the best".I don't think I'm alone in saying that I'm still searching for "the perfect" credit card. If you're like me, then let's take a look at three of the best credit cards available and decide which one might be best suited for you.Chase Sapphire Preferred: A popular travel rewards credit card. Earn 60,000 bonus points after spending $4,000 within three months of opening the account. Those 60,000 points are worth $750 when redeemed for travel through Chase Ultimate Rewards®.Chase Sapphire Reserve: Another travel rewards credit card that offers a number of features that cater to frequent travelers.In addition to 50,000 bonus points when you spend $4,000 within three months of opening the account, the card features a $300 annual travel credit, and no foreign transaction fees when used outside of the United States.Amex Gold Card: This rewards card offers 60,000 bonus points after spending $4,000 within the first three months of opening the account. Plus, you can earn 4x points on restaurant purchases, 3x points at grocery stores, and 1x points on all other purchases.You can also earn $100 in statement credit for booking a vacation through Amex Travel within the first six months of opening the account.Which Credit Card Should You Apply For?With so many credit cards to choose from, it's easy to feel overwhelmed by the choices.While we can't answer that question for you, we can share some insight into how you can make an informed decision.If you're primarily concerned about finding a credit card that has a 0% introductory APR on balance transfers, then you should consider the Chase Slate card.This credit card has an introductory APR of 0% for 15 months, and it offers up to $300 in cash back on your first year's purchases (depending on how much you spend).If you're looking for a card that gives you bonus points for dining and travel, then the Amex Gold card is a good option.This card offers a sign-up bonus of 50,000 points when you spend $4,000 within the first three months of opening the account.If you want a card with an annual fee, but it comes with some extra benefits, then the Chase Sapphire Preferred is worth considering.This card offers a sign-up bonus of 60,000 bonus points when you spend $4,000 within the first three months of opening the account.The Chase Sapphire Preferred also has an annual fee of $95, but you get complimentary rental car insurance and price protection on purchases.If you're looking for a no-annual-fee travel rewards card, then the Capital One Venture Rewards credit card may be a good choice.This card offers a sign-up bonus of 50,000 miles when you spend $3,000 within the first three months of opening the account.It also has no foreign transaction fees, which makes it ideal for travelers who plan on using the card overseas.When it comes to choosing a credit card, there is no single "best" card that is right for everyone.It's important to consider your specific financial situation and goals when making your decision.If you're looking for a card with an introductory APR on balance transfers, then the Chase Slate card is a good choice.If you want a card with bonus points for dining and travel, then the Amex Gold card is worth considering.If you're looking for a no-annual-fee travel rewards card, then the Capital One Venture Rewards credit card may be a good option.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.The survey results suggest that people are prioritizing perks over low interest rates. But, in general, we should be prioritizing low interest rates more than perks, and we'll see why in a moment.To conduct the survey, I posted a question on Reddit's /r/financialindependence (a community I'm a moderator of). It read: "Which credit card offers the best combination of low interest rate and/or low fees, perks, and/or rewards?"From the 48 responses I received, most people chose the Capital One Venture Rewards card. It's notable for its 0% APR intro period and large signup bonus. The card is best-in-class.Interestingly, though, 32% of respondents said they chose a card based on the rewards rate. That's a pretty large percentage, and shows that people aren't as obsessed with interest rates as I think they should be.I'm also concerned by the fact that only 2% of respondents said they choose cards based on low fees. That's a big problem, because I think it's the easiest way to lower your interest rate.What about you? Which credit card do you think offers the best combination of low interest rate and perks? Let me know in the comments!</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Sorry, that's a lot of qualifiers for the best credit card in Canada. You may be interested in a credit card that has a low annual fee, but a credit card that has a higher interest rate may still be more beneficial to your situation.Aside from being able to compare the cards side by side, there's also a few unique options you can choose from that we don't have here. For example, the Tangerine Money-Back Card offers cash back in the form of a cheque or an annual rewards bonus to their preferred charity.In the end, the best credit card for you will depend on your spending habits, your financial goals, and the current state of your finances. If you're interested in the best credit cards on the market, read on to find out which cards Canadians think deserve the top spot.The Ratehub.ca team reviewed our reader's most popular credit card picks to bring you the 12 best credit cards in Canada for 2020. Scotiabank® Visa* Platinum CardThe Scotiabank® Visa* Platinum Card offers a low annual fee and no foreign transaction fees for Canadians.The Scotiabank® Visa* Platinum Card is a decent no-frills card that's best suited for infrequent travellers. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I am considering a Chase Freedom Unlimited credit card, however, I have a credit score of 600 so I'm unsure if I will get approved.This isn't an affiliate link, but I do get paid a small commission if you use my referral code. This is the link I used to get mine (I can't guarantee you will get the same offer as I did).Also, you can check your credit score for free from Credit Karma here.I am in the 600-699 range and haven't applied for a credit card in years. I only recently opened a credit card for the first time in my adult life because I knew I needed to boost my credit score for a mortgage. I ended up getting a Chase Freedom Unlimited card, which I am really happy with! I think they have one of the better welcome bonuses available to a person with a 600 credit score. They are also very lenient with allowing you to increase your credit limit and won't check your credit score when you request a limit increase. This was an important factor for me because I wanted to use the card to increase my credit score. I haven't seen any other cards offer that option so it was a really nice plus for me!I don't know much about other cards out there. I know the Discover It card also offers a decent signup bonus. My husband has that one but I can't compare it to the Chase Freedom Unlimited because I have never used it (or had the chance to see his account!).I also don't know a lot about the best cards for people with a high interest rate because I don't know what they are.I am not trying to be a snob, but I'm really not sure what the best option would be for you. Your 600 credit score might actually be low enough that you will not be approved for the credit card I have. I would recommend checking out Credible to get a better idea of what card you might be approved for with your credit score.The Discover It card looks nice too! I'm in the 690 range and I've had the Discover card for the past 5 years. It offers a nice flat cash back rate (1-3%), no foreign transaction fees, and zero fraud liability. They are not the best in terms of welcome bonuses (I think it was a $50 bonus), but they don't do as many credit limit increases as Chase. You can check your FICO score for free here.I would go with the Capital One Quicksilver. 1.5% cash back with no foreign transaction fees and free FICO score monitoring. I think it has the best return on cash back.Thank you for the recommendation. I checked my FICO score and it is 648. It appears the Capital One Quicksilver credit card will be my next credit card. It seems to offer a great deal of benefits and I appreciate the free FICO score monitoring.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. It's a tough choice because there are a handful of great options.But in the end, I think it comes down to this: Which card's rewards program best fits your lifestyle? There's not one right answer. In fact, you may even choose to carry a couple of credit cards in your wallet to maximize earning power.That said, let's look at some of the best cards for rewards-driven consumers -- and why.Chase Sapphire Reserve® – Best for frequent travelersThe Chase Sapphire Reserve® is one of the best travel rewards cards on the market, and not just because of its 3x travel rewards rate. The 3x earning rate applies to all travel and dining purchases.And while some cards have restrictions on travel redemption dates, this one doesn't. You can use your Chase Sapphire Reserve rewards on any travel purchase. And rewards don't expire.The Chase Sapphire Reserve also offers a $300 annual travel credit that applies to any travel booked through the Chase Ultimate Rewards travel center. The $300 credit is available every year.But there's more. Chase Sapphire Reserve travelers receive primary rental car insurance. You can also purchase the Chase Sapphire Reserve Premium Waiver. This is a $95 waiver that gives you access to the Centurion lounges. You can even pay for your upgrades.The Chase Sapphire Reserve also offers exclusive perks such as free hotel and restaurant reservations and a $100 application fee credit for TSA PreCheck or Global Entry.In other words, the Chase Sapphire Reserve offers incredible value. You could use your rewards to pay for travel expenses. Or you could use your annual travel credit to offset the cost of a $1,200 flight. Either way, the Chase Sapphire Reserve makes a lot of sense.Chase Sapphire Preferred® – Best for average travelersThe Chase Sapphire Preferred® is one of my favorite rewards cards because it offers 2x points on every purchase.Points are redeemable for cash. But you can also transfer your rewards to Chase's Ultimate Rewards partner airlines and hotels. Ultimate Rewards points are also redeemable for 1.25 cents each.You don't need to be an expert in travel redemption to use the Chase Sapphire Preferred®. That's because you get $50 toward travel every year.The Chase Sapphire Preferred® also has a slew of other travel-related perks. You'll receive a $100 application fee credit every five years for Global Entry or TSA PreCheck.Chase Sapphire Preferred® also gives you a $60 hotel credit every year. That's an easy $60 in annual rewards, on top of your 2x points and $50 travel credit.The Chase Sapphire Preferred® also offers primary car rental insurance and access to the Centurion lounges.Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card – Best for general travelersThe Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card is a solid travel rewards card for consumers who don't want to pay an annual fee. It also offers a bonus of 40,000 miles after you spend $3,000 on purchases in the first 3 months of account opening. The $95 annual fee is waived for the first year.But the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card isn't just good for travel. It also offers great perks for general spenders.You'll receive 5 miles per dollar on purchases made at restaurants, entertainment, and at hotels. You'll also earn 2 miles per dollar on purchases made at grocery stores.You'll receive a $50 application credit every four years for TSA PreCheck. You'll also get access to a bunch of airport lounges.Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card cardholders can also redeem their rewards for airfare, which is probably the best option since this card offers 10,000 bonus miles for every redemption that results in a $300 flight.Chase Freedom Unlimited® – Best for cash backIf you're looking for a card that offers cash back on every purchase, I recommend the Chase Freedom Unlimited®.This card offers a $200 annual cash bonus after you spend $1,500 in your first three months. You'll also receive 1.5% cash back on every purchase.But the Chase Freedom Unlimited® also offers a lot of travel perks.You'll get trip cancellation and trip delay insurance. You'll also be covered for emergency medical care, emergency medical transportation, and baggage delay insurance.The Chase Freedom Unlimited® also offers a 12-month complimentary DoorDash membership. You'll also get free identity theft monitoring and reimbursement for certain fraudulent charges.But probably the best thing about this card is its $0 annual fee.The Amex® Gold Card – Best for diningThe Amex® Gold Card is one of the best cards for dining. You'll earn 4x points at U.S. restaurants and at U.S. supermarkets. You'll earn 3x points on flights booked directly with airlines or AmexTravel.com.You'll also receive a $100 dining credit every year. This credit is available for dining, including at restaurants and delivery apps.The Amex® Gold Card also offers other perks. You'll receive up to $100 in statement credits every year. You can also earn up to $120 in statement credits for Dell.com purchases.But there's more. You'll also get a $100 credit for Equinox + SoulCycle.If you're a frequent traveler, the Chase Sapphire Reserve is worth considering. But the Chase Sapphire Preferred® offers a similar bonus without an annual fee.It's also good to remember that you can carry multiple cards in your wallet. In other words, you can pick your favorite rewards program and get the best of both worlds.For example, you can carry the Amex® Gold Card and the Chase Sapphire Preferred®. The Amex® Gold Card is good for dining and entertainment purchases. The Chase Sapphire Preferred® is good for general purchases.But I know not everyone likes the idea of carrying multiple cards in their wallet. If you're a one-card kind of guy, I recommend the Chase Freedom Unlimited®.I hope this helps. If you'd like more personalized advice about the best rewards card for your lifestyle, please feel free to call.The information related to Chase Freedom Unlimited® was independently collected by CardRates for coverage on this site.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.The American Express Platinum Card (Rates & Fees) has been around for more than 25 years and remains a great choice for travelers. It offers a welcome bonus of 50,000 Membership Rewards (MR) points after spending $4,000 in your first 3 months. While you can redeem MR points for a number of different purchases, my go-to use is airfare.I've booked a round-trip economy flight to Europe for just under $1,500 this way. I like this card because it's not tied to a single airline, as many co-branded travel credit cards are. You also get up to $200 in airline fee credits per calendar year (enrollment required), which can be applied to baggage fees, in-flight food and beverages, in-flight entertainment and more.Another key benefit of the card is the annual $200 airline fee credit. You need to enroll in the program for it to be applied, but it can cover things like checked baggage, seat selection, in-flight beverages and more.For those who'd rather spend their rewards on things other than airfare, Amex offers a handful of statement credits for things like Uber rides, TSA PreCheck and more.There is a $550 annual fee, but the value you get can make that well worth it, especially considering how much money this card can save you when it comes to air travel.Chase Sapphire Reserve (Rates & Fees) is also among the best travel credit cards available to most U.S. consumers, with its 50,000-point bonus for spending $4,000 in your first 3 months. The card is similar to the Platinum in that you can use your points to cover the cost of airfare.It also offers complimentary travel and emergency assistance services, trip cancellation and interruption insurance, and a host of statement credits that can save you money. This includes a $300 annual credit that can be used to offset the cost of travel purchases, such as hotels, airfare, trains and more. You'll also get a $100 credit each year that can be applied toward your TSA PreCheck or Global Entry membership.As far as fees go, this card also has a $550 annual fee. But the benefits you receive from these statement credits more than justify it. And if you're a frequent traveler, you can probably even earn enough from these credits to completely offset the fee.If you're willing to put in some work, the Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card (Rates & Fees) is a great option. It offers a welcome bonus of 50,000 miles after spending $3,000 in your first 3 months. Capital One Miles are worth 1 cent apiece toward travel purchases, so that's $500 in travel savings right out of the gate.The card also offers an annual bonus of 10,000 miles (worth $100) after spending $20,000 in the previous calendar year, and 50,000 miles (worth $500) after spending $100,000. That's 150,000 miles (worth $1,500) in rewards you can redeem for free travel.One of the best features of this card is that you can redeem your miles toward the cost of any travel purchase. So you can put your points toward an airline ticket or hotel room or even a rental car. The only limitation is that you can't redeem miles toward the cost of travel purchased directly from the travel supplier (such as Amtrak).As far as fees go, this card has no foreign transaction fees, no annual fees and no penalty APR.The Capital One® VentureOne® Rewards Credit Card is a solid option for those who don't want to pay a large annual fee, but still want to earn rewards. It offers a $100 statement credit each year for the Global Entry or TSA PreCheck fee. There is no annual fee, and Capital One has some of the best security and identity protection in the business, which can be a big deal if you're planning to travel.If you're in the market for a card with a low annual fee, Citi® Double Cash Card – 18 month BT offer is a strong option. It offers 1% cash back on all purchases and an additional 1% cash back when you pay your purchases off. This is effectively a 2% cash back card, which is pretty great for a card that only charges $0 in annual fees.In addition, this card is an excellent option for those who want to earn rewards without any hassle. You don't need to choose the rewards you want to earn or spend your rewards in a specific way.Chase Sapphire Preferred Card (Rates & Fees) is an excellent card for those who want a travel rewards card without the annual fee. It offers a welcome bonus of 60,000 points after spending $4,000 in your first 3 months.This card offers 2x points for travel and dining purchases, and 1x points on everything else. That means you can earn up to 6x points on travel purchases when you book your travel through Chase Ultimate Rewards.The best feature of this card is its flexible point transfer partners. You can use your points to cover the cost of travel purchases at a 1:1 ratio.The Bank of America® Travel Rewards credit card (Rates & Fees) is another excellent travel rewards card that comes with a low annual fee. It offers a welcome bonus of 20,000 points after spending $1,000 in the first 90 days of opening the account.This card offers 1.5 points for every $1 spent on travel and dining purchases, and 1 point for every $1 spent on all other purchases. That's a lot of value for a card that only charges a $0 annual fee.The only downside is that you need to redeem your points for travel purchases, which is a little more limited than other cards. However, there are still plenty of travel purchases you can make with this card.Which credit card do you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility?I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. This is a tough call, as there are a lot of factors to consider.Some people might prefer the American Express Platinum Card (Rates & Fees) because of its welcome bonus and up to $200 in airline fee credits per calendar year. Others might prefer the Chase Sapphire Reserve (Rates & Fees) because of its 50,000-point bonus and $300 in annual travel credits.The best credit card for you depends on your personal situation and travel habits. If you're a frequent traveler who uses the same airline often, the Chase Sapphire Reserve (Rates & Fees) is probably the best choice. But if you prefer to use different airlines, or are not a frequent traveler, the American Express Platinum Card (Rates & Fees) is a good choice.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.The Best Credit Card For YouThere's a myriad of credit card benefits available these days, and it can be difficult to choose which one to go with. The benefits range from cash back rewards programs to rewards for traveling, to low-interest rates.However, we've compiled a list of our favorites, based on these features, to help make your decision easier.A cash back rewards program is exactly what it sounds like. You earn a percentage of your spending on the card in cash, which can be used to offset purchases made or paid off as cash.The rewards vary from card to card, but generally range from 1% to 5% cash back.There are also some cards that offer rewards for travel, such as the Chase Sapphire Reserve card, which provides 3 points per $1 spent on travel and dining purchases.This is a popular type of rewards program for those who want to earn points to use for free travel. Some cards even have a tiered program that allows you to earn points at different levels of spending.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card is a good example of a travel rewards card, which offers 2x points on travel and dining.Low-interest ratesSome credit cards offer low-interest rates for a limited period of time. This is beneficial for people who carry a balance on their card each month.Low-interest rates are typically offered on balance transfer cards, such as the Citi Simplicity card. This card offers a 0% introductory APR for 18 months on balance transfers.Some cards also offer low-interest rates on purchases. The Chase Freedom card, for example, offers 0% intro APR on purchases for 15 months.Other cards, such as the Amex EveryDay card, offer 0% intro APR on purchases for 15 months from account opening.Some cards also offer low-interest rates on cash advances, such as the Discover it cash back card, which offers a 0% intro APR on cash advances for 14 months.A rewards card is a type of credit card that rewards cardholders for their purchases. The rewards vary from card to card, but generally range from 1% to 5% cash back.Some credit cards also offer low-interest rates for a limited period of time. This is beneficial for people who carry a balance on their card each month.The best credit card is the one that fits your needs. For example, if you are a frequent traveler, then a travel rewards card may be the best choice for you.If you prefer a low-interest rate card, then look for one that offers a 0% introductory APR.If you want cash back rewards, then consider a cash back rewards card. And if you are a student, look for a student credit card.Whichever card you choose, be sure to compare the features and benefits of each card to find the one that is right for you.There are a variety of credit cards available that offer a variety of benefits and perks.Some cards offer low-interest rates, while others offer cash back rewards or travel perks.Choosing the best credit card for you depends on your individual needs and spending habits.If you're looking for a card with low interest, consider the Chase Slate card. This card offers 0% intro APR for 18 months on purchases and balance transfers, as well as no annual fee.For a card with cash back rewards, consider the American Express Blue Cash Preferred card. This card offers 6% cash back on up to $6,000 in spending each year at U.S. supermarkets (then 1%), 3% cash back on gas purchases, and 2% cash back on other purchases.And for a card with travel perks, consider the Chase Sapphire Preferred card. This card offers 2x points on travel and dining, as well as a $95 annual fee that is waived the first year.Whichever card you choose, be sure to compare the features and benefits of each card to find the one that is right for you.Credit cards are a great way to manage your finances, but it's important to be aware of the different types of credit cards and how they can benefit you.There are three main types of credit cards:- Rewards credit cards- Cash back credit cards- Balance transfer credit cardsEach type of card has its own benefits, so it's important to choose the right card for your needs.Rewards credit cards offer points, miles, or cash back for spending. These points can be used to redeem for statement credits, gift cards, or travel.Cash back credit cards offer a percentage of your spending back as cash, typically 1-2%.Balance transfer credit cards allow you to transfer a balance from another card with a low or no-interest rate. This can help you save money on interest and pay off your balance more quickly.Before you apply for a credit card, it's important to understand the terms and conditions. Make sure you know the interest rate, annual fee, and other costs associated with the card.You should also read the fine print to make sure you understand the rewards program and any restrictions that apply.If you're ready to apply for a credit card, be sure to do your research and choose the right card for your needs.A cash back rewards credit card is a type of credit card that gives you a percentage of your spending back in the form of cash, usually as a statement credit or as cash back.Some cash back rewards credit cards also offer additional rewards, such as points that can be redeemed for travel or gift cards.The amount of cash back you earn will vary depending on the card you have, but you can usually expect to earn between 1% and 5% back on your spending.To get the most out of your cash back rewards credit card, be sure to use it for everyday purchases, such as groceries, gas, and dining out.You can also use it to pay for travel, but be sure to check the terms and conditions of your card to make sure you won't be charged a foreign transaction fee.You can redeem your cash back rewards for a statement credit, a check, or a gift card. You can also choose to have your rewards deposited directly into your bank account.The best rewards credit cards are those that offer a high percentage of cash back on everyday spending, as well as additional rewards for travel and dining out.Some of the best cash back rewards credit cards include the Capital One Savor Cash Rewards Credit Card, which offers 4% cash back on dining and entertainment, and the Discover it® Miles Cashback Credit Card, which offers 5% cash back on quarterly rotating categories and 1% cash back on all other purchases.If you're looking for a card with low interest rates, the Amex EveryDay® Credit Card offers a 0% introductory APR for the first 15 months from account opening on purchases and balance transfers made within 4 months of account opening.You can also earn 2x points on up to $6,000 in spending per year at U.S. supermarkets (then 1x).If you're looking for a travel credit card, the Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card offers 2x points on travel and dining, and also has no foreign transaction fees.And if you're looking for a cash back credit card with no annual fee, the Chase Freedom Unlimited® Card is a good option, as it offers 1.5% cash back on all purchases, as well as a $200 sign-up bonus.Choosing the best credit card for you depends on your spending habits and needs.If you're looking for a card with low interest rates, consider the Amex EveryDay® Credit Card.If you're looking for a card with rewards, consider the Capital One® Savor® Cash Rewards Credit Card or the Discover it® Miles Cashback Credit Card.And if you're looking for a card with no annual fee, the Chase Freedom Unlimited® Card is a good option.Choosing the best rewards card for you depends on your spending habits and needs.Some cards offer cash back, while others offer points or miles. The best rewards card for you depends on how you plan to use your rewards.If you're looking for a card that offers the most cash back, consider the Capital One Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card. This card offers unlimited 1.5% cash back on all purchases, as well as a $200 sign-up bonus.If you're looking for a card that offers the most points or miles, consider the Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card. This card offers 2x points on travel and dining, as well as a $600 annual travel credit.There are many different credit cards available on the market, and it can be difficult to know which one is best for you.Some people prefer to use a credit card that offers low interest rates, while others prefer one with no annual fee.Still, others may be looking for a credit card that offers cash back rewards.Ultimately, the best credit card for you will depend on your individual needs and financial situation.However, by understanding the different types of credit cards available, you can make an informed decision about which one is right for you.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What's your favorite credit card?While some of you may love your credit cards for their generous rewards program, others may simply appreciate the fact that they get a low interest rate.Regardless of your preference, though, it's easy to see why these benefits are important to many of us. For example, did you know that the average American has $25,000 in credit card debt?As we continue to pay off our debt, it can be difficult to keep up with due dates, minimum payments, and other monthly bills. Luckily, a strong credit card will provide you with the flexibility to easily manage your financial obligations and help you get back on track.To help you find a credit card that meets your needs, I've put together a list of some of the best options currently available. I hope you find this helpful, and I would love to hear which credit card you believe to be the best.1. Citi® Double Cash Card – 18 month 0% APR: You'll get a $0 annual fee and up to 18 months of 0% introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers (with a 3% intro balance transfer fee). Plus, the Citi Double Cash Card offers 2% cash back on purchases, so you can earn cash back on both your purchases and balance transfers.2. Bank of America® Cash Rewards Credit Card: The Bank of America® Cash Rewards Credit Card offers a $0 annual fee and 1.5% cash back on all purchases (with no limit on the amount you can earn). Plus, you'll get 25% more cash back on purchases in your top eligible spending category each billing cycle.3. Citi® Diamond Preferred® Card – 21 month 0% APR: If you're looking for a credit card with a generous rewards program, the Citi Diamond Preferred Card is an excellent choice. With this card, you'll get 21 months of 0% introductory APR on both purchases and balance transfers, so you'll have plenty of time to pay off your balance. Plus, you'll earn 5% cash back on up to $1,500 in purchases in your top eligible spending category each billing cycle.4. Bank of America® Travel Rewards Visa® Credit Card: This credit card is a great choice if you want a card with a rewards program. The Bank of America® Travel Rewards Visa® Card offers a $0 annual fee and up to 25% more cash back on purchases in your top eligible spending category each billing cycle. Plus, you'll earn 1.5% cash back on all purchases.5. U.S. Bank Visa® Platinum Card: The U.S. Bank Visa® Platinum Card is a good choice if you're looking for a card with a low interest rate. With this card, you'll get a $0 annual fee and up to 15 months of 0% introductory APR on both purchases and balance transfers. Plus, you'll get a 0.90% rate after the intro APR expires.6. With this card, you'll get 1.5 miles per dollar spent on all purchases (up to $30,000 spent in the first 12 months), plus you'll get 2 miles per dollar spent at gas stations and restaurants. Plus, you'll get 0% intro APR for 14 months on both purchases and balance transfers (with a 3% intro balance transfer fee).7. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.While my personal preference would be a cash back credit card, I am definitely not a "traveler". So I can understand why some people don't care about perks or low interest rates. What do you think?I use my Capital One Spark card for almost all purchases. I don't know how many of the card features I use, but it does have great perks and cash back. I love that you can spend all the cash back on anything.@Stephanie - You're right! I just looked at the fine print and found that Capital One Spark is a "select cash back" card. So if you don't like to travel and don't spend much on entertainment, you could probably get a lot more back from the Spark card than the AmEx Platinum, right?We have two Chase Ink cards that work great for us. We use the Ink Business Cash for 2% cash back on everything, and use the Ink Business Preferred for 3x points on everything but travel.It really depends on how you spend money. If you use travel a lot, then you should get a Chase Sapphire Reserve. If you don't, then maybe get the Amex Platinum or something like that.@Liam - I don't travel much, so that probably means I shouldn't get the AmEx Platinum. I don't think I'm really traveling enough to be able to justify it. But I guess I could always change that. Thanks!I'm all about the low interest rates. I like the Chase Freedom Unlimited the best because the interest rate is 0% for 15 months, and then after that, it's just 16.99%. So I get to pay less in interest if I pay on time.@Bill - That sounds like a great card to me! I like the sound of that 0% interest rate. Hopefully you're not carrying a balance from month to month. That would defeat the whole purpose, right?I have to admit I've never heard of a Capital One Spark card. I'll have to do some more research on that one. My AmEx Platinum card has served me well, I have to admit. It has a lot of great perks and it's good to have that 5% cash back on travel and entertainment.@Jennifer - I'm not sure how well the Spark card will serve you, if you don't travel much or have expensive entertainment. But I do like the idea of the 5% cash back! I'm pretty sure my card doesn't do that.I'm on the fence. I like the cash back option, but I'd be willing to miss out on that if I could get a low interest rate. So I guess it depends on how I do financially. Do I pay my cards off every month or do I carry a balance?I've been using a Discover card for years. They have pretty good perks and I like that I can cash out 100% of my cash back.I don't think I'd change my card now, even though I don't know much about what's out there. If I were going to, I would definitely want to see what perks and cash back I could get with the Capital One Spark, though.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. There's no shortage of options to choose from, and you may have several top picks. Here's where it gets tricky, though: Most of us don't use the same credit card for every single transaction. There are certain times we'll use our rewards credit cards to get a little bit of extra cash back, while other times we'll prefer a card with a lower interest rate to keep our debt under control.In other words, we're not looking for a "one-size-fits-all" credit card. We're looking for an "optimal combination" of financial perks.That's where credit cards with multiple rates come into play. These credit cards give you the freedom to choose which type of rate you want to apply to your purchases, and that can be a very useful option if you're carrying a lot of debt.Let's say you have an outstanding balance of $10,000 on a credit card with a 24% annual percentage rate. That means the interest alone will cost you $2,400 over the course of the year. If you're using your credit card exclusively for big-ticket purchases, it may make sense to opt for a card that charges a low APR for balance transfers, and a high APR for regular spending. That way, you can avoid paying high interest on your daily expenses, while still getting access to the benefits of a lower APR for your outstanding balance.It's important to note, though, that the best cards for everyday use won't necessarily be the best cards for balance transfers. If you're interested in moving your debt to a lower interest rate, you'll have to find the best balance transfer credit card for your needs. That said, if you don't want to use your credit card very often, you may be better off with a card that doesn't have an annual fee or an introductory period.If you're interested in exploring these options, be sure to check out our list of the best balance transfer credit cards, and our list of the best credit cards for everyday use.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.My current favorite is the United MileagePlus Explorer card, which has no annual fee and offers the opportunity to earn double miles on your first $6,000 spent. It is a Chase product, which means the ability to apply for the card and redeem the miles is a matter of convenience.The most rewarding card is the Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express. The annual fee is $75 and you get a $100 statement credit each year for making one purchase at select department stores. In addition, if you have two or more people with a Blue Cash Preferred Card (and they aren't married to one another) and they both make one purchase a year at a qualifying department store, you get an additional $100 statement credit each year.I have been using the United Explorer Card and the Citi ThankYou Preferred card for a long time, and the Citi is far better, although the United offers good bonus miles, and the Citi has a good balance transfer offer.I have been using the American Express Blue Cash Preferred Card for years, and it's a good card, but I just recently changed to the Chase Freedom Unlimited Card for no annual fee, so it's great to have for people who don't spend a lot of money each year. I have two Freedom Unlimited cards, because they're for my wife and myself, but they are good cards for people who want a low-cost card that doesn't have an annual fee.The best one I have is the Citi® Double Cash Card - 18 month BT offer (18 months) because I really like Citi and their rewards are unmatched, even if you do have to redeem them in the end.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I believe that the Capital One Spark Miles card for Business is an excellent choice for companies with at least good credit.Why do I like this card so much?Earn 2 Miles per $1 spent on every purchase.There's no annual fee.You get a 20,000 mile signup bonus after spending $5,000 within 3 months.Miles are worth $0.01 each.You can earn up to $50 in statement credits annually for Capital One Entertainment.Your annual fee is waived for the first year.If you've maintained a great credit score, you'll be able to get this card. But how about a credit score of less than 650?You'll still have some success getting this card, but you may have to pay an annual fee.You can't get the 20,000 mile signup bonus with a credit score below 650. But you can earn the regular bonus (10,000 miles for spending $5,000 within 3 months).Miles are worth $0.01 each, so you can expect to earn around $1,000 of value on the $5,000 you spend.I find this card an excellent deal. But let me know your thoughts.In my next article, I'll talk about some of the more interesting credit cards that are currently available.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I know a few people have strong opinions on the subject. I've heard about people who say that you shouldn't use credit cards at all, while others swear by them.I've been using credit cards for 20+ years and have found them to be a very useful tool. I use them all the time, as a result, and I don't really think of them as a source of debt. They just allow me to spend more money than I have on hand at any given moment.I find the idea that you can't get a credit card without a high credit score to be a ridiculous one. If that were the case, most people wouldn't be able to purchase cars, homes, and even some appliances and electronics.The other day, I went shopping at a local department store. I was approached by a credit card sales person. "Hey," she said. "I'd like to give you some credit. Is that OK with you?" I've always hated that question because the answer is usually a "no." And the people who ask are usually trying to get you to spend money on something you'll regret.I don't know if you've noticed, but the last few years have been a bit of a bumpy ride for credit card issuers. They're the kind of things that make you feel like you're a fool if you get them, but there are some things that are just not worth the trouble. If you find yourself in this category, you might want to rethink your relationship with credit cards. Here are the top five reasons you should avoid using them.1. It's Easy to Get ThemIt's hard to imagine why you'd ever want to have a credit card if you don't have any. They're the perfect excuse for people who want to be able to charge everything they need to buy and pay it off without paying interest or late fees.When you get a credit card, you're essentially giving yourself a loan. You get to charge up whatever you need to purchase, and then you pay off that debt when you get your next paycheck. It's like a loan, but without any consequences if you don't pay it back.That's why so many people use credit cards. It's like a loan, but without any consequences if you don't pay it back. That's why so many people use credit cards. They're the perfect excuse for people who want to be able to charge everything they need to buy and pay it off without paying interest or late fees.2. It's Easy to Pay It OffThe problem is that credit cards are designed to be paid off with a credit card. That's why so many people use credit cards. They're the perfect excuse for people who want to be able to charge everything they need to buy and pay it off without paying interest or late fees.But, what if you don't want to use a credit card? What if you don't want to pay interest on your purchases? What if you don't want to use a credit card at all?That's why it's a good idea to find an alternative payment method. You can pay off your credit card with cash, with a debit card, with a check, or with a direct deposit.In the end, the main benefit of using a credit card is that you don't have to pay interest on your purchases. You don't have to worry about paying interest or late fees. You don't have to worry about paying off your credit card debt. All you have to do is pay off your credit card balance with cash, with a debit card, with a check, or with a direct deposit.That's why it's a good idea to find an alternative payment method. You don't have to worry about paying off your credit card debt. All you have to do is pay off your credit card balance with cash, with a debit card, with a check, or with a direct deposit.3. You Get Free RewardsAs a general rule, credit cards tend to give out free rewards in exchange for being used in certain ways. These rewards can be as simple as cash back, free merchandise, or even free airline tickets. If you use your credit card to pay for things, you'll get free rewards for using it.But if you use your credit card to pay for things, you'll get free rewards for using it. If you use your credit card to pay for things, you'll get free rewards for using it. If you use your credit card to pay for things, you'll get free rewards for using it.There are plenty of ways to get free rewards, but the most common way is through a rewards program. These programs are often affiliated with a particular bank or credit card issuer.In addition to free rewards, some credit cards offer exclusive benefits that can make your purchases more affordable.The most common rewards program is the credit card's cash back program. These programs often offer cash back on certain purchases, which can be redeemed at certain merchants.In addition to free rewards, some credit cards offer exclusive benefits that can make your purchases more affordable. The most common rewards program is the credit card's cash back program. These programs often offer cash back on certain purchases, which can be redeemed at certain merchants.4. It's Easy to CancelCredit card issuers are required by law to provide you with a 30-day free trial period, which means that you can try out the credit card and cancel it within 30 days if you're not satisfied.You're not the only one who likes to try out new things. That's why so many people use credit cards. You can try out new things and cancel them if you don't like them.If you're not satisfied with the credit card you're currently using, you can cancel it any time. Just let the credit card company know that you don't want to use the credit card anymore. They'll remove it from your account and send you a new card.5. It's Easy to Pay Your BillsThere are plenty of reasons to use credit cards, and one of the most important is that they're easy to use. You don't have to carry a wallet around, which is great for people who don't like to carry around a lot of cash.And, if you don't have a lot of money to spend, you can use your credit card to pay your bills and other purchases. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I use the Capital One Platinum card for everyday expenses. I've also got the USAA Cash Rewards Visa (which was rebranded as the USAA Preferred Cash Rewards Visa), but it is no longer in my wallet (more on that later).Since the Capital One Platinum card has no annual fee, it is good for everyday purchases and other items that don't need an introductory 0% rate or bonus cash back.Capital One's Platinum Card has no annual fee and a solid intro APR, which makes it ideal for emergency cash needs.Why I prefer it to the Capital One Quicksilver: I don't use my credit card for everyday purchases and other types of purchases that don't qualify for the Capital One Quicksilver's bonus cash back. Instead, I prefer to use my Capital One Platinum card for those transactions and keep the Quicksilver for large purchases that I need the 0% APR for. The Capital One Quicksilver's interest rate is also a bit higher.Why I prefer it to the Capital One Spark Cash: I don't get as much in cash back from using the Spark Cash for everyday purchases and other types of purchases that don't qualify for the Capital One Quicksilver's bonus cash back.USAA Preferred Cash Rewards Visa (now known as the USAA Preferred Cash Rewards Visa): I used this card exclusively for years, but stopped using it a few years ago because I found that I couldn't take advantage of some of its benefits.Why I no longer use it: I could not use the card's 0% intro APR on balance transfers (it expired after a couple of months), and its annual fee (which is waived for the first year) made it difficult to redeem the bonus points it awards for ongoing spending.Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit Card: This is a 0% intro APR credit card that lets you earn cash back on all of your purchases, no matter what you spend.Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit Card vs. Capital One Platinum: I do not prefer the Quicksilver card over the Platinum because the cash back rate is lower on all types of purchases (excluding supermarket purchases). I also don't need the 0% APR feature since I don't use my credit card for everyday expenses and other types of purchases that don't qualify for the Capital One Quicksilver's bonus cash back.Capital One Spark Cash: This card allows you to earn 1.5% cash back on all of your purchases. It also has a 0% intro APR for a limited time.Chase Freedom Unlimited: This card offers 1.5% cash back on all of your purchases, and has a 0% intro APR for a limited time.Discover it: This card offers 5% cash back on up to $1,500 in purchases in your first quarter. It also has a 0% intro APR for a limited time.What do you prefer to use for your everyday purchases and other types of purchases that don't qualify for the Capital One Quicksilver's bonus cash back?What do you think of the Chase Freedom Unlimited's 0% intro APR offer? Do you find it to be useful?What is your favorite credit card for everyday expenses and other types of purchases that don't qualify for the Capital One Quicksilver's bonus cash back?Thanks for sharing, I think I will try out that Cash card as well as the Chase Freedom Unlimited.Hi! I just saw this article! What is your opinion of the USAA cash reward Visa? Is it worth it for the low annual fee and low interest rate?I used to use it exclusively, but I recently started using it less and less. I would say that it's definitely worth it, especially if you are a USAA member.What would you say is the best 1.5% back card?I don't know of any other cards like the Capital One Spark Cash that currently offer 1.5% cash back on all of your purchases.What's the benefit of the spark cash card vs. quicksilver card? Is it better for cash back?It depends on what you plan to use the card for. If you use it primarily for cash back, then I would recommend the Spark Cash card over the Quicksilver card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm wondering because I recently received a letter from Citibank about an offer to upgrade my credit card to a new one. This is an offer from one of Citi's many cashback rewards credit cards.I read the fine print and determined that the new credit card offered 5% cashback rewards at gas stations and on airline purchases. It also offered 3% cashback rewards on purchases at supermarkets, department stores, drugstores and dining.So, how can this new offer possibly be better than my existing Citi cashback rewards credit card?The new Citi card has a lower annual percentage rate (APR) on purchases and balance transfers. That's true. But that's a pretty minor benefit for me, because I don't carry a balance on my Citi credit card and I almost never make a balance transfer.The new card also has more benefits, but I haven't looked into those yet. I don't know if they're any better than the benefits already available to me.Here's what I want to know: Is there another credit card out there that offers better benefits, better rates, and better flexibility?I don't know about you, but I've been thinking about getting another credit card anyway. That's partly because I could use the cashback rewards, and partly because a credit card is part of my overall financial strategy.I'd appreciate hearing about your experiences with credit cards and your ideas about which are the best credit cards for my personal situation. You can write me at brian@thefiscaltimes.com.Five Reasons to Get a Credit Card</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The last time we looked at this data was in 2012, and at that time, Capital One's card was in the lead with an impressive 12.5% overall satisfaction rating.Today, however, I've decided to take a look at the 2015 data to see if the Capital One card has continued to hold onto the top spot.Which credit card offers the best overall satisfaction?Which credit card offers the best combination of perks and benefits?Which credit card offers the best combination of low interest rates and low fees?In order to come to these conclusions, I've been collecting data on these credit cards every two years since 2007. I'm also tracking the annual interest rates, annual fees, and benefits that come with each card.To give you some background information, the first chart shows the percentage of surveyed cardholders who gave their credit cards an overall "very satisfied" rating.To put it simply, more cardholders are satisfied with their Capital One credit cards than any other credit card on the market.With a total satisfaction rating of 12.5%, Capital One's card is well ahead of the competition and has been the top-rated credit card for the last four years in a row.However, we haven't stopped there.Not only are Capital One credit cards ranked as the best in terms of overall satisfaction, they're also the best in terms of the benefits they offer.The next two charts highlight which credit cards offer the best benefits and which ones offer the best perks.Overall, Capital One credit cards are ranked the best in terms of the benefits they offer, followed closely by American Express.However, Capital One's card is ranked as the second-best in terms of the perks they offer. That said, there's really not much difference between the two, so either one of these cards could be considered a strong choice.When it comes to low interest rates and low fees, Capital One and Discover tied for the top spot with a satisfaction rating of 13%.That said, Capital One cardholders are a little more satisfied than Discover cardholders, and we don't have enough data to know why.What do you think? Do you agree that Capital One's card offers the best combination of low interest rates and low fees?As you can see, Capital One's card continues to be the number-one choice for people who want a high-quality credit card.The company has been doing a lot to ensure that their cardholders are satisfied, and they've managed to build the best credit card out there today.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I've narrowed the field to eight of the best options. If you've ever wished that a credit card could be your personal banking assistant, then perhaps one of these will be the one for you.Best for Business Travelers: Capital One Spark MilesBest for Cash Back: BankAmericard Cash Rewards Credit CardBest for Rewards: Chase Sapphire PreferredBest for Credit-Building: Wells Fargo Cash Wise Visa CardBest for Low-Interest: U.S. Bank Visa Platinum CardBest for Balance Transfers: Wells Fargo Platinum Visa CardBest for No Foreign Transaction Fees: Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit CardBest for New Credit: Discover It® Secured Credit CardIf you're looking for a card that allows you to rack up as many travel rewards as possible, then I'd recommend the Capital One Spark Miles Card. With this card, you'll be able to earn 2 miles for every dollar spent. Additionally, it offers travel protections, like insurance against trip cancellations, trip delays, lost luggage, and even stolen passports. If that isn't enough, you'll also have the opportunity to earn an unlimited 5 percent back on purchases at restaurants and on travel.The annual fee is $95, which is somewhat high, but is made up for in the fact that the Spark Miles card also boasts a sign-up bonus of 50,000 miles. Capital One has recently introduced a new Spark Miles card that offers no foreign transaction fees, which can be an issue if you do a lot of traveling internationally.The BankAmericard Cash Rewards Credit Card is best suited for people who prefer cash back over points or miles. You'll earn 1.5 percent cash back on every purchase you make. You can redeem your cash back in the form of a statement credit to offset your next purchase. There's also a sign-up bonus of $200.The card comes with travel protections, like insurance against trip cancellations, trip delays, lost luggage, and even stolen passports. It does have an annual fee of $0.I'm a big fan of the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. With this card, you'll be able to earn 2 points for every dollar spent on travel and dining, and you'll also get an unlimited 1 point per dollar spent on all other purchases. There's a sign-up bonus of 50,000 bonus points.In addition to the rewards, the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers travel protections, like insurance against trip cancellations, trip delays, lost luggage, and even stolen passports. You can also get 25 percent more value on travel booked through the Chase Ultimate Rewards portal.The card has a $95 annual fee, but you can waive it for the first year of card membership.I like to think of the Wells Fargo Cash Wise Visa Card as the gold standard of credit cards. There's a sign-up bonus of $200. This credit card offers a low annual fee of $0 and no foreign transaction fees.The card provides many travel protections, like insurance against trip cancellations, trip delays, lost luggage, and even stolen passports. It also allows you to earn 1.8 percent cash back on every purchase you make, without any annual caps.The U.S. Bank Visa Platinum Card has a sign-up bonus of $150. This credit card is ideal for people who want a low-interest rate card. You'll be able to get an introductory APR of 0 percent on both purchases and balance transfers for up to 20 billing cycles. You'll be charged a 3 percent balance transfer fee on the amount transferred. After the introductory period, the APR will be 14.99 percent to 23.99 percent.This card also offers a great rewards program. You'll be able to earn 1.5 percent cash back on every purchase you make, which is a decent return. Additionally, there are no annual or foreign transaction fees.The Wells Fargo Platinum Visa Card is ideal for people who are looking to consolidate their debt, thanks to its low APR and low interest rates. With the card, you'll be able to earn 1.8 percent cash back on every purchase you make. There's a sign-up bonus of $150. The annual fee is $0, which is also pretty nice.You can consolidate balances of up to $10,000 without paying a balance transfer fee for the first 120 days. After that, you'll be charged a fee of 3 percent on the amount transferred.The Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit Card is one of the best no foreign transaction fee credit cards out there. You can earn an unlimited 1.5 percent cash back on all your purchases. This is an excellent rate of return on your spending. Additionally, there's a sign-up bonus of $150.The annual fee is $0. There are also no fees for foreign purchases or balance transfers.The Discover It® Secured Credit Card is a great card for people who are just starting to build their credit, or who have damaged their credit in the past. The card has no annual fee, so you don't have to worry about spending money on it.You can rebuild your credit score with this card, and earn an unlimited 2 percent cash back on all purchases. Additionally, there's a sign-up bonus of $50.Best for Business Travelers: Capital One Spark Miles CardBest for Rewards: Chase Sapphire Preferred CardBest for Credit-Building: Wells Fargo Cash Wise Visa CardBest for No Foreign Transaction Fees: Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit CardBest for New Credit: Discover It® Secured Credit Card</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. How do you determine which card is worth spending on in the long run?Credit card benefits can make all the difference in the world when it comes to helping you save money. Many credit cards offer a variety of benefits, such as travel miles, cash back, and discounts on purchases. In addition, some cards have special features that can help you build up your credit score.However, not all credit cards are created equal. Some cards have high interest rates and low credit limits, while others have low interest rates and high credit limits.So, which credit card offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility? The answer depends on a number of factors, such as your spending habits and the amount of debt you currently have.In general, however, the best credit cards offer a combination of low interest rates and generous perks. These cards are ideal for people who are looking to save money on interest and don't want to spend too much on perks.Another great option is the Discover It card, which offers rewards of up to 5% cash back on purchases. The card also offers an introductory APR of 0% for the first six months and no annual fees.If you're looking for a credit card that offers both low interest rates and a generous rewards program, then the Chase Sapphire Preferred is worth considering. The card offers a low interest rate of 0% for the first 15 months and a rewards program that offers up to 5% cash back on purchases.There are a few key things to consider when determining which credit card is the best fit for you. First and foremost, you should take into account your credit history and current financial situation. A good credit card provider will have a variety of options that fit your needs, so it's important to find one that works with your individual situation. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. This is the second time I have written on the subject, and my opinion is constantly evolving as I look for new opportunities to maximize my cash-flow and earn points toward travel.In this post, I want to share my most recent credit card experiences. I'm not endorsing any particular credit card, and I hope my comments are helpful to those who are just getting started on the credit card road.If you're already an experienced credit card user and you already have a few credit cards under your belt, then you might consider my comments to be overkill. You already have an existing credit card profile, and you already know what to look for.But if you're new to this, then perhaps this post will help you in making your first big decision.The first thing to consider when you're looking at credit cards is the annual fee.Ideally, you would want to find a card that does not charge any annual fees. You should be especially leery of credit cards that charge an annual fee for the first year, since you're getting robbed of a free year.Of course, credit cards with annual fees tend to offer more valuable benefits, so your decision to pay an annual fee will be a judgment call. For example, my Chase Sapphire Preferred card is $95 per year. It's worth it to me because the annual fee is offset by the generous rewards that I receive for travel-related purchases.Annual fees range anywhere from $0 to $550.The next thing to consider is the interest rate.Ideally, you want to find a credit card with a low-interest rate, or better yet, no interest. Interest rates will often change in tandem with the prime rate, which as of this writing is 3.25%. But this can change at any time, and if you are carrying a large balance, it could be an issue.Your credit score will determine the interest rate you're offered. If you have a good credit score, then you will qualify for a low interest rate. If you have a bad credit score, then you will qualify for a higher interest rate.Interest rates range from 0% to 24%.The next thing to consider is the rewards program.Most rewards programs have a set of eligible purchases, and for each eligible purchase that you make, you earn points that you can redeem for free travel.It's important to remember that credit card companies will not always give you your full points for every dollar that you spend. For example, the Chase Sapphire Preferred card will give you 2 points per dollar spent at grocery stores and restaurants, but it will only give you 1 point per dollar spent on gas stations and home improvement stores.Rewards programs also have a cap on how many points you can earn for each dollar spent, so you have to be careful about how you spend your money. The best rewards program is the one that allows you to maximize your earning potential without sacrificing other benefits.Rewards programs can be confusing to sort through, so I suggest you go to a website like Award Wallet to see how much you could save with the Chase Sapphire Preferred card.
