<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.While I appreciate the many benefits that a Chase Sapphire Preferred Card or an American Express Platinum card can offer, I feel like my Citi Prestige Credit Card gets me the most bang for my buck.Citi Prestige Credit CardSignup Bonus 50,000 miles + $250 statement credit after $4,000 in purchases within 3 months.Annual Fee $450 (waived first year)Points 3 points per dollar on travel and dining. 1 point per dollar on everything else.Introductory Interest Rate 0% APR for 15 months on balance transfers and purchasesI chose to focus on this card for several reasons. First and foremost, the Citi Prestige Card has the best signup bonus in the business. Not only do you get 50,000 airline miles after you spend $4,000 in purchases in the first 3 months, but you also get a $250 statement credit!Even if you're not a regular traveler, I find that this is an easy card to recoup the cost of. Simply apply the $250 statement credit to a $250 American Express Gift Card and you're essentially getting the card for free.If you have to pay a $450 annual fee, it's nice to know that you'll be able to recoup the fee in the first year alone. And even if you don't spend as much as I do, there's still a strong chance that you'll get the fee back.Citi Prestige has a great signup bonusIt also happens to be the only credit card in the U.S. that allows you to earn 5 points per dollar at restaurants, including both food and dining. This is a big benefit if you like to dine out for dinner or if you eat out while on the road for business.And if you spend $3,000 on travel each year, you can easily recoup the annual fee by earning the 3 points per dollar for travel.In addition to the bonus categories, Citi Prestige has some of the best benefits in the business. It's rare to see a travel card without any foreign transaction fees and this card is no different. And if you want to use your rewards for flights, it will automatically send the points to your preferred frequent flyer program.And finally, this card offers an extended warranty for 24 months and car rental insurance if you pay for the car with your Citi Prestige card.Citi Prestige offers a great signup bonus. If you have to pay an annual fee, it's nice to know that you can use it to offset the fee. And it's nice to have perks like the extended warranty and car rental insurance as a perk of using the card.What's your favorite credit card to use for travel?Related: Citi Prestige Credit Card Review: Worth it?11 Comments on "What Credit Card Should I Use for Travel?"Jessica | TheTravelingTurntable | July 9, 2015 at 10:14 am | ReplyI really like the Citi Prestige Card as well and agree that the signup bonus and fee waiver is a great combination! We also love the points earning categories and get pretty good use of those. Thanks for stopping by my blog this week!Jennifer | The Solitary Wanderer | July 9, 2015 at 10:27 am | ReplyAwesome, thanks for your comment! And congrats on your recent move.Never Heard of That | July 9, 2015 at 11:47 am | ReplyGreat post! I love using credit cards for the points and free travel. I used to use the Amex platinum and chase Sapphire cards for this but I was charged an annual fee for the sapphire card so I switched to a citi credit card (prestige) and I love it!Jennifer | The Solitary Wanderer | July 9, 2015 at 12:10 pm | ReplyThanks! I’m glad that you’ve been happy with your Citi Prestige Card! It’s a nice card and I’ve been happy with mine so far.Kathleen | Adventure to Somewhere | July 11, 2015 at 8:50 am | ReplyI’ve got the Chase Sapphire Preferred so I don’t really get any of the perks you mention. But I’ve never paid an annual fee. I’ve got 19 months of interest free on transfers, which I’ve only used once, but it was nice knowing it was there. The points are also worth so much more than when you use them for cashback (like $2500 to $3000 if I remember correctly) so I’ve always paid for travel expenses with them.I also agree about the Citi Prestige Card being a nice card for traveling and for foodies. They have a $350 statement credit if you apply by 8/21/15 so that might be worth checking out if you haven’t already.Hope you have a great time at Blogfest!Jennifer | The Solitary Wanderer | July 12, 2015 at 8:21 pm | ReplyThank you so much for your comment, Kathleen!That’s interesting that your Chase Sapphire Preferred doesn’t offer a fee waiver and I also appreciate that you’re getting the points for travel. The points are very easy to use and I’ve used them to book a few flights on the website.And thanks so much for letting me know about the $350 statement credit for the Citi Prestige. I’ll be signing up for it as soon as I get back from Blogfest. I have a feeling that I’ll be spending a lot on the card in the next 12 months!Kathleen | Adventure to Somewhere | July 14, 2015 at 1:42 pm |Glad to be of service! I’ve always been amazed at how flexible the points are. I’ve also heard of people who have done the math on their own and the Chase Sapphire Preferred is the best deal if you don’t travel very often and pay the fee.Jennifer | The Solitary Wanderer | July 15, 2015 at 7:19 am |I’m glad that you’ve found my posts helpful! Thanks so much for letting me know.Pingback: BlogFest 2015: What Makes You Tick? | The Solitary WandererRick | July 20, 2015 at 7:09 pm | ReplyThat Citi card sounds awesome.Rick | TheTravelingTurntableThe Citi Prestige Card has been great for me so far! Thanks for your comment.Pingback: BlogFest 2015: Meet Me at 6 a.m. | The Solitary WandererCaleb | November 13, 2015 at 8:32 pm | ReplyI’ve actually just received this card, and I’m very happy with the rewards.Pingback: Favorite Frequent Flyer Programs: American AAdvantagePingback: 6 Reasons to Sign Up for a Credit CardPingback: Chase Sapphire Preferred vs. Citi Prestige | The Solitary WandererPingback: Chase Sapphire Preferred vs. Citi Prestige</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I've seen a bunch of posts on here about credit cards, but it's a bit hard for me to decide which one to sign up for. I'm not really a huge spender (other than travel), so I'm not really sure if I need the benefits of one of the fancy-schmancy travel or cash-back cards. But at the same time, I know I'd be foolish not to sign up for a card with a low interest rate, especially since I'm planning to do lots of traveling.Any advice? Which one do you use?I have the Amex Gold card (not the premier one, which is supposed to be even better) and it's been great. It's a very low-interest card (12%) and has pretty good perks: two points per dollar spent, free rental car insurance, etc. They have a nice, simple rewards program. I don't like my cash back reward programs (I never use them and find them more confusing than the Amex one), and I haven't tried any of the travel rewards, but I'm pretty sure you could use points toward travel.I do have one complaint: the card is really hard to use for online transactions (no easy way to add it as a payment option to your PayPal account, for instance). But, I've had no problems whatsoever with Amex, so overall I'm very satisfied with the card.I've been an AMEX Platinum cardholder for years. It has been a good card for me. I get 5 points per dollar for travel (I don't travel a lot, so that's good), free rental car insurance, and 5 points per dollar for all non-travel related spending. AMEX has been very flexible about the points. I had to cancel a trip to Paris because of a family death, and they were great about giving me the points back. They also had a good point/mileage exchange program with United. I can't get in to the current one because the points have changed but it was a good program.My only complaint is the high interest rate (21.99%).I've recently decided to switch to a travel card. I think I'm going to get the Discover Miles card. It's similar to AmEx in that it's a points system that you can redeem for travel, but you can also redeem the points as cash. The sign-up bonus is $500 which is pretty cool.The biggest issue I've had with AMEX is the lack of an online account.Anyway, I think I'll go for the Chase Sapphire Preferred Rewards Visa card. It seems like it has a decent sign-up bonus and it offers a $50 statement credit for using Chase's Uber service.Oh, yeah...it's really expensive. They have one of the highest interest rates in the business.Sorry if this is a repeat...I've been trying to sign up for a new credit card for quite a while, and I finally decided to go with the Chase Sapphire Preferred card. It seems to have some decent perks (points for travel, cash-back on certain types of transactions, no foreign transaction fees), as well as a nice sign-up bonus and 0% interest for 12 months. The annual fee is $95, but it comes with an $80 credit, so it's only $15 for the first year. I just have to get through the application process without making any mistakes, and I should be all set.I'm still a little iffy about it, though, since I don't really spend a lot of money (I have a Chase debit card which gives me 5% cash-back on a lot of stuff). But at the same time, I figure I might as well get the benefits of a low-interest credit card with some extra perks.Anyone here use this card or have any advice for a newbie?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I've listed a few below, but please feel free to add more in the comments!As always, it's best to shop around before choosing your credit card.Chase Sapphire Preferred: 0% APR for 12 months and 2 points per $1 spent on travel and diningChase Ink: 0% APR for 12 months and up to 50,000 pointsUS Bank Platinum: 0% APR for 12 months and low interest rates (but no points or perks)I'm not much of a credit card guy, so feel free to correct me if I'm wrong. I'd also be interested to hear which credit cards you all are using, and why.I agree with the choices. We have been trying to make our first trip abroad for years. We want to travel and not pay $600 for hotel and flight for just a couple of days. I would love to hear about your trip to the Philippines. I've been there and love the people there and would love to return to see some other places. If you can, email me.Glad to hear you've had such a positive experience with the Sapphire Preferred Card! I recently opened the account and I've only had one or two charges so far, but everything looks good so far.Here's some of the perks that I'm looking forward to:1) No foreign transaction fees on international purchases. This alone is enough for me to not want to carry a debit card on vacation.2) I'll probably do some spending on Amazon and other online retailers, and it'll be nice to get the 2x points on those purchases.3) 0% interest for 12 months on all purchases.4) 15,000 bonus points if you charge $1000 in the first 3 months (and meet some other criteria).5) 50,000 bonus points if you apply with a travel buddy. This one probably won't apply for me, but I'll be sure to post here if it does :)6) Free two-day shipping on Amazon if you buy their $70 gift certificate. You get the card, they send you a code, you use the code, you get your stuff, and you get to keep the card. Win-win.7) Free credit score reports every month.Hope you have some good experiences with your travels. Feel free to email me at chris at gocurrycracker dot comI'm a big fan of the Ink Cash Business card. It's a little bit different than the Ink Plus in that it offers up to 50k bonus points ($500 worth) instead of the Ink Plus' $600.The Ink Cash card is a business card, but I like to think of myself as a business. I use my rewards for business expenses. The $500 in cash bonus points makes the Ink Cash card one of the top cash back cards for business owners. You could also use the card for personal expenses, in which case, the Plus would be better.The Ink Cash card offers an introductory 0% rate for 12 months. You'll have to meet the minimum monthly requirements for purchases and payments, but it's good to know you can go 12 months interest-free.The Ink Cash offers 5% cash back on purchases at office supply stores, cell phone/phone services, landline communications, and on internet, cable, and satellite services.Overall, this is a great card that offers big rewards to small business owners. You can sign up here: http://tinyurl.com/cashinkThe main reason I wanted to share this is because I think a lot of people are afraid of going into business for themselves, or are intimidated by it. But there are so many small business owners out there, including yourself. I know I'm not the only person who is starting his own business and doing his own thing. I think it's a great way to gain financial freedom.I think a lot of people just don't realize it's possible. The other thing is that people think you have to have a storefront or office, but that's not the case. You can do a lot of business online and never set foot in an office. The other thing that I've seen so many people do is quit their jobs and work on their business.I love the idea of someone who quits their job and works on their business, especially because they're working on their passion, which I think is so important. I also think it's important to focus on your passion instead of your job. There are so many people who are unhappy because they're not following their passions. They're not doing what they love. I think that's a really big reason why so many people are unhappy with their jobs.You can learn more about me and my business at http://www.currycracker.com. Thanks for reading and have a great day!</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What are your thoughts?This depends a lot on the credit profile. For someone with good credit (i.e. they have been a responsible borrower for some time) a card with no annual fee and a lower interest rate may make the most sense. There may be times where you need some flexibility on your monthly payment, or you want to be able to transfer a balance to a different card without any penalties. In these cases, a card with a low introductory rate may work best.For someone that doesn't have an excellent credit history (i.e. there are a few blemishes on their report) I would always recommend they start with a rewards card. It's not as important whether they have an introductory rate, as the real focus should be on the rewards. I have clients that only keep one card, and they use that card for everything. That way, they can maximize their rewards points and avoid being charged interest.Of course, for the vast majority of the population there is probably no "best card." That's because most people have limited experience with their credit and/or have a lot of debt (which means they may not even qualify for a credit card with the best perks). Instead, I'd recommend looking at what makes the most sense for your financial situation. If you need to keep your payment low, then I'd focus on the introductory offers. If you want flexibility, then I'd find a credit card with a lower interest rate.But, for most people it doesn't matter because they probably should be using debit cards or cash instead.I don't have a favorite card, but I'll use them for rewards and the bonus rewards categories like 2x gas at supermarket, or 1x everywhere else.I do like the no foreign transaction fee. It is very useful when traveling abroad.This question always comes up and it's so hard to give a definitive answer, especially since the perks vary depending on which card you get.For the average user, the most important thing is to look at how you intend to use your card. If it's to accumulate rewards points, then there are lots of cards out there with decent rewards. Some even give rewards on purchases that aren't the card's rewards category. The best rewards cards also tend to come with a nice annual fee, so look for a card that has a strong rewards category.If you're looking for the best card overall, then I'd look at cashback cards. They typically come with lower fees and can pay up to 5% cashback in certain categories.What I would look for in a card is the lowest possible APR and low fees. If your credit is strong enough, you can get that with most of the credit cards offered in the U.S.There are many different factors that determine whether or not you should have a credit card. You can read about them here and determine what is right for you.But, if I had to choose the best credit card for most people, I'd say it's the one with the lowest APR.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.The American Express Gold Card offers 4X Membership Rewards points per $1 spent at restaurants and at U.S. supermarkets (up to $25,000 per year), 3X Membership Rewards points per $1 spent on flights booked directly with airlines or on prepaid hotels with American Express Travel, and 1X Membership Rewards points per $1 spent on all other purchases. It also offers $100 of Uber Cash each year (up to $10 in December, $20 in January, and $30 in February).The AmEx Gold Card has an annual fee of $250, which isn't waived in the first year. It offers a 0% introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers for 21 months from the date of your first purchase and an APR of 17.49% to 26.49% thereafter. You can see the AmEx Gold Card's full details here.It's worth noting that in 2018, American Express launched a new version of the AmEx Gold Card, which offers fewer points per dollar spent on dining purchases (but more on everything else). This version of the card is no longer available for new cardholders.The AmEx Gold Card also allows you to transfer your rewards to a travel partner.The Chase Sapphire Reserve offers 3X Chase Ultimate Rewards points per $1 spent on travel and dining (including takeout and delivery), 2X points per $1 spent on other travel purchases, and 1X point per $1 spent on everything else. This is one of the highest earning rates I've seen on a travel card.The Chase Sapphire Reserve also has no foreign transaction fees, a 0% introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers for 12 months from the date of your first purchase, and an APR of 17.24% to 25.99% thereafter. It has a $550 annual fee (not waived in the first year).The card offers $300 in travel credits that you can use on either a trip to cover travel expenses or to pay for eligible purchases at select online retailers in the Ultimate Rewards mall. You can see the Chase Sapphire Reserve's full details here.This card also allows you to transfer your rewards to a travel partner.The Platinum Card® from American Express is known as one of the most exclusive cards. It offers 5X Membership Rewards points per $1 spent on flights and prepaid hotels booked with American Express Travel, 5X Membership Rewards points per $1 spent on hotels booked through AmEx Travel, 1.5X Membership Rewards points per $1 spent on purchases in select business categories, and 1X Membership Rewards point per $1 spent on all other purchases.The AmEx Platinum Card also offers $200 in airline fee credits that can be applied toward baggage fees or other services, a $100 Uber credit each year, and a $100 annual Saks Fifth Avenue shopping credit. Plus, it has no foreign transaction fees.The card also offers a 0% introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers for 12 months from the date of your first purchase, and an APR of 17.49% to 25.99% thereafter. It has an annual fee of $550, which is waived in the first year. You can see the Platinum Card's full details here.This card also allows you to transfer your rewards to a travel partner.The AmEx Platinum card also has a unique travel benefit called the $200 hotel credit that gives you a $200 annual statement credit toward purchases at eligible hotel properties when you pay for your stay with your AmEx Platinum card. This benefit works at participating hotels in the Americas, Asia Pacific, Europe, and the Middle East.This benefit gives you one credit of up to $200 each year you spend at least $10,000 on qualifying stays (with eligible purchases at $7,500 and $15,000 earning a $150 and $200 statement credit).I think that the Chase Sapphire Reserve, the American Express Platinum Card, and the American Express Gold Card are the best cards for travel, although the American Express Gold Card is the cheapest.These cards also have the best perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility, in my opinion.But you might prefer the Capital One Venture card, which offers 2 miles per $1 spent on every purchase, no annual fee, and 50,000 miles (equal to $500) after you spend $3,000 on purchases in the first three months.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.While the Bank of America® Travel Rewards card (a personalized offer) offers the best rewards in terms of rewards points for everyday spending, the Bank of America® Customized Cash Rewards card (a personalized offer) offers the lowest APR for people with good credit.Keep reading to learn which credit card might be best for you, based on your specific situation.Earn 1.5 points for every dollar spent on all purchases, automatically.Earn 25% more points for travel booked through the Bank of America Travel Center.Your points never expire, even if you don't use them.There's no cap on how many points you can earn.You can redeem your points for cash, travel, merchandise, gift cards, and more.You can transfer your points to a Bank of America bank account.If you transfer your points to a Bank of America account, there is a $20 minimum and a $1,000 maximum each month.The travel rewards card is a good option if you spend a lot on travel and want to save on your purchases. If you have fair credit, you can check out the Bank of America® Customized Cash Rewards Secured Credit Card.Earn $200 cash rewards bonus after spending $1,000 on purchases in the first 90 days of your account opening.This card is a great choice if you want to earn cash back rewards for every purchase you make. It is a good choice if you want to start establishing credit or you have fair credit and need to build credit.0% APR for 12 billing cycles for purchases, and for any balance transfers you make within 60 days of account opening.You will be charged a 3% (or $10 minimum) fee on balance transfers.With a balance transfer, you can consolidate your debt to a card with a lower interest rate and manage your debt with more ease.The Customized Cash Rewards card is a good choice if you have fair credit and are looking for a credit card with a balance transfer offer.How Much Credit Limit Will I Be Offered?This is one of the most important factors to consider when comparing credit cards.Your credit limit is the maximum amount of money you can spend on your card. This amount is determined based on your credit score, income, existing debt, and more.Since you might be interested in paying off your balance in full each month, you will want to have a high enough credit limit to make this possible.Because each person has unique circumstances, the best credit card limit for one person might not be the best for another.If you would like to find your credit limit ahead of time, you can check your credit score for free on WalletHub.After you have found the credit card with the highest credit limit, you will need to decide if it’s worth the annual fee.Annual fees are charged by many of the best cards, including some with high credit limits.If you spend enough to qualify for the rewards you’re receiving, you will benefit from having a high-limit credit card.However, if the annual fee is more than you’re comfortable with, you can look for a similar card with lower fees.The Bank of America credit cards reviewed in this guide do not have annual fees.Can I Get a Credit Card with a $500 Credit Limit?As of May 2018, the minimum credit limit you can get on a Bank of America credit card is $300.What Credit Score Does Bank of America Need to Approve You for a Credit Card?This question is difficult to answer because banks base their approval decisions on many factors beyond just your credit score.That said, the higher your credit score, the greater the chance you have of being approved for a credit card with Bank of America.If you’re wondering how to get approved for a credit card with Bank of America, the best thing you can do is improve your credit score by making on-time payments and keeping your credit utilization ratio as low as possible.Bank of America is known for its personalized credit card offers. Personalized offers are sent to people who are likely to qualify for certain cards.Because these offers are based on your credit score, you might be approved for one Bank of America card but not another.Even if you do not receive an offer from Bank of America, the bank still might consider you for its credit cards if you apply in-person at a branch.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The more points you accumulate, the more likely you are to get airline miles, redeem points for a vacation, or save up money for a big purchase down the road.With that in mind, I wanted to find out which credit card has the best overall value for its rewards and perks. I also wanted to determine the best overall value of a traditional credit card based on its cash rewards. That way, I could get a good feel for how the top credit cards in America stack up.While many Americans spend money every day, many others tend to save up for big-ticket items or rainy days. And to do that, they may put those funds in a high-yield savings account. In fact, according to The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), over $13 trillion is held in U.S. savings accounts as of 2017, which works out to $135.75 for every person living in the U.S.With this information in mind, I wanted to determine which credit cards are the best for those with big savings. To do that, I looked for credit cards with low rates of interest, no annual fees, and strong rewards programs to help consumers maximize their credit card rewards.To get the information I needed, I first pulled the data on the top credit cards for interest rates, rewards, and overall value. Then, I compared this data to the best savings accounts in the country and found which credit cards would help consumers get more out of their savings while still maximizing their rewards.While each credit card company has different perks, benefits, and fees, each rewards program follows the same basic rules. For example, if you earn 10,000 bonus miles after making your first $5,000 in purchases, you'll receive 10,000 rewards points (100,000 miles) after spending $50,000 with your credit card.There are a number of factors to consider when looking for a credit card. Here are the top credit cards in the country based on their cash rewards.When choosing a credit card, it's important to take into account your financial situation. If you're looking to save money on your credit card, then you'll want to compare the top credit cards based on their rewards program. If you want to maximize your rewards, you'll want to compare the best cards based on their cash rewards.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Here are the cards I would recommend to anyone that I think are the best of the best.The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card is one of my favorite cards to recommend to beginners, especially those who want to earn lots of travel points. Chase offers some of the best travel rewards around with this card. I would recommend this card to someone just starting out who wants to start saving on travel. You'll earn 2X points on dining and travel and 1 point per dollar on everything else. That sounds good, right? Well, it gets even better. You can transfer those rewards to 10+ different airline and hotel partners. You can also redeem them for cash at a 1:1 rate or through Pay Yourself Back at a 1.25 cents value.This card offers tons of travel benefits too. You'll get a $50 statement credit every 4 years for travel purchases, a $60 annual travel credit, and even a $100 Global Entry or TSA Pre-Check credit. If that wasn't enough, you'll get complimentary rental car insurance, primary rental car insurance, and lost luggage coverage. Plus, you'll get Priority Pass Select membership, which offers free airport lounge access.Best for: Those who are just starting out.Annual Fee: $0 for the first year, then $95 afterThis is a great card to start building your credit if you are a young student or just starting out. If you have a student loan and you're looking to build credit, you'll benefit from this card's $0 annual fee and low APR. That's not all. You'll earn 1X point per dollar spent, which can be redeemed for cash back or transferred to a Chase Sapphire card, where the value increases to 1.25 cents. This is a great starter card that will help you build your credit while earning some money on the side.Best for: Students looking to build credit.I think the Amex EveryDay Card from American Express is a great option for those who want to earn 1X point per dollar spent. However, if you're a heavy dining or travel spender, you can't go wrong with this card either. You'll earn 2X points on up to $6,000 in spending per year on dining and travel. That's $12,000 total spent on those categories, meaning you could earn 48,000 Amex points. After that, you'll earn 1 point per dollar spent. You can transfer those points to 14+ different airline and hotel partners, or redeem them for cash at a 1:1 value. You'll also get $100 statement credit each calendar year at US Supermarkets for purchases of $1,000 or more. That's on top of the $120 in annual dining and travel credits you'll get. Plus, you'll get complimentary lounge access, lost luggage insurance, and baggage delay insurance.If you're interested in a no-annual-fee travel rewards credit card, then this is the one you should apply for. You'll earn 2X points on purchases at gas stations and restaurants (up to $1,000 in spending per month) and 1 point per dollar spent on everything else. You can redeem those points for travel through Chase's travel portal. You can also transfer them to 10+ different travel partners. You'll get a $50 statement credit every 4 years for travel purchases, a $60 annual travel credit, and even a $100 Global Entry or TSA Pre-Check credit. If that wasn't enough, you'll get complimentary rental car insurance, primary rental car insurance, and lost luggage coverage. Plus, you'll get Priority Pass Select membership, which offers free airport lounge access.Best for: Those looking to build travel points in a no-annual-fee card.This card offers lots of value for a low annual fee of $0. It's an excellent card for those who want to earn points quickly. With it, you'll earn 1.5X points per dollar spent on all purchases. You can redeem those points for cash, but they're really valuable when redeemed for travel. It is important to note that this card offers 0% APR for 15 months from account opening, then a 14.99%, 20.99%, or 24.99% (variable) APR.Best for: People looking for a 0% APR credit card to help them pay off their purchases.The Citi Premier Card is a great no-annual-fee card to have in your wallet. If you're a foodie, you'll like earning 3X points on dining. You can also earn 3X points on travel and gas and 2X points on groceries. If you have no interest in those categories, then you can simply earn 1X point per dollar spent. That's the same as the Chase Freedom Flex card.You'll earn 60,000 points after you spend $4,000 in the first 6 months. That's worth $750, according to our valuations. This is a great bonus offer for a no-annual-fee card. You can redeem those points for cash, but they're better when you redeem them for travel through Citi's travel portal. You can also transfer them to several different airline and hotel partners. You'll get a $100 statement credit every calendar year on travel purchases.Best for: People who don't want to pay an annual fee and still earn lots of rewards.Annual Fee: $0 for the first year, then $95The United Quest card offers the best bonus and ongoing rewards of any airline credit card. If you're a traveler and you're looking for a new no-annual-fee card, then you should look no further. You'll earn 2X points per dollar spent on United purchases and 1X point per dollar spent on everything else. You'll earn up to a $120 annual travel credit. Plus, you'll get complimentary baggage insurance and travel assistance.There are lots of travel benefits with this card. You'll get a $100 statement credit every 4 years for travel purchases, and a $60 annual travel credit. If that wasn't enough, you'll get complimentary rental car insurance, primary rental car insurance, and lost luggage coverage. Plus, you'll get Priority Pass Select membership, which offers free airport lounge access.Best for: Those who want to build travel points and fly United.I hope this list helps you decide on the best credit cards for you. Feel free to read more of my credit card recommendations for travelers. This makes it a great option for anyone who travels frequently and wants to avoid paying additional fees every time they use their card abroad.Another card that offers excellent rewards is the Chase Freedom Unlimited credit card. This card is similar to the Chase Sapphire Preferred in that it offers two points per dollar spent on dining out and traveling. I think that it depends on your individual needs and spending habits. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.A friend of mine recently purchased a new laptop computer. The salesman told him that the 21-inch LCD screen would last him a lifetime. My friend was skeptical about the salesman's claim, so he asked him for a 90-day money back guarantee. The salesman looked at my friend in shock. "Why do you want a money back guarantee? This is a 21-inch LCD screen. I promise it will last you a lifetime."My friend's response: "But the salesman's promise doesn't last a lifetime. And you don't know that this isn't a defective screen. If you gave me a lifetime guarantee, then I'd have peace of mind."While a money back guarantee isn't something you want to abuse, it's nice to have one when you're considering purchasing big-ticket items. It's also nice to have the option to walk away from your financial commitments.Credit card issuers have realized this. Now, they are willing to issue credit cards that have no annual fee, a 0 percent introductory interest rate, a money back guarantee, and the ability to "walk away" from your financial commitment.Today's card issuers offer two types of cards - reward cards and cash back cards. A reward card typically gives you cash rewards when you spend money. The cash can then be used towards anything you choose (gas, travel, clothing, etc.). A cash back card gives you money back when you spend money. This money is then deposited into your credit card account.The rewards and cash back cards are both excellent options, but each has distinct advantages and disadvantages. If you have been wondering whether a reward or cash back card is better, this article will help you decide.The Cash Back CardA cash back card works by giving you a percentage of what you spend. For example, if you spend $1,000 per year, you will receive $100 back from the issuer. This money is then deposited into your credit card account. You then use this money towards any purchases you choose to make. For example, you can use it towards your monthly cable bill, groceries, or even your mortgage payment.The advantage of a cash back card is that it can provide financial flexibility to consumers. It provides a type of "float" money that you can use towards any of your financial commitments. In essence, this is free money for you to use towards anything you choose.The drawback is that this free money comes at a price. Cash back cards are known for charging higher than average interest rates (18 percent or more). The interest rates are usually charged to your account every month regardless of whether or not you make a purchase.The reward card is a newer option on the scene. This card works by giving you cash when you make a purchase. In the old days, issuers would give you airline miles when you spent money. Now, they will give you cash, and they'll use a wide variety of marketing gimmicks to convince you to spend more.The advantage of a reward card is that it allows you to use your cash to purchase anything you choose. You can use your cash to pay for travel expenses, clothes, or even your mortgage payment. The biggest benefit, though, is the fact that you can get free cash. Rewards cards give you cash back and they are excellent options for consumers who can't resist spending money.The disadvantage is that you can only use your cash towards things you choose. If you spend too much money on clothes or dining out, then you might find that you're not left with as much cash for the things you need. This can result in financial stress and debt, which is why these cards are only recommended for consumers who can resist overspending.The Best Credit Cards: Which Card is Best?The bottom line is that both types of cards are great options. It all depends on the type of cardholder you are. If you are someone who can control your spending and is looking for financial flexibility, then a cash back card is probably the best choice. If you are a type of person who cannot control their spending and is in search of a cash "float," then a cash reward card is probably the best choice.Anthony Nieves is a credit expert who has been writing about personal finance and debt for over a decade. In addition to writing for Debt.org, Anthony has written for other publications such as Credit.com, Forbes, and Yahoo Finance. He is the author of "The Consumer Credit Decision: What You Need to Know Before You Apply for Credit".</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What other criteria do you use when choosing a credit card? Do you prefer to have more than one credit card?A few things to think about when considering a credit card1. Consider the annual fee: An annual fee is the price of holding the credit card. Typically, annual fees range from $50 to $100, but many major banks offer 0% annual fees. Before signing up for a credit card with a fee, make sure that you can make use of the perks that come with it.2. Consider the interest rate: There are usually three types of interest rates that you can find on a credit card: cash advance rate, standard rate, and balance transfer rate. If you carry a balance over several months or years, then it's important to consider what type of rate you'll be charged. Many credit cards offer a 0% rate on balance transfers, while others charge very high cash advance rates.3. Consider the credit limit: The credit limit is the maximum amount of money you can charge to your account before the bank starts charging you interest. The credit limit is also sometimes referred to as the "daily spending limit." Credit cards typically come with a credit limit of $2,000 or more.4. Consider the interest rate: As mentioned above, there are three types of interest rates that you can find on a credit card: cash advance rate, standard rate, and balance transfer rate. Many credit cards also offer a 0% interest rate on balance transfers, while others charge very high cash advance rates.5. Consider the APR: The Annual Percentage Rate is the interest rate charged on balances that are not paid in full by the end of the month. The APR can also be thought of as the cost of borrowing money from a bank.6. Consider the rewards program: The rewards program is a perk offered by some credit cards. Some rewards programs allow you to earn points for every purchase you make, while others offer points for every dollar you spend. You can use your rewards points to buy items from a catalog or to travel.7. Consider the credit card's features: Some credit cards offer additional perks such as auto rental insurance, free travel insurance, and travel assistance. Other cards include an extra line of credit for emergencies. Still other cards offer cash back rebates and airline miles. There are a lot of different types of credit cards, so it's important to know what you're looking for.8. Consider the card issuer: The card issuer is the bank or credit union that you'll be using to pay your bills. Different issuers offer different types of benefits.9. Consider the rewards program: The rewards program is a perk offered by some credit cards. Some rewards programs allow you to earn points for every purchase you make, while others offer points for every dollar you spend. You can use your rewards points to buy items from a catalog or to travel.10. Consider the card's features: Some credit cards offer additional perks such as auto rental insurance, free travel insurance, and travel assistance. Other cards include an extra line of credit for emergencies. Still other cards offer cash back rebates and airline miles. There are a lot of different types of credit cards, so it's important to know what you're looking for.Credit cards can be an easy way to borrow money, but they can also lead to problems if they are not used responsibly. Many people use credit cards for a variety of reasons, including building credit, earning rewards, and saving money. Some people use credit cards to pay for items they cannot afford with cash. Credit cards can help you build credit, but only if you are responsible with your spending. When you use a credit card, you are borrowing money from the bank that issued the card. You will be required to repay this money with interest and fees.There are three types of credit cards: secured, unsecured, and prepaid. Secured credit cards require a deposit in order to use them. The amount of the deposit varies, but is usually equal to the card's maximum spending limit. Secured credit cards are generally used to build credit and improve your FICO score. Unsecured credit cards are not secured with a deposit and do not require an application. These cards are typically used for everyday purchases and do not offer rewards or cash back. Prepaid credit cards are similar to debit cards, but you must load money onto the card in order to use it. Prepaid credit cards do not require an application and are typically used for travel and other expenses.Which credit card is right for you?There are many different types of credit cards available, and each has its own set of benefits and drawbacks. The best way to decide which credit card is right for you is to compare the benefits of each type of card and choose the one that best meets your needs.If you're looking for a low-interest rate, then a secured credit card may be the best option for you. If you're looking for a rewards program, then an unsecured credit card may be a better fit. And if you're looking for a card with no annual fee, then a prepaid credit card may be the best choice for you.No matter which type of credit card you choose, make sure to compare the fees and benefits of each before making your decision. And always remember to use your credit card responsibly so that you can build good credit and enjoy all the benefits that come with it.Here are 7 facts you should know about credit cards.1. Credit cards are a type of loan that allows you to borrow money from a financial institution, such as a bank or credit union. You must repay the loan, with interest, in full each month.2. Credit cards are not just for people with good credit. Even if you have bad credit, you may still be able to get a credit card. The card issuer may require you to pay a higher interest rate, however.3. Credit cards are not just for buying things. You can also use them to make withdrawals from an ATM, pay for items online, and get cash back from a merchant.4. Credit cards are not just for spending money. You can also use them to pay for things like rent, mortgage payments, and utilities.5. Credit cards are not just for adults. Many credit card issuers now offer credit cards for teens and young adults.6. Credit cards are not just for people who live in the United States. Many credit card issuers now offer cards that can be used anywhere in the world.7. Credit cards are not just for people who have a lot of money. Many credit card issuers now offer cards that can be used by people who don't have a lot of money.Credit cards offer a lot of flexibility, but they also come with a lot of responsibility. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.It is very important to me to have a credit card with a low interest rate. I have paid down the balance on my current card (a Discover) and I don't plan on using it again.I would use it to buy things for my business, which is why I want a lower interest rate.If there is a card out there with a great combination of low rate, high limit, great customer service, and perks, I'd like to know about it.I do not have a Discover card, but it sounds like I should consider one.The Chase Freedom card is my favorite card. I get 1% back on all purchases, and 5% on rotating categories (up to $1500 each quarter). Plus it offers $100 cash back for new card members (they'll match your highest sign-up bonus in the past 18 months with other cards).This is probably my all-around favorite card. I also have a Chase card that earns me 2% on gas and dining (but 1% elsewhere).I would recommend you check out www.cardhub.com to see all the cards out there.I have an American Express Blue Cash card, and I like it very much. The card has no annual fee and pays 3% cash back on grocery and drugstore purchases.It has a $25 annual fee for $2500 in annual spending.This is the card I use for all of my personal and business expenses. I get a 1% bonus on my spending, and if I spend more than $10,000, the 1% bonus goes to 2% (and it is 5% on gas stations).I also have a Bank of America business card that pays 1% for purchases, and a Discover card.I will take a look at Card Hub.I also like the Discover card.Thanks for the tip about CardHub, Jody! It's a great tool for comparing different cards and their perks.The American Express Blue Cash card is another card I would like to apply for. It is my favorite of the Blue Cash cards, because it is a cash card (not a points card) and it has a low annual fee.The one thing that makes the Amex Blue Cash card stand out from other cards with lower annual fees is that you get a free monthly report on your credit score, as well as free copies of your credit reports (with your credit score included) once a year.Thanks for posting this, Jody. I agree that Card Hub is a good resource for comparing different cards and their benefits.I also use this site a lot, it's great for comparing rewards cards and figuring out which is best for you based on spending habits, etc.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I use the American Express Platinum card for almost all of my spending, except for the 2% rewards cards I have for my gas purchases and for Whole Foods purchases. My AMEX card has a $450 annual fee, and I don't qualify for a rewards card that offers rewards for my everyday purchases. I love my AMEX card because it's a great card for business travelers; I get 5X rewards on airfare and 10X rewards on hotels booked on the AMEX website, as well as other great perks such as a $100 airline credit, and a $100 hotel credit. Additionally, the card's annual fee is rebated the second year, so I only pay $350. That's a great deal to me for the perks I receive.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.So, please answer one simple question:If you could only have one credit card, what would it be and why?I would choose the Chase Sapphire Preferred card for my choice of one card. The cash back is 2% back on dining and travel expenses, and the rewards you earn can be used on anything. I use it as my everyday card and save on travel.For a long time, I thought about using the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card for that reason as well. However, my experience with the Chase Freedom Unlimited card has been a much more positive one.While the Chase Freedom Unlimited card doesn't have a travel bonus like the Chase Sapphire Preferred card, it does have a 1.5% cash back bonus on all purchases.Plus, it doesn't have an annual fee like the Chase Sapphire Preferred card.So, to answer your question, I'm going to choose the Chase Freedom Unlimited card as my one and only credit card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm not an expert in this area, so I was wondering what kind of help and advice you guys could offer. I really need a credit card that will allow me to pay my bills with some money to spare. I'm looking for a credit card that will give me some extra spending power.Sounds like the best credit card for your situation is the Chase Sapphire Preferred.This is the best card for someone who wants a flexible card to use for everything but airline and hotel booking. The Chase Sapphire Preferred has a 1:1 points ratio on all spending and no cap on the amount of points you can earn. Plus, if you want, you can upgrade to the Sapphire Reserve card and earn 100,000 bonus points after $4,000 spend in the first three months. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Are there any cards that you recommend over the rest?I’m not sure that there is one card that is the best for everyone, as people’s financial situations are quite different. My recommendation for people is to take their time, do some comparison shopping, and then take the time to understand the benefits of the card and compare them to your current lifestyle and financial situation. In this way, you’re making an educated choice. The card you choose should fit your lifestyle and needs and make sense for you.Some cards can offer you rewards for your spending while others can offer you 0% interest on balance transfers, but you need to find out which is best for you.I think it’s important to remember that a credit card can be a great financial tool if used the right way. It should not be thought of as a source of “free money” and should not be used if you are not in a position to repay your debt on time and in full.Most credit cards today come with some kind of rewards program or perks attached to them. What would you consider to be the best credit card rewards program currently offered?It’s a matter of which card is the best for you and the rewards you want. I have found that American Express Membership Rewards to be very versatile and easy to redeem. You can use them to pay off your balance or redeem them for travel, gift cards or cash. I use mine for all of these three options. The best rewards program depends on your personal situation and what you want to get out of your credit card.If I had to pick one card with the best overall rewards program, I would probably pick the AMEX Platinum which comes with a host of benefits and rewards, including priority service at airports, as well as a $200 airline credit per year. I have also found the Barclaycard Arrival Plus to be quite versatile as well.Many people find that they rack up rewards faster than they can actually cash in. As a result, they can build up large amounts of points or miles in their accounts. What do you think is the best way for a cardholder to redeem rewards?This depends on the card you have. Some cards are a better fit if you like to travel and some are better for redeeming for cash. I have both types of cards but like to use my AMEX Membership Rewards points for travel. They are flexible and have a host of transfer options, which allow me to use them for travel all over the world.However, I have found that some people just like to get the money back in their pocket and are not interested in travel rewards. They would rather cash them in for a statement credit and get their money back to pay for everyday expenses. This works well for those who do not travel often and want the cash back.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.As far as credit cards go, there are plenty of perks to choose from: cash back, airline miles, hotel points, and discounts at restaurants. While the perks sound great, it's easy to get overwhelmed by all the different cards on the market today.My two favorite credit cards for travel are:Airlines often have special sales where points are worth a lot more. That's the best time to book!Here are some of my favorite perks that come with the Citi Prestige:An airline credit card that allows you to accumulate pointsWith the Chase Sapphire Reserve, you can accumulate airline miles with every purchase you make. For those who like to travel, this card is a great option for travel. The card also offers a $300 annual travel credit that can be used for airfare or hotel stays.Chase Sapphire Reserve cardholders earn 50,000 bonus points after spending $4,000 within the first three months of card ownership. In addition, they earn an extra 10,000 bonus points each anniversary year. The points earned with the Chase Sapphire Reserve can be redeemed for cash, gift cards, merchandise, and even travel through Chase Ultimate Rewards®.The Chase Sapphire Reserve also offers a 50 percent bonus on all rewards earned from dining and travel. In addition, there are no foreign transaction fees for purchases made outside the United States.You can also get reimbursed for your TSA PreCheck® or Global Entry® membership. These programs allow you to speed through airport security with minimal or no lines.What is Citi Prestige?Citi Prestige is a credit card from Citibank that offers its cardholders rewards, including travel, dining, and shopping. The card also provides other benefits such as concierge services and access to special offers and discounts. The card comes with a $450 annual fee and has a 18-month introductory period.If you're looking for a travel credit card, you may want to consider the Chase Sapphire Reserve® or the American Express® Gold Card. Both cards offer travel perks like airport lounge access and airline credits. But if you're looking for a card that provides more comprehensive travel benefits, including hotel stays, rental cars, and other benefits, the Citi Prestige may be a better option.The Chase Sapphire Reserve® offers more comprehensive travel benefits than the Citi Prestige. It offers a $300 annual travel credit that can be used for hotel stays, airfare, or car rentals. The card also provides complimentary membership to TSA PreCheck and Global Entry. Additionally, cardholders receive an annual $100 airline credit that can be used on any airline.The Citi Prestige also offers travel benefits, including a $250 annual travel credit and TSA PreCheck or Global Entry membership. However, the card's other benefits are limited compared to the Chase Sapphire Reserve®. For example, the Citi Prestige does not offer free airport lounge access, airline credits, or free Uber rides.The Citi Prestige is a travel rewards credit card that allows you to earn 3x points on all purchases made at restaurants, airlines, and hotels. You can also earn 2x points on all other purchases. The Citi Prestige also offers a 100,000-point bonus for new cardholders.Is Citi Prestige a good card?The Citi Prestige is a good card for those who travel often and want to earn rewards. The annual fee is $495, but it comes with some excellent perks.The card offers a 3x points multiplier on travel purchases, a $250 annual travel credit, airport lounge access, and more. Plus, you'll receive a free one-way award ticket after your first purchase with the card.The only downside to this card is that it doesn't have a sign-up bonus like some other travel cards. Still, if you're looking for a card that rewards you for your travels, the Citi Prestige is a great option.Is it worth paying the annual fee for the Citi Prestige?The annual fee for the Citi Prestige is $495. It's worth it if you use the card's benefits often. If you use the card for all your travel expenses, it will quickly pay for itself. Plus, you'll receive valuable perks, including airport lounge access and a $250 annual travel credit.Is it possible to get reimbursed for the annual fee?The annual fee for the Citi Prestige is $495. If you spend enough on your card each year, you can get reimbursed for the annual fee. In addition to reimbursing your annual fee, the Citi Prestige also comes with complimentary airport lounge access and a $250 annual travel credit.The Citi Prestige card is a travel rewards credit card that offers some of the best perks and benefits in the industry. However, it does have some drawbacks, including an expensive annual fee and poor rewards on dining and gas.What is the Citi Prestige annual fee?The Citi Prestige annual fee is $495. This fee covers the cardholder's access to airport lounges and other travel perks, such as complimentary rental cars, airport transfers, and a $250 annual travel credit.What is the Citi Prestige APR?The Citi Prestige APR is 26.99%. This APR is variable, so it may change over time.What is the Citi Prestige foreign transaction fee?The Citi Prestige foreign transaction fee is 2% of the transaction amount. This fee applies to purchases made in foreign currencies or with foreign currency cards.Citi Prestige is a travel rewards credit card that offers some of the best perks and benefits in the industry. However, it does have some drawbacks, including an expensive annual fee and poor rewards on dining and gas. Still, if you're looking for a card with excellent travel benefits, Citi Prestige is worth considering.The Best Credit Card for Travel: How to ChooseThe best credit card for travel is one that offers a variety of perks and benefits. For example, you may want to consider a card that has a sign-up bonus or a low APR. You may also want to look for a card that offers travel insurance or a rewards program.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I've asked this question before (see here), but I've never received a definitive response.So let me be more specific, for those of you that aren't interested in Chase Sapphire Preferred (the best card, in my opinion) but are looking for something better suited to the average traveler (like me!)...Please select one of the following:American Express Gold - 35k offerDiscover It - 50k offerCiti Prestige - 35k offerSouthwest Premier - 40k offerCiti ThankYou Premier - 50k offerSouthwest Premier Plus - 50k offerSouthwest Business - 50k offerCiti Hilton HHonors - 40k offerChase Sapphire Preferred - 50k offerChase Freedom Unlimited - 30k offerChase Freedom - 30k offerChase Sapphire Reserve - 50k offerChase Sapphire Reserve Preferred - 50k offerCapital One Venture - 40k offerCapital One Spark Cash Select - 20k offerCapital One Spark Miles - 30k offerCapital One Spark Cash Plus - 20k offerChase Ink Plus - 50k offerChase Ink Preferred - 50k offerChase Ink Business Cash - 20k offerChase Ink Business Preferred - 50k offerCapital One Spark Miles Select - 20k offerCapital One Spark Cash Select - 20k offerDiscover it Chrome - 50k offerDiscover it Miles - 50k offerDiscover it Balance Transfer - 50k offerI just added the Discover it Balance Transfer offer to this poll because the card offers more than just a 0% APR and has a sign-up bonus. However, I'm not sure it's really better than the other cards on the list.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.For my own personal use, I've recently applied for the Chase Sapphire Preferred® card. I've seen some amazing travel perks for the first year and am looking forward to cashing in on them!I also use the Discover It® Cash Back card, for it's unique 5% cash back category perks. The fact that you receive 1.5% on everything else is also a nice bonus!As for my credit history and score, I've never had a credit card in the past, so the process was definitely a learning experience.Let me know what you choose in the comments below!If you need to build or rebuild your credit, Discover it is a great way to do it. The card allows users to rebuild their credit and earn 1.5% cash back at the same time. Discover it also has a longstanding and strong history of protecting their cardholders from fraud.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.1) Which credit card do you use?2) What makes it the card of your choice?3) What would you like to see in the card of the future?4) What do you think of the current credit card climate in the U.S.?5) Have you ever used a prepaid card? If so, how has it worked out for you?This is a great discussion topic. I'll start out with a few observations of my own first and then get to your questions.For the past year or so I've been using a no-fee AmEx Blue cash card. The only fee I pay on it is a $1 transaction fee for every out-of-network ATM use. I pay that fee for two reasons. First, it saves me the $1 ATM fee that my bank would otherwise charge me. Second, I've found it to be one of the easiest ways to get cash out of a machine with no hassles. When I used to have my debit card with a brick and mortar bank I would use an in-network ATM and pay a $2 fee, so it was $1 more for nothing.As far as the no-fee AmEx Blue card, I do not have an introductory interest rate of any sort, no APR bonus, and no cash back rewards of any kind. I don't use my credit card to buy gas, groceries, or to pay rent, and I've paid off the entire balance on my card for two years running. So, I can't really complain about paying an ATM fee if I know I won't rack up a balance I can't pay off.I have seen the benefits of getting a card with some sort of rewards program, but I think it's a waste to carry a balance on that kind of card. That's the only reason I got rid of a rewards card I had for a few years. I was a heavy user and racked up a balance of about $4,000 (which is actually very small compared to most credit card balances). I think it would have been a bit insane for me to keep the card and not pay off the balance in full every month, so I got rid of the card.I still get my AmEx Blue cash card every year, but I don't know if I'll use it in 2013. In 2012, I used the $500 cap AmEx Blue cash card I had from last year. It was easy to use, very convenient, and saved me money when it comes to fees (both on ATM withdrawals and foreign currency).As far as what I'd like to see in the card of the future, it would be good if it were easy to pay off and if the fees were low. I'm also not crazy about credit cards that offer more benefits and rewards in exchange for paying an annual fee. The only cards I'd be interested in are no-fee cards. I'd also like a card that could save me money when traveling abroad. There are several cards that offer that kind of coverage, but they all seem to charge fees. That's too much when I could just use my debit card instead.As far as the credit card climate in the U.S., I think it's gotten better in the past few years, but it still has a long way to go. I don't think it's going to improve too much in the near future as long as there are still high-interest, high-balance credit card users. That being said, it does seem like credit card lenders are a bit more responsible and that's a good thing. I don't see many credit cards that charge no-fee, but the interest rates are as high as 30% these days. I don't know if that is because of the new CFPB or not, but I like it better than the old way.As far as prepaid cards go, I've only used one a couple of times when I forgot to bring enough cash with me. I'd like to use them more, but the fees make it expensive to use them as a substitute for debit or credit cards.1) I am currently on a Capital One Venture Rewards credit card with the 50k bonus if you spend $3,000 in the first three months. I have been a Chase Freedom Visa card holder for several years with a zero balance every month and a 5% cash back rate on groceries and dining. I switched over to the Venture Rewards Card because of the cash back rate and also because I found out I can transfer the points to frequent flyer miles which is what I usually do.2) The Venture Rewards Card is the best card I've ever had. It gives you 2x points on all purchases except gas and airlines. I spend a lot on gas and airlines so that makes the card perfect for me. In addition, I've gotten a 50,000 points bonus when I met the $3,000 spending minimum. I also have the benefit of the 5% cash back rate when I need to spend on groceries or dining out.3) I think I'd like to see the card companies offer a better rate of return. The current rate of return on many of the reward cards is a joke compared to the spending that goes on each month. My personal opinion is that I'd rather have a 5% cash back rate on everything I purchase (similar to my Freedom card) and not be rewarded based on where I spend.4) I think the current climate is actually quite good in comparison to what it used to be. I'm pretty sure that some people would disagree with me but the truth is that the credit card companies aren't as greedy as they used to be. Sure, they charge a ton of fees for late payments and the like, but the interest rate is generally lower. When you consider that a credit card is just a loan with a lower interest rate it makes a lot more sense. It's the same thing as a student loan, they give you a lower interest rate but if you don't pay it off in time the interest grows and grows.5) I've never really used a prepaid card. I had an American Express card several years ago that was prepaid but I never used it. I think it's pretty easy to use but it's a pain to get cash from the ATM with a prepaid card.It's difficult to make any judgement on my credit card as it doesn't provide me with any benefits (other than a few bucks to spend on my grocery bill). I use a Citi Double Cash credit card (0% APR for the first 18 months) that I received a few months ago. I have to say that I'm not impressed with the card so far. It seems like they are only interested in trying to get as much interest out of you as possible.I would like to be able to earn more reward points. I also would like it to offer cashback, but it only offers points. In addition, they charge a pretty high interest rate and it takes quite a bit of time to earn the 1% cashback.The credit card climate seems to be getting more reasonable but I still feel that the rates are still too high. I don't use my credit card for many things other than buying groceries and gas, so the rates are very reasonable for me. I'm sure that they would be higher for people that have more expensive spending habits.I've never used a prepaid card before but I'm interested in looking into them. I am currently in the market for a new credit card so I will have to research prepaid cards a little more.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I have a Chase Freedom Unlimited, the Freedom, a Chase Ink Preferred, a Capital One Venture, and a couple of others. Right now my Ink and Freedom have no annual fees and Capital One will cover them next year. I was really happy with the Ink Unlimited when it had no annual fee, but I didn't care for the fact that the card is subject to the 5/24 rule. So, it is still useful to me, but I wish I could be using it for more purchases.The Capital One Venture was another that had an annual fee and has been cancelled. It is a no-fee card with the best cash back program I have seen. It was a lot of fun to watch the balance go up and up. It was nice to be able to travel and save money, but I think I need to consolidate the cards. My wife has a Chase Sapphire Preferred and she is able to use Ultimate Rewards to get better deals on airline and hotel bookings. That makes her a good candidate to take over the Ink Unlimited.I'm still trying to find the right combination for myself. I love the flexibility and security of Chase cards, but don't really need another Chase card. My wife can handle the Chase Preferred and Ultimate Rewards, but I want to find a credit card with low interest rates. I would love to consolidate the Ink Unlimited with another card that has more flexibility.Any suggestions?
