<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm referring to cash back or rewards credit cards, specifically those which provide 3% cash back on all purchases.There are quite a few cards out there offering this perk.For simplicity's sake, I'll focus on a list of the best cash back credit cards with no annual fee and the best cash back credit cards with no minimum balance requirements.Cards that meet these criteria will appeal to the vast majority of consumers because it's free money.We all love free money.The following are my three picks for the best 3% cash back credit cards.Between the three cards, there are a variety of features and benefits.The information in the following sections will help you determine the card that best suits your needs.If your goal is to get the most money back on all purchases, I recommend the Capital One Savor Cash Rewards Credit Card.This card is the highest yield cash back credit card that I know of, offering 3% cash back on all purchases.But it doesn't stop there. The card also offers 3% cash back at restaurants, 3% cash back on entertainment, and 3% cash back on travel.The cash back rewards are worth 10% more when redeemed for travel purchases through the Capital One Travel portal.In addition to the cash back, the card also offers 0% interest on all purchases for the first 15 months.This card has no foreign transaction fee, so you won't pay any additional fees when using the card outside of the United States.It has a variable purchase APR of 15.99% to 25.99%, which is the average rate charged on cash back credit cards.Keep in mind that this card has a $95 annual fee.I would only recommend it if you'll be able to make good use of the annual 3% cash back categories.You'll have to keep track of the categories, which can be a hassle if you use the card for all of your purchases.So if you spend a lot on restaurants, entertainment, and travel, the Savor card can be a good deal.The Discover it® Cash Back credit card offers an unparalleled sign-up bonus.It gives new cardholders $200 cash back after they spend $1,500 in the first three months.But the card doesn't just reward you with sign-up bonuses.In addition to the introductory bonus, you'll also get a $100 cash back bonus after spending $1,000 in the first 12 months.Discover also gives you 1% cash back on every purchase, so it's an all-around solid card that rewards your spending.You can redeem the rewards for cash back, gift cards, or merchandise.The cash back earned will be worth 100% of what you earn. So if you earn $100 in cash back, you'll receive $100 in the form of a statement credit.The card comes with no annual fee, which is good because there are other cards that offer better rewards without charging any annual fees.Its variable purchase APR is 10.99% to 22.99%.Keep in mind that this card does charge an upfront balance transfer fee of 3% of the amount transferred.I recommend the Discover it® Cash Back if you want to earn money back with no annual fee.It's an excellent card for anyone looking for an easy way to earn cash back.The last pick for the best 3% cash back credit cards is the Citi Double Cash card.The Double Cash card offers 1% cash back on all purchases, so it's not the best rewards card in the bunch.However, its 2% cash back on all purchases category makes it a unique offering.There is no cap on the amount of cash back you can earn and the rewards are worth 100% of what you earn.You can also get a $200 sign-up bonus after spending $1,500 in the first six months.The card also has a great 0% introductory APR on purchases for the first 18 months.This is a welcome perk considering that most credit cards charge a variable purchase APR of 14.49% to 22.49%.There is a $0 annual fee on the card, so it's a good option for anyone looking to get a great deal on cash back rewards.There are a few downsides to the Citi Double Cash card.The first one is that it does charge a foreign transaction fee of 3%. This fee is pretty standard on most cash back credit cards.Another potential drawback is the card's high APR of 17.24% to 25.24%.The rewards are good, but they are worth less than they would be if they weren't capped at 100%.The card is a great choice for people who want to maximize their cash back rewards.It's a good card for anyone looking for an easy way to earn cash back with no annual fee.The bottom line is that all of the cards on the list offer excellent cash back rewards.They are all well-suited to different types of consumers and will likely fit the bill for most people.My top pick is the Citi Double Cash card because it's a great choice for anyone looking to maximize their rewards.But I recommend the other two cards for anyone who doesn't want to pay an annual fee.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'd appreciate your input. Thanks!I've always had excellent experiences with Chase and am thinking of switching to the Sapphire Preferred Card because I know it offers 20,000 bonus points after you spend $1,000 in the first three months. These points can be redeemed for a 20% discount at hotels.com, travelocity.com, or expedia.com, or 1.25 cents per point for travel.My biggest concern is my credit rating. I just became a U.S. resident three years ago, and have very little experience with credit in this country. How do you think my FICO score will be affected by applying for this card? What about my credit rating in general?Hi, and thanks for your question. It's true that your credit rating can be adversely affected by opening too many credit accounts. That being said, I'd still apply for the Sapphire Preferred Card because you can earn 10,000 bonus points if you use it within the first three months.That brings me to my next point. I know many people get hung up on credit-card bonus point offers. For me, however, I have to weigh the benefits of the offer against the risks of opening a new account. In your case, I think it's safe to assume that you can earn 10,000 points without harming your credit rating or credit standing in any way.My biggest advice is that you not apply for several new credit cards in a short period of time. If you're concerned that a new credit card will adversely affect your credit rating, there's a way to reduce the risk of doing so.My favorite method is to apply for only one card a year. For example, you might want to apply for a travel card and a cash-back card once or twice a year. That way you don't have to worry about applying for a credit card if you're not ready for one.I'd also encourage you to apply for the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. You'll receive 20,000 bonus points if you spend $1,000 within three months of opening your account.The bottom line is that I think the Sapphire Preferred Card offers you excellent perks for a low annual fee. The card also has no annual fee for the first year, and you'll receive $200 in travel credit if you purchase a plane ticket using your card.Overall, I believe the Sapphire Preferred Card offers the best combination of rewards, low interest rates, and financial flexibility. Good luck and happy traveling!</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. How would you describe your personal definition of a perfect credit card?I recently asked this same question to our community over on Reddit, and the discussion that ensued shed some light on the different types of cards that people are using to build their credit or get out of debt.Weighing Credit Card Perks Against RatesI'll give a brief overview of the top five credit cards people cited for their own use, but I'll focus primarily on the perks they get out of each. Many people who have high-interest credit card debt are turning to balance transfer cards to reduce the cost of their monthly payments. If that sounds like you, then a balance transfer card is definitely in order.In addition to low rates, balance transfer cards typically offer an introductory period of 0% interest. This allows you to consolidate your high-interest debt into a single, low-interest loan, and if you pay it off in full during the introductory period, you'll avoid paying any interest on your balance at all. Some balance transfer cards don't charge a balance transfer fee.Best Balance Transfer Card: Chase SlateChase's Slate card has one of the best 0% introductory offers on the market—an introductory period of 15 months on balance transfers and new purchases. And while the standard APR is 15.24% variable APR, it has no annual fee, no balance transfer fee, and the introductory rate is retroactive to your first day of membership. That means that your balance transfers won't count against your 15-month period, even if they were completed before you signed up for the card.Best Starter Credit Card: Capital One PlatinumI'm a big fan of Capital One's Platinum card. It has no annual fee, which is great for people looking to build credit. But unlike some starter credit cards, it has an introductory offer of 0% for new purchases for 15 months, along with a 0% balance transfer offer for the first 15 months. This means you can use the card to build your credit, and even take advantage of a 0% balance transfer to pay off debt.Best Cash-Back Card: Chase FreedomIf you spend a lot on gas, dining out, and purchases made through PayPal, you'll get the most from the Chase Freedom Unlimited. But there are lots of cash-back cards that work similarly. For instance, the Discover it Cashback Match offers 1% unlimited cash back on all purchases, which is then matched with 1% from the first year. That means 2% cash back on all purchases. There is a $0 annual fee.Best Credit-Building Card: Capital One PlatinumCapital One offers several credit-building cards with different features. But its Platinum card offers one of the best introductory periods, along with a reasonable APR of 26.99% variable APR. There is no annual fee and it's easy to apply for the card online in just a few minutes.Best Flagship Card: Citi ThankYou PreferredCiti's flagship ThankYou Preferred card offers 10% cash back in the form of ThankYou points at gas stations and drug stores, and it also earns 2x points on restaurants and entertainment. It also offers 1x point on all other purchases, and you can redeem ThankYou points for cash back at an effective 1 cent apiece. If you travel frequently, you might find that the Citi Prestige offers more value with its 5x points at air travel and hotels.What Makes a Perfect Credit Card?For me, the ideal credit card offers low rates, a 0% balance transfer offer, and decent rewards. It's great for everyday spending, and it has no annual fee. If you're trying to build credit, a card with a low rate and no annual fee is probably your best bet. If you have a lot of credit card debt, then a balance transfer card is in order. But a lot of people with debt are also using these cards to improve their credit rating.This type of card is the best for those who want a simple option that can help them build credit. Many of these cards also have low rates and may offer other features, such as cash-back rewards. These cards are good for people who don't need balance transfer offers, but they are good for those who want a credit-building card.A balance transfer card is a great option if you have a lot of debt and want to consolidate it into one, low-interest loan. This type of card usually has a lower interest rate than a cash-back card, which makes it a great choice for people who want to pay off their credit card debt.The best card for building your credit is the one with the lowest interest rate and the lowest fees. You can get both with a balance transfer card, so it's a great choice if you have high-interest credit card debt.A balance transfer card is a good option for those who want to build their credit, but they don't have much credit history yet. With a balance transfer card, you can transfer your high-interest credit card debt to a lower-interest card, and you can pay it off faster.If you want to get a credit card but don't know what type of card is best for you, the best thing to do is to figure out your goals. Do you want to build your credit? Pay off your debt? Earn rewards? Do you want to do all of those things? Once you figure out what you want to do, you can figure out the best credit card for you.</s>

And while I can't speak for everyone, I do have my favorites.My preferred credit cardMy preferred credit card, without question, is the Chase Freedom Unlimited®. I like that it offers 2 miles per dollar on purchases, and that you can transfer those rewards to 11 travel partners. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Are you an AMEX holder or a Chase Freedom cardholder? Do you prefer one of the major banks over the major credit unions? Or, if you're not yet familiar with some of the major players, are you simply not sure which one suits your lifestyle best?To help you sort out the most important factors, below is a brief description of a few of the best options for credit cards. We'll take a close look at two of the most popular options from the big banks -- American Express and Chase -- as well as some of the top options from credit unions and smaller banks.Here are the best credit cards of 2013.Chase Freedom -- The best combination of perks and financial flexibility.With the Chase Freedom, the biggest selling point is the low interest rate on new purchases. This card offers a competitive APR on new purchases of 13.24% with a balance transfer option. In addition to low interest rates, the Chase Freedom also offers 1% cash back on all purchases, so you can get reimbursed for nearly everything you buy.The biggest downside to the Chase Freedom is the annual fee. But considering the card's low interest rate and cash back perks, it's a worthwhile expense for some.A second downside to the Chase Freedom is that the card does not offer travel rewards. This is a major disadvantage if you plan on taking frequent trips and want to take advantage of credit card points.American Express SPG -- A perfect option for business owners.The American Express SPG card is designed for the business owner in mind. The annual fee on this card is steep, but you can easily earn it back through the free nights and hotel rewards.One of the biggest advantages of the American Express SPG is the free nights, which give cardholders one free night in hotels that cost up to 30,000 points every year. If you're a frequent traveler who stays at hotels throughout the year, this is a great perk. In addition, the hotel rewards program gives you a point for each dollar you spend on a hotel.The biggest downside to the American Express SPG is the lack of low interest rates and perks on purchases. The interest rates and perks on the card are focused solely on travel rewards. So, this card is great for business owners who travel often, but not so great for someone who spends money in other places, such as on groceries and gas.USAA Cashback Rewards -- A perfect option for someone who doesn't travel.If you don't travel frequently or like to stay at specific hotels, the USAA Cashback Rewards card is an ideal option. This card has a low APR and gives cardholders 1% cash back for each dollar they spend.The only downside to the USAA Cashback Rewards card is that it has a very low interest rate. While the 1% cash back per dollar you spend is ideal, many other cards have lower interest rates than this.One of the best ways to compare credit card options is to do so side-by-side. The following chart, which you can find here, gives you a detailed comparison between the American Express SPG, USAA Cashback Rewards, and the Chase Freedom.It's easy to get bogged down in the credit card application process and forget which card offers the most cash back or which one offers the lowest interest rate. The chart below gives you a quick way to compare several of the best options so you can easily figure out which card is best for your lifestyle.Which credit card is best for you? The answer depends on your lifestyle. But whatever card you choose, make sure to pay off your balance each month and to keep your finances in check. If you can stick to those two golden rules, any credit card will be perfect for you.Joe Cortez is a personal finance blogger and the founder of DollarForDollar.com. You can connect with Joe on Facebook and Twitter.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. While many credit card companies now offer a multitude of attractive perks and benefits, there are a few that stand out above the rest. I'm talking about the Chase Sapphire Preferred and the Citi Prestige cards.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card is currently the best starter credit card, especially for those who love to travel. On the other hand, the Citi Prestige card is one of the most luxurious and premium cards on the market. So, what are the main differences between the two? Keep reading to find out.The Citi Prestige card is best suited for those who are interested in earning more points with every purchase they make, and those who are looking to redeem those points for high-end travel. On the other hand, the Chase Sapphire Preferred card is best suited for those who are looking to earn and redeem their points for everyday purchases.The Citi Prestige card offers several benefits that make it a top choice for travelers. For starters, the card offers 3 points per dollar spent on all travel and dining purchases, and 2 points per dollar spent on all other purchases. You can also earn an additional 50,000 bonus points if you spend $4,000 in the first three months after opening your account.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card also offers several benefits that make it a top choice for travelers. For starters, the card offers 2 points per dollar spent on all travel and dining purchases, and 1 point per dollar spent on all other purchases. Additionally, you can earn an additional 50,000 bonus points if you spend $4,000 in the first three months after opening your account.Another key difference between these two cards is the sign-up bonus. The Citi Prestige card offers a 50,000-point sign-up bonus, which is worth $625 in travel credits. The Chase Sapphire Preferred card offers a 50,000-point sign-up bonus, which is worth $600 in travel credits.So, which card is right for you? If you're looking to earn and redeem your points for travel, the Citi Prestige card is a great option. If you're looking to earn and redeem your points for everyday purchases, the Chase Sapphire Preferred card is a better choice.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.It’s no secret that credit card debt is on the rise, and the Federal Reserve recently found that 45% of Americans have a balance on their credit cards. It’s more important than ever to get a credit card with a great balance transfer offer, rewards program, or a combination of both.I personally like having one credit card that offers low interest and good rewards points, as long as those rewards aren’t too hard to earn.So, if you’re curious to know which credit card you should be considering, we’ve got a few suggestions that might make your decision easier.Before we dive in, I’ll warn you that there are some great options below and it may be tough to pick one over another. Just remember that your credit and income play a huge role in determining which card you can qualify for, so make sure you know where you stand before you begin the application process.With that in mind, here are the best credit cards to consider in 2018.If you can’t qualify for an offer like this (like if you have bad credit), you can always take a look at credit card offers from issuers that focus more on customers with fair and good credit. That said, a company like Capital One has some really great offers for customers with good credit, so you’re not going to be out of luck.One of the best things about this card is that you’ll get 0% on both new purchases and balance transfers for 20 months (or up to 21 months, depending on the terms offered). After that, you’ll be charged an 11.9% interest rate.As far as the rewards you earn, Capital One offers a simple 2% cash back program (1% back on the date of purchase, and an additional 1% back six months later).However, to be eligible for this card, you’ll need to have a credit score of at least 690.The APR for the Sapphire Preferred card is slightly lower at 13.99%-22.99% based on your creditworthiness, and you’ll also earn 2x points for dining, travel, and even on transit and gas stations.Between those two cards, I would lean toward the Sapphire Preferred for a number of reasons. For starters, the card’s 20-month offer is a little more enticing, and that could come in handy if you’re looking to pay off your credit card balance before a large expense (like a wedding).Additionally, the travel rewards and dining/gas station benefits are worth considering, and you can get cash back on travel when you book through Chase’s Ultimate Rewards portal.If you want to qualify for either card, you’ll need a minimum annual income of $30,000.While you might be able to qualify for the Capital One Venture card without a strong income, the Chase Sapphire Preferred card has a few requirements that will limit your chances of being approved.The first requirement is a credit score of at least 690. That said, there are some options available that can help you build your credit, and I’d suggest looking into those if you’re worried about your current score.The next requirement is an income of at least $30,000 a year. If your income is higher than that, you shouldn’t have a problem qualifying for this card.While you’ll earn unlimited 1.5% cash back with the BankAmericard, it only has a 0% interest rate for 6 months. Plus, there’s no rewards program attached to this credit card.If you have bad or fair credit, you’ll need to look elsewhere.It also doesn’t have a rewards program attached to it, but you do get some nice perks.For starters, you’ll get a $150 cash back bonus if you spend $500 on the card in the first 90 days of owning it.You’ll also be able to take advantage of Discover’s Miles program, which allows you to collect 1.5x miles on every dollar spent on travel.As you can see, there’s a bit of a tradeoff between the Chase Sapphire Preferred and Capital One Venture cards.Both cards offer 0% interest for the first 18 months and you’ll earn rewards that can be used for travel, dining, and more.The Capital One Venture card offers rewards on both dining and travel that can be used with a variety of providers, which could be a huge help if you’re looking to book your next vacation. Additionally, you’ll have the ability to use your cash back as a statement credit or check, which is convenient if you want to make your payment with cash.The Sapphire Preferred card, on the other hand, offers rewards you can use for travel booked through Chase’s Ultimate Rewards portal. In other words, you can’t simply redeem your points for cash back (as you can with the Capital One card), but that might not be a big deal for some people.I would also give the nod to the Capital One Venture card if you’re looking to earn rewards. While the Sapphire Preferred card offers some good rewards, the Capital One Venture card offers unlimited rewards, which means you can collect more points as you use the card for everyday purchases.Of course, you can also use your points for travel booked through Chase’s Ultimate Rewards portal, but if you have to pay a travel charge for your ticket, you’ll be taking home less cash.Finally, while the Sapphire Preferred card has a 0% interest rate for a longer period of time, you’ll be paying a higher APR afterward (13.99%-22.99%, depending on your credit score).On the other hand, the Capital One Venture card has a lower APR, though it only lasts for 18 months. After that, you’ll be charged an APR between 12.99% and 22.99%, which is still lower than what you’ll pay with the Sapphire Preferred card.If you have good credit, I’d recommend considering the Capital One Venture card. It offers a great 0% interest promotion, unlimited rewards, and an APR that isn’t too high after you reach the end of the promotion period.However, if you have bad or fair credit, I’d recommend taking a look at one of the options from Wells Fargo and Bank of America.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.For the time being, my primary card of choice is the Citi Diamond Preferred Card®, which is an outstanding balance transfer option. This is primarily because of the fact that I don't use the card for anything other than making balance transfers and paying off the transfer balance in full.While the 21-month 0% introductory APR on balance transfers and purchases does not expire until the balance transfer has been paid off, the interest rate after that will likely be in the neighborhood of 17.99% or greater. Since I don't pay any interest charges (because I make payments in excess of the minimum), this is not an issue for me.When you consider that I receive an excellent 5% cash back bonus on all purchases made with this card, I am also well compensated for my financial discipline in this regard.For cash back rewards, I use the Discover It® Card. I enjoy earning the 5% cash back on purchases at restaurants and gas stations, as well as on purchases in other categories (including travel), each quarter. In addition, I appreciate the ease of earning 1% cash back on all of my other purchases.I have a Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards Credit Card, which is the card with which I earn the most cash back each year. However, it doesn't earn any bonus categories of cash back; instead, it gives you 1.5% cash back on all purchases.It is worthwhile to have a card that you use for all of your purchases in order to maximize your earnings.When I have a specific use for a new purchase that I do not intend to pay off immediately, I usually use my Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card, which has a 2-year 0% introductory APR.In addition, there is the possibility of earning 60,000 Ultimate Rewards points after making $4,000 in purchases within the first three months of opening the card, which is an additional benefit. In this situation, I like to keep my balance at a minimum of $500 to maximize the benefits of the 21-month 0% introductory APR period.I have a few other cards in my wallet, but this is by far the most frequently used and well-liked of the bunch.Since you have more credit cards, the amount you pay in interest will also increase. As a result, you will need to be more cautious about your spending habits and pay off your balances more quickly to avoid paying interest. If you spend more than you can afford to pay off, you should always pay at least the minimum payment in order to avoid paying interest.If you want to make sure that you will be able to make the payments, only take out a credit card that you can easily pay off in full each month. It is not worthwhile to incur debt on a credit card if you will be required to pay interest on it.If you want to keep your credit score high, only use credit cards that have a low interest rate. Even if you have a high credit limit and are only using a portion of it, the total amount of credit available to you can be a factor in your credit score.Because the minimum payment requirement is determined by the credit limit that has been assigned to your account, the lower the credit limit, the higher your minimum payment will be. This is a significant disadvantage for people who are required to make a minimum payment in order to prevent default.Using credit cards to pay for small expenses like groceries and gasoline on a regular basis is a good way to increase your credit limit and improve your credit score.Your credit score is impacted when you use a credit card to pay for expensive items such as a new automobile or home improvement.Your credit score is affected by the types of things you use credit cards to buy.To improve your credit score, you should make at least the minimum payment each month. Make sure that you don't have any outstanding balances on your cards, which is one of the quickest ways to increase your credit score.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.For those of you who use several cards, I'd like to know which one you think is your favorite.As you can imagine, I get a lot of requests for credit card recommendations, and for a while now, I've been telling people that the Citi Double Cash is my favorite. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm in the market for a new credit card that can be used as a primary form of payment (e.g. groceries, etc.).My ideal situation would be to pay off the balance in full each month, and only use the perks (air miles, cash back, etc.) of the card every once in a while.I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. If you have no knowledge of Canadian credit cards, it's fine to say that. If you know of some great cards in the US that are comparable, please let me know.A few years ago, I had the MBNA World Mastercard with an annual fee of $45. That was the time of year where credit card companies were offering bonus points for getting new credit cards, so I signed up for that card and got 10,000 points (in 2 categories). That was enough to get us a free weekend stay at a nice hotel (e.g. Marriott Residence Inn).Now that I'm looking to renew my card, I find that it now has a $79 annual fee.I'm not sure how the new card compares to MBNA's old World Mastercard, but the new MBNA Platinum Mastercard appears to be less favorable.The MBNA World Mastercard appears to offer a higher credit limit and higher bonus points for travel expenses, but with the annual fee, I don't think it's a good deal for me. I don't travel outside of North America often and the travel expenses I make are usually within Canada (e.g. Air Canada).The RBC Rewards Mastercard (which has an annual fee of $25) seems to be the best bet, especially because it also gives me a 30 day grace period when I pay my bill on time.I like the RBC Rewards Mastercard and have been using it since the fall of 2007. I also have the RBC Travel Rewards Mastercard but haven't been using it much since the introduction of the Aeroplan Plus Mastercard which is better for travellers.If you're interested in a card with a better perk selection, try the American Express Platinum Cards. They are only available to those who are able to qualify for a high limit account but they have a large list of perks. The current offer is 50,000 AMEX points when you spend a certain amount on the card within a set period.For a credit card with a low annual fee and good rewards you can also look at Capital One. They also offer a great rewards program and no annual fee on their no fee MasterCard. The sign up bonus is also very good - 10,000 Aeroplan miles for a $500 purchase in the first three months and then another 20,000 Aeroplan miles after $3000 in purchases in the next six months.I personally don't like American Express because I can't pay online, which means that I'd always have to write a check.With Capital One, if you use PayPal then you can always pay online.I don't think I could live with a high-limit account and a high credit limit either.It is not that easy to find a low cost credit card. What I always look for is an annual fee that is less than 3% of the credit limit. It will usually be about $30-$50 per year but that is the only way to ensure you get the best return.Most no-fee credit cards have such a low limit that the annual fee would be well over 10% of the limit.In the end, I'm more than happy to pay a $50 annual fee for the travel points. As long as I pay my bill on time and don't make any over-limit fees, I can still get the travel points and the extended grace period.I have an Amex AERO cards. This is a "travel rewards" card but you do have to redeem the points through AERO and you have to charge about $1,500 per month to get a decent amount of points back. The problem is that this card is difficult to qualify for. I got mine about 10 years ago, and I'm still happy with it.I have an American Express credit card and there are so many perks that go with it. I like the fact that I get extra points for every dollar spent and the card has no annual fees.It's nice to have a credit card with perks but sometimes I think I can be a little spoiled by them. I'm getting too used to my credit card rewards and I don't think about them as much.I just received the card in the mail and it's a nice card.My only complaint is that the annual fee is a little steep.I've had my TD Visa card for a while and so far I really like it. There are no fees and the interest rate is decent. I've never had any problems with the card.It's always good to look at different credit cards and compare what they offer. I'm always looking at my credit card and thinking about what the next perk or reward is. I like that. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'd really appreciate hearing what you believe is the best card out there. I'm always curious to know how my readers think.My recommendation is a little different from the usual. I would say the best overall is the Chase Freedom®. Here are my reasons for picking it as the best of all the travel credit cards.Chase has a 5/24 rule. This means if you have opened 5 or more credit cards in the last 24 months (from all banks) you will not get approved for a credit card from them, at least for a while. This means you may want to think twice about getting a Southwest card, as that might be your 6th one. The Chase Freedom is an excellent choice for those who want a no-annual-fee credit card.The Chase Freedom® offers 5% cash back on select spending categories that change every quarter (up to $1,500 per quarter). I believe you should try to focus your spending in these categories, because there is a chance you will spend more than $1,500 per quarter in that category, meaning that you will get 5% back on more than $1,500. That's a good thing.After spending $1,500 per quarter in 5% categories, your cash back earnings will drop to 1%. However, all purchases that you don't spend in the 5% categories will earn you 1% cash back. This is great. I can't think of a better program than this.All cash back is redeemed as a statement credit. You can do this any time. No hoops to jump through. Just choose your rewards and spend.The Chase Freedom® has a $0 annual fee. This card is also a no-annual-fee card. This is a really important feature. Credit cards should not cost you money.The Chase Freedom® comes with free access to more than 900+ airport lounges worldwide. With TSA Pre✓, you get to go through the security checkpoints with no need to remove your shoes, belt or take out your laptop. The Chase Freedom® is not an airline credit card, but it does come with free access to airport lounges.What about the other no-annual-fee cards? I feel the Chase Freedom® is superior to the Discover it® and the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card, though the Chase Freedom is not as good as the Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard®, which offers 5x points in the 2 spending categories that you choose (up to $50,000 in purchases per year). The Chase Freedom is better than the PenFed Pathfinder Rewards American Express® card, and it's definitely better than the PenFed Platinum Rewards Mastercard®, and the PenFed Premium Travel Rewards American Express® card.Now what about the Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard®? This is a better choice than the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card, and it's better than the Discover it®. It is also a better choice than the Chase Freedom®. The Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard® has a $0 annual fee, 1.8% back in all spending categories, and a 2% back in one bonus spending category (rotating quarterly). This is definitely a good choice.I don't want to compare the Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard® with the Chase Freedom®, because the Chase Freedom® is a no-annual-fee card. This is a better choice for people who want to avoid an annual fee.What about the Southwest Rapid Rewards® Premier Credit Card? I don't like the fact that you can't earn more than 3x points (12,000 points per year) on Southwest airfare purchases. I would have no problem getting 5% back on Southwest purchases (2,500 points per $1,000), but 3x seems to be the standard for airline credit cards.I feel the Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard® is better than the Southwest Rapid Rewards® Premier Credit Card. It's also better than the United MileagePlus® Club Card from Chase and the British Airways Visa® Signature Card.If you can only have one credit card, I think the Chase Freedom® is a good choice. You will get 5% back on spending in the rotating 5% bonus categories each quarter, and 1% back on all other spending. It has no annual fee. You can redeem cash back any time as a statement credit. The Chase Freedom® is good at airport lounges worldwide. I think it's the best no-annual-fee credit card on the market.I also have the Chase Freedom but I'm not sure it's the best of all cards... especially since I have the Barclay Arrival Plus and the American Express Platinum.If you use the Arrival Plus to pay for a flight that's not with the partner airline you're still getting a 2% return (3X). If you're using the Amex Platinum to pay for a flight that's not with the partner airline you're still getting 5X.But for most other spending I agree the Chase Freedom is one of the best cards to have.My take is that the Chase Freedom is the best all around card but the Amex Platinum is the best airline card.I would also add that you should definitely get the Chase Freedom if you don't already have 5 or more cards from Chase. I don't know of another no annual fee card that comes with this perk.I've already used my 5/24 rule so I'm hoping the Chase Freedom will let me have the Amex Platinum and the Chase Freedom.I do not have the Chase Sapphire Preferred so I cannot have that card and the Freedom. But I can still have the Freedom?And what if you already have a Chase Sapphire Preferred, a United card (since those also do not count) and a Marriott card? Would that still make me OK for the Freedom?I'm just trying to figure out if I can really have the Freedom, Platinum, and Preferred.Also, can you explain how you get the 5% rewards? I've never gotten more than 3x for flight on my Chase Sapphire Preferred and I haven't been able to figure out how to get the 5% back. Can you help me understand it better?I'm not really sure I understand what you are saying. Are you saying that you can't get the Chase Freedom card because you already have a Chase Sapphire Preferred card? I'm pretty sure you can get that card as well.I agree that it's a good card to get, but I disagree with it being the best overall. I'd say the best is the Platinum Card from American Express. If you're planning on paying $200 a year for a card, I'd suggest the Amex Platinum over the Chase Freedom (which is $0). And you'd earn 5X on airfare booked through AmexTravel.com instead of 5% back on the Chase Freedom.The best all around card is the Chase Sapphire Preferred (and Chase Freedom) in my opinion.I have both the Platinum and the Chase Freedom. But I use the Freedom far more often. It has no annual fee, and I have it because I want a no annual fee card. I would much rather pay $89 for the Chase Sapphire Preferred and not have an annual fee on either.I find it very hard to believe that you have both cards, but still use the Freedom more often. What do you mean you have both cards?Yes, the Chase Freedom® card is great because of the 5% bonus cash back categories. I love it. But you could get 2x in all spending categories by using the Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard®, so I wouldn't say that makes the Freedom the best card overall.I agree with you on the 5% bonus cash back categories. If you get the Barclaycard Arrival Plus® World Elite Mastercard®, you could get 2% cash back on all purchases. I would have no problem redeeming this as a statement credit.I do not have any idea what you mean. Are you saying that you have both cards, and still find it hard to believe you use the Freedom more often?How do you get 5% back? I've gotten 5% back on travel purchases in my bonus categories a few times but usually it's 3%. And since there are only 5 categories, there's always one that I don't care about. I'd love to get 5% back on everything!Also, I have the Platinum, Gold and Freedom. I have the Platinum for the 5x airfare purchases. The Gold for the 4x travel purchases and the Freedom for the 5% bonus categories.I think you misunderstood the question. I did not say "I find it hard to believe I use the Freedom more often", but "I find it hard to believe that you have both cards, but still use the Freedom more often".I'm sure you know what I mean. If you don't, I'll clarify. I have both the Freedom and the Arrival Plus. But I prefer to use the Freedom more often. I don't think it's hard to believe, since the 5% cash back bonus categories are the best thing about the Freedom.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I've tried out 30+ credit cards over the years, but my favorite one, by far, is the PenFed Power Cash Rewards Visa Signature Card. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.For many years, I had an American Express Blue Cash Preferred card that I used for gas and grocery purchases. I had a $200 grocery spending bonus, an annual $100 statement credit for Uber rides, and a 1.5% cash back on everything I purchased, including gas, groceries, and restaurants.I would get $300 worth of cash back every year from the grocery bonus and an additional $100 cash back from Uber, which totaled $400 in cash back.However, if you're interested in applying for one, the cash bonus for 2023 is now only $200, and it is limited to $6,000 in grocery store purchases each year, or $12,000 per calendar year. I believe that Amex will do the same for the Uber credit this year.This year, Capital One announced that it would boost the $300 cash bonus for the Spark Card to $450 for grocery store purchases, which is higher than what Amex is offering.However, Capital One will limit the bonus to $12,000 in grocery store purchases, compared to $6,000 at Amex.The Cash Back Card from Chase also increased the $200 cash bonus to $400, and it will only apply to up to $10,000 in grocery store purchases per calendar year. I used to use a Chase Sapphire Preferred Card, which has an excellent sign-up bonus and annual fee reimbursement, and I think it's still a good card. However, the Sapphire Preferred Card will only provide up to $250 in bonus cash for groceries.My Capital One Venture X card gives me a sign-up bonus of 75,000 miles for $4,000 in new purchases in the first three months after account opening.This is more than double the amount offered by Amex, which offers 50,000 points. This is also double what Chase is offering with the Sapphire Preferred Card and the Sapphire Reserve.While Capital One's card will give me more points for my grocery spending, Amex's sign-up bonus will give me more points for my travel.The Capital One Venture X will not give me bonus miles for groceries, nor will it give me a yearly credit to offset the cost of airline tickets.I also have the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card, which offers an annual $60 credit for any hotel stay booked through Chase.This is also a nice benefit for anyone who travels frequently.My Capital One Venture X card offers $100 in annual Uber Cash, as well as $300 in annual Capital One Travel credit.This card also offers 10x Capital One miles per dollar spent on hotels and rental cars booked through Capital One Travel. I believe this card provides the best combination of benefits and perks.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. You're likely to be a heavy user of at least one credit card in your lifetime, so it makes sense to make the choice that will best suit your needs in the long run.For some, it could be a card with a lot of extra perks, such as rewards points, airline miles, or cash back. Other card users are looking for the card that provides the most savings. Still others are concerned with getting the best rate possible on their debt.The best choice will depend on your priorities, your credit history, and the card offers that are available to you.A rewards card will earn you points for the purchases you make with it. These points are often redeemable for a variety of perks. It could be a free trip, a gift card, or even a cash back check. The amount of points needed to redeem will depend on your point's value.Some reward cards are issued through a bank, but most are issued through major credit card companies. Some of these cards are affiliated with airline companies, and other cards are issued with partners such as grocery stores.Some of the best rewards cards in the market are also some of the most expensive cards, because the banks and card companies will offset their costs by charging you more in interest than they charge someone who is paying off their bill every month.If you're going to get a rewards card, it's best to do your homework first. Find out what kind of points the card gives you, how much the points are worth, and what it takes to redeem those points. If you have poor credit, you may want to choose a rewards card that offers a secured credit card with a low interest rate and minimal fees.Some cards provide a great rate, but they also require that you pay off your bill every month. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.What's more, what's your current method of payment? Do you prefer to use your credit card to pay for large purchases? Or do you find yourself reaching for a debit card?This is important because if your answers are similar to many other people's, you may not realize that you're missing out on some valuable benefits.I personally find it incredibly convenient to use my debit card for everything. But that doesn't mean you should give up on credit cards.So, let's see what people are saying!What's the Best Credit Card for Your Lifestyle?If you use your credit card for everything, you may want to look for a card that offers cash back bonuses.In that case, one of the best credit cards you can get is the Citi® Double Cash Card. This card gives you an unlimited 1% cash back when you make purchases, and another 1% cash back when you pay the bill.The Citi Double Cash Card does have an annual fee of $0, so make sure you're confident in your spending habits before applying.As another alternative, consider applying for the Citi® / AAdvantage® Executive World Elite™ Mastercard®. This card gives you 20,000 bonus miles just for signing up, and up to 2 AAdvantage® bonus miles for every dollar you spend on eligible purchases made with your card.Finally, if you'd prefer a travel rewards credit card, I'd recommend the Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card. This card gives you 50,000 bonus points after spending $4,000 in the first three months.You can then redeem your bonus points for travel.If you're looking for more details on travel rewards credit cards, be sure to check out our recent post!If you're a heavy user of your credit card, you'll want to avoid paying an annual fee.Alternatively, you may find it more practical to pay your credit card bill with a debit card.If that's the case, I'd recommend the Discover It® Miles card. You can get 50,000 bonus miles after spending $3,000 in the first three months, and then redeem those miles for travel rewards.On top of that, you'll get 1.5X miles per dollar on all of your eligible purchases, which is significantly more than most other cards.For a low annual fee, the Discover It® Miles card is a great way to get more out of your credit card.If you're looking for a different kind of credit card that offers rewards, the Chase Freedom® gives you a $150 bonus after spending $500 in the first three months.In addition, the Chase Freedom® rewards you with $150 cash back for each year that you renew your account.This means that if you decide to apply for the Chase Freedom® card, you could get a total of $300 in bonus rewards.The Chase Freedom® is a great way to get extra money back when you use your credit card, and it's one of the best cards that you can get for a low annual fee.Finally, if you'd prefer a card that gives you more flexibility, you may want to apply for the Bank of America® Cash Rewards credit card. You can get 10% cash back on your first $3,000 in purchases each year.The Bank of America® Cash Rewards credit card is a great way to get extra money back when you use your credit card.If you're looking for the perfect card that matches your lifestyle, I think you'll love these options. Which card do you prefer? Let me know in the comments!</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.What Is A Credit Card Rewards Program?How Do You Choose A Credit Card Rewards Program?How Can You Save Money With A Credit Card Rewards Program?Credit cards offer a variety of benefits to consumers. Some are geared more towards the convenience of using a credit card instead of cash. Others are designed to reward customers for using their cards, such as airline miles or free hotel stays.There are many different rewards programs offered by credit card companies today, making it difficult for consumers to choose which one is best for them. This article will explore the benefits and drawbacks of each program so that you can make an informed decision about which rewards program is right for you.There are many different types of rewards programs available, but the most popular are those offered by major banks and airlines. These programs offer consumers points or miles that can be redeemed for travel, gift cards, or cash back.Some programs offer additional perks, such as free checked baggage or priority boarding on flights.The benefits of rewards programs vary depending on the type of program you choose. For example, if you choose a program that offers airline miles, you may be able to earn free tickets or upgrade your seat on a flight.If you choose a program that offers cash back, you may be able to receive a percentage of your purchase back in the form of a credit on your statement.Another consideration is how easy it is to redeem your rewards. Some programs require that you meet certain spending requirements before you can redeem your points or miles. Others may have a minimum redemption amount that must be met before you can receive your reward.The Best Credit Card Rewards ProgramIf you're looking for a credit card rewards program, you have many choices. The best card for you will depend on your needs and goals. For example, if you travel frequently, a travel rewards card may be a good option.Alternatively, if you're looking for a card with no annual fee, a cash back card may be a better fit. Consider your spending habits and lifestyle when choosing a rewards program. Then, compare cards to find the one that offers the best rewards for your needs.When choosing a rewards program, it is important to consider your credit score. Your credit score can impact the types of rewards that you are eligible for, as well as the interest rate that you will be charged on your balance.A higher credit score will qualify you for more valuable rewards and a lower interest rate, while a lower credit score may only allow you to receive lower-value rewards or higher interest rates. When comparing rewards programs, make sure to check both the rewards value and the interest rate to determine which one is the best fit for you.Choosing a Credit Card Rewards Program: What to Look ForIf you're looking for a credit card rewards program, there are a few things you should consider. The best rewards programs typically offer at least 1% cash back on all purchases, plus additional bonus rewards for specific types of spending.For example, some programs may give you 2% cash back on dining and entertainment purchases, or 3% cash back on travel expenses. It's important to read the fine print on any rewards program to make sure you understand what you'll need to do to earn those rewards.Some programs require you to spend a certain amount of money each month in order to qualify for the bonus rewards. Others may only offer the bonus rewards for specific types of purchases, such as airline tickets or hotel stays. It's important to read the fine print and make sure you understand what you'll need to do to earn those rewards.When comparing rewards programs, it's also important to compare the redemption options. Some programs require you to redeem your rewards for cash, while others may allow you to use your rewards towards travel expenses or merchandise purchases. It's important to read the fine print and make sure you understand what you'll need to do in order to redeem your rewards.Finally, it's important to consider the annual fee for each rewards program. Some programs may require a minimum spending requirement in order to avoid an annual fee, while others may charge a monthly fee. It's important to read the fine print and make sure you understand what you'll need to do in order to avoid an annual fee.When it comes to rewards, there are many options to choose from. Some people like to earn rewards for their spending, while others prefer to earn rewards for their travel. The best credit card rewards program for you will depend on your personal preferences.The Citi® Double Cash Card – 18 month BT offer is a great option for people who want to earn rewards for their spending. This card offers 1% cash back on all purchases, and an additional 1% cash back on purchases made at gas stations and restaurants.If you prefer to earn rewards for your travel, the American Express® Gold Card is a great option. This card offers 3% cash back on purchases made at restaurants, and 2% cash back on purchases made at gas stations and supermarkets.Ultimately, the best credit card rewards program for you will depend on your personal preferences. Consider your spending habits, and choose a card that offers rewards that fit your lifestyle.Credit cards can offer many benefits to consumers, including rewards points and cash back on purchases. To find the best credit card rewards program for you, it's important to compare offers from different banks.The Citi® Double Cash Card – 18 month BT offer is one of the best credit card rewards programs available, offering 18 months of 0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers. The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers 60,000 bonus points after you spend $4,000 on purchases in the first three months from account opening.The American Express® Gold Card offers 3X points at restaurants and 2X points at supermarkets. When choosing a rewards program, be sure to consider your spending habits and goals to find the best program for you.Credit card rewards programs can be a great way to earn free travel or cash back on your purchases. But it's important to choose a rewards program that offers the right type of rewards for your spending habits.Some programs offer airline miles, while others offer cash back or points that can be redeemed for gift cards. When choosing a rewards program, be sure to compare the rewards value and the redemption options to make sure you're getting the most out of your rewards.If you're looking for the best credit card rewards program, be sure to compare the different programs available and choose the one that offers the best value for your spending habits.When choosing a rewards program, it is important to compare the rewards offered by different banks and credit card companies. Some banks offer rewards that can be used for travel or cash back, while others offer rewards that can be used for merchandise or experiences.The best credit card rewards program will depend on your spending habits and preferences. If you prefer to travel, you may want to consider a bank that offers rewards that can be used for travel.If you prefer to earn cash back, you may want to consider a bank that offers rewards that can be used for cash back. Ultimately, the best credit card rewards program for you will depend on your individual preferences.Credit card rewards programs are a great way to earn rewards points that can be used towards travel or other purchases. However, it is important to know how to save money with a credit card rewards program before you sign up.One way to save money with a credit card rewards program is by taking advantage of bonus offers. Many credit card companies offer bonus points for spending a certain amount of money in a certain time period. For example, Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers 60,000 bonus points after you spend $4,000 on purchases in the first three months from account opening.Another way to save money with a credit card rewards program is by taking advantage of cash back offers. For example, Citi ThankYou Preferred Card offers 2X points at restaurants, gas stations, grocery stores and drugstores, plus earn 1 point for every $1 spent on all other purchases.When choosing a credit card rewards program, it is important to read the fine print to understand how the points and cash back are earned and redeemed. Some points are worth more than others, and some rewards programs have a limited time to use the points.Choosing a credit card rewards program that is right for you can be a challenge. Points? Miles? Cash back?-Redemption options: How do you redeem your rewards? Can you use them for travel, cash, or merchandise?-Sign-up bonus: What is the sign-up bonus for the program?-Annual fee: Does the program have an annual fee? If so, is it waived for the first year?-Introductory APR: Does the program offer an introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers? If so, for how long?-Foreign transaction fee: Does the program charge a foreign transaction fee? If so, how much is it?-Additional benefits: What additional benefits does the program offer, such as travel insurance or extended warranties?When choosing a rewards program, be sure to compare the programs based on these factors to find the best fit for your needs.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. As of now, the two cards that I have in my wallet are the Blue Cash Everyday Card from American Express and the Platinum Visa Card from Chase. The Blue Cash Everyday Card allows me to save 1.5% cash back on all purchases, and 6% cash back on up to $6,000 in combined grocery store and wholesale club purchases (such as Costco), 3% cash back at gas stations, and 1% cash back on all other purchases. The Platinum Visa Card offers a 0% introductory APR for 15 months on balance transfers and purchases, and has a $100 annual credit.Both credit cards are fantastic in their own ways. I would have a tough time choosing between the two of them because both cards have many great features, yet both cards also have drawbacks. It sounds like the best option for me would be to have two credit cards that both offer the best of both worlds, but unfortunately, such a card does not currently exist.Do you currently use one credit card exclusively? If so, what card do you use, and why do you believe that your card is the best option for you? If not, which card or credit cards do you use, and why do you like those cards?I currently have 4 credit cards. The main reason I have 4 is because I like the reward points that they each offer.First card - Capital One Platinum Rewards MasterCardThis card does not have an annual fee, and offers 1% cash back for every purchase that I make, which can be redeemed as gift cards for various retail stores. I use this card for groceries and any other purchases that I do not want to use my other cards for. The only drawback with this card is that there is a $0.50 fee for every ATM transaction that I use to get cash, and I find myself having to use my other credit cards to avoid paying that fee.Second card - PenFed Premium Travel Rewards MasterCardThis is the credit card that I use when I travel internationally. This card does not have an annual fee, and offers me the ability to earn 1.5% cash back on all purchases that I make. I do not use this card on a regular basis, but when I do use it, I can earn 1.5% cash back on all of my purchases while I am abroad.Third card - Capital One Venture Rewards Credit CardThis card is also the only credit card that I have that does not charge an annual fee. The main reason that I carry this card is because it allows me to earn 2 miles for every dollar that I spend on any type of purchase.Fourth card - Citibank Platinum Select World MasterCardI carry this card for the sign-up bonus that it offers, which is 50,000 bonus miles after I spend $3,000 during the first three months of having this card. This card also allows me to earn 50,000 bonus miles for making a single purchase at Best Buy or Bed Bath & Beyond during the first three months of having this card, so it offers some flexibility with the ways that I can earn miles on this card.My favorite feature of this card is the 0% introductory APR that it offers for purchases and balance transfers for 15 months, which is the longest 0% introductory APR that I have ever seen. I recently moved into a new house, and I wanted to use this card to make my home purchase with, because I will be able to save money if I do not have to make any monthly payments until the 0% introductory APR period ends.Overall, I find that each of the cards that I have works well for my purposes. The Capital One Platinum Rewards MasterCard is ideal for day-to-day purchases and is great when I need to use my credit card for a small purchase or a purchase that does not cost a lot of money. The Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card allows me to earn miles on all of my purchases, which makes it ideal for traveling, while the PenFed Premium Travel Rewards MasterCard allows me to earn miles on all of my international travel purchases. The Citibank Platinum Select World MasterCard allows me to save money on interest payments if I ever need to transfer a balance or make a large purchase that will take me several months to pay off.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The American Express Business Platinum Card is currently the most talked about business credit card and for good reason - it offers an incredibly high signup bonus and other great benefits.However, some other business credit cards are competing in this space as well. So, let's take a look at what each card offers and which one you should apply for in 2019.Let's start with a quick review of the American Express Business Platinum Card and how it compares with the rest of the field.You'll earn 50,000 bonus Membership Rewards points after spending $10,000 on purchases within the first 3 months. These points are worth $750 in travel or statement credit, according to The Points Guy.You'll earn 1.5 points for every dollar spent on select business purchases and 5 points for every dollar spent on flights and prepaid hotels booked through Amex Travel.You'll earn 1.5X points on purchases at US restaurants, US office supply stores, US purchases for shipping, US computer hardware stores, and on US purchases for advertising in select media.There's no annual fee the first year, then $595 thereafter.Your first year is eligible for an extended warranty of up to one year on warranties of three years or less. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I've been an avid user of my Chase Sapphire Preferred card for many years now, and I can't imagine using anything else. But my colleague, who writes for Forbes' Advisor and is a credit card expert, has some thoughts on the best card to choose for you based on your financial situation.Here's what he had to say:For people looking for a no-fee, low-interest-rate credit card to get them out of debt or put a dent in credit card debt, the Chase Slate card is tough to beat.The Chase Slate card has no annual fee and charges 13.99% interest for 15 months from when you open the account (that's 3.5 percentage points less than its nearest competitor, Discover It, which offers 17.24% interest for six months from account opening).After the initial 15 months, the APR climbs to a still-very-low 16.49% APR. That's a better deal than the Chase Sapphire Preferred card, which offers 16.49% APR from account opening (plus 19.99% for late payments) and the Citi Double Cash card, which charges 14.74% APR on balance transfers and 24.74% APR for cash advances.The card also has a low minimum-balance transfer amount of $15, which makes it easy to transfer $150 or $300 from a high-interest credit card account. Plus, there's a low late-payment penalty of up to $35.The Chase Slate card offers new cardholders a $0 intro balance transfer fee (then, 5% of each balance transfer; $5 minimum) and $0 intro foreign transaction fee (then, 3% of each transaction in U.S. dollars)."The Chase Slate card is a fantastic tool to help manage debt and stay in credit card good standing, but I would like to see the company increase its rewards to make it worth the annual fee," said NerdWallet writer Adam McCann. "The card earns two points per dollar spent on travel and dining, and one point per dollar on everything else. That's not a lot of value considering that other cards offer a higher return for everyday spending."Read the original article on DailyWorth. Copyright 2019. Follow DailyWorth on Twitter.SEE ALSO: A new survey found that people in these 10 US cities have the highest credit card debtMore: Credit Cards DailyWorth Debt</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. This is a common topic that's discussed amongst credit card enthusiasts and I'd love to know how your choice of card aligns with the best.Which Credit Card is Best for You?In case you're unfamiliar, I'll provide a quick breakdown of the three primary cards that I believe offer the most flexibility in terms of cash back perks, travel benefits, and low interest rates.Let's start with cash back. Most cash back credit cards fall into three general categories: those that offer flat rate cash back, those that offer rotating categories of cash back, and those that offer cash back for specific types of purchases. In the former group, you'll find cards like the Discover It, Citi Double Cash, and the Capital One Quicksilver. In the latter, you'll find the Chase Freedom Unlimited, Chase Freedom, Discover It, and the Chase Freedom Unlimited. And in the third group, you'll find cards like the Chase Sapphire Preferred and the Chase Sapphire Reserve.Next, let's talk travel. Some cards are specifically designed for travel rewards. These cards include the Chase Sapphire Preferred and the Chase Sapphire Reserve. Other cards allow for travel perks like reimbursements for trip cancellations, rental car insurance, and complimentary hotel upgrades. These cards include the Barclaycard Arrival Plus, the Citi Prestige, and the Capital One Venture Rewards.Finally, let's talk low interest rates. Most credit cards offer a low introductory interest rate on new purchases and balance transfers. This rate is often around 0% for the first year but could last anywhere from 6 months to 24 months. These low interest rates are ideal for carrying balances from one month to the next or paying down high interest debt.So which card is best? Well, that depends on your financial goals and the kinds of purchases you make. If you want the best combination of rewards and low interest rates, I'd recommend the Chase Sapphire Reserve (for the 2x perks and 50,000 bonus points), the Chase Sapphire Preferred (for 1x rewards and 50,000 bonus points), and the Citi Prestige (for $250 in travel credit). If you want a card with the best low interest rates and the ability to earn cash back, I'd recommend the Capital One Venture Rewards. And if you want a card with the best combination of cash back and travel rewards, I'd recommend the Chase Freedom Unlimited and the Chase Freedom (for $150 in travel credit).Ultimately, the best credit card is the one that fits your lifestyle and aligns with your financial goals. So take some time to think about what matters most to you, then compare the available options to find the card that meets your needs.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.To the best of my knowledge, the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card is the most popular, with its 2% rewards bonus and 20% discount at certain restaurants (including Chipotle) among the perks. The AMEX Gold Card, meanwhile, is very popular among people who enjoy luxury experiences, as they're often given an invitation to special Amex events and such. I haven't seen many folks talk about the Blue Cash Preferred Card, though - that one is one of my favorites. It's best for people who spend a lot on groceries and restaurants, and it's worth looking into.If you've been in the industry long enough, you'll recall that the CSPC was pretty awful when it launched in 2006. Back then, it was the only card offering a rewards bonus of 2%, so there was a mad rush of folks trying to apply, and they were denied by the thousands. Then, Chase pulled an amazing, unprecedented coup, by offering to resell the cards to those who'd been rejected. The result was a massive surge in the credit card market. This may be worth looking into as a strategy, if you're not getting approved for the Sapphire Preferred Card (although I'm not sure how it'd work now that Chase has raised its credit standards).Chase recently changed the terms and conditions on their travel and entertainment rewards card, the AMEX Platinum Card. Now, they're cutting out a few of the perks, including 12 months of free airline lounge access.Chase has notified those with the AMEX Platinum Card that they have until June 1 to take advantage of the free airline lounge access. After that, those who still have the card will be notified about the new, lower benefits, including the removal of the Global Entry/TSA Precheck credit.If you have this card, now's a great time to call Chase and cancel it. The lounge access alone is worth far more than the 50,000 Membership Rewards points you'd earn from closing it.The AMEX Platinum Card offers 12 months of complimentary lounge access. The card also comes with an exclusive concierge service, and it offers double Membership Rewards points on travel. The card itself, though, carries an annual fee of $450 (or $550 for the version with lounge access).To give you an idea of how valuable this card is, you'd have to earn 66,700 Membership Rewards points from spending on your card in the next 12 months in order to receive the full value of the $550 lounge access fee. You'd also have to spend $11,100 on travel in order to earn the same value.You might be able to save even more on this card if you call and cancel it. Just make sure you do so before you hit 12 months.If you're looking to sign up for an Amex card to boost your credit score, you might want to avoid signing up for the Blue Cash Preferred Card.When I applied for the Blue Cash Preferred Card last year, I was instantly rejected. According to some online forums, this has happened to others, too. If you're having the same issue, you can call in and ask for a personal loan from Amex, but I haven't heard if this actually works.</s>
