<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I think I have my answer, but I'd like to hear yours.I don't often find myself in the position to answer questions, but one I received the other day compelled me to do so.I think the credit card I mentioned in the question is the best in many ways, but it may not be best for everyone. There are several credit cards out there that are good for different reasons.It is the American Express Gold Card.First off, I think this card is a great choice for those who travel regularly and plan to earn Membership Rewards® Points.In order to earn the most points, you need to spend $5,000 in purchases on your card each calendar year, and you need to be traveling in the first and/or business class section of a flight.This means that, unless you are flying internationally first or business class, you won't be earning points at full capacity.Further, the points you earn can be redeemed for almost any type of travel, including flight tickets, hotel stays, car rentals, and more. The more points you accumulate, the more flexible they will be in terms of what type of travel you can book.The American Express Gold Card has a yearly fee of $175, which is a bit more than the average credit card.This card is only available for those who have a good to excellent credit score.If you are an eligible applicant and you meet the requirements, you will be able to earn one point for every $1 you spend.I don't think you should necessarily use your credit card to earn points. You should be careful to only use it to make purchases you would normally make. If you don't have a travel budget, it's best to set aside money for your trip.If you are not traveling often, the best option may be the American Express Everyday® Preferred Credit Card, which I'll discuss below.This is the only American Express card you can apply for without an invitation. However, it may be harder for those with a limited credit history or with a low credit score to qualify for.You can also earn one point for every $1 you spend, but you will need to spend $1,000 in purchases within the first three months.The downside to this card is that it only comes with two airport lounge accesses per year.The American Express® Green Card is a good choice for those who are not looking to earn Membership Rewards Points and want to save a bit of money while traveling.This card offers a welcome bonus of $100 for every $1,000 you spend in the first three months.You also earn one point for every $1 you spend, but your points do not expire if you are not traveling much.The downside to this card is that you may have a higher interest rate than other credit cards.I don't think the American Express® Green Card is the best choice for most people. I would recommend that you look for cards that offer better perks and lower interest rates, as they may help you pay less in the long run.This is the card that offers the best overall value.You'll earn 2 Membership Rewards® points for every $1 you spend on the card, and you can earn points in any airline or hotel.You can earn one point for every $1 you spend, and you will be able to redeem your points for airfare, hotel stays, and more.You will earn 1.5 points for every $1 you spend on your purchases.The American Express Gold Card has the lowest interest rate of any card.The American Express Gold Card is the best choice for anyone who is looking for the best value.I think that the Chase Sapphire Reserve® is the best overall card for most people.However, it may not be the best for those who are just starting out.The Chase Sapphire Reserve® offers a welcome bonus of $300 for every $4,000 you spend in the first three months.This is the only card that comes with an annual fee of $450.This is the only card that offers an introductory rate of 0% APR for the first 12 months.You'll earn two points for every $1 you spend on the card, but you will also earn one point for every $1 you spend in the first three months.You'll earn 1.5 points for every $1 you spend on the card.This is the only card that comes with travel benefits, which include a complimentary Delta SkyMiles® companion certificate and a $300 statement credit.The Chase Sapphire Reserve® has a lower interest rate than other cards. It is the best choice for those who are looking to earn points and save money while traveling.I think it is worth it to get a credit card that offers perks and low interest rates.I would recommend that you read my post, "What is a Good Credit Score," to learn more about how to use a credit card responsibly.In order to earn the best rewards possible, you need to be traveling in first and/or business class. If you are not, you can only earn a small amount of points.If you are traveling in the first and/or business class section of a flight, you will be able to earn points at the full capacity.You can also earn one point for every $1 you spend.The American Express Gold Card is the best choice for those who are looking for the best value.It has the lowest interest rate of any card and is the best choice for those who are just starting out.I think that the Chase Sapphire Reserve® is the best overall card for most people. It offers a welcome bonus of $300 for every $4,000 you spend in the first three months, and it comes with travel benefits, which include a complimentary Delta SkyMiles® companion certificate and a $300 statement credit.If you have any questions, please let me know in the comments. I'm always happy to help!How Much Cashback Can I Earn From Using My Credit Card?I have a lot of questions about how much cashback can I earn from using my credit card. I have a good credit score but don't travel very often. I've never used my credit card for travel but I am curious about the rewards.My Credit Card Is Charging Me A Lot More Interest Than Other Cards. Is This Normal?I am getting in trouble with credit cards and am wondering if I should stop using them all together. I have had a lot of issues with my credit card company. They keep charging me more interest than other companies, and now I don't know what to do about it.The best credit card for your needs depends on your credit history and what you use the card for.You should also look for a card with low interest rates, no annual fee, and great rewards.The best card for you is the one that works best for your needs.I've recently taken a look at my credit report and noticed that there are a few negative items on it. I've been trying to get them removed, but it's been hard. I'm not sure what to do.How Long Does A Credit Card Balance Transfer Take To Process?The time it takes for a balance transfer to process depends on the type of transfer and the type of credit card used.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What do you like most about your credit card?My personal favorite is the Barclaycard Arrival World MasterCard because it offers 5x the points on purchases made directly from the airline and hotel partners, 2x on other purchases and 1x everywhere else. And because it has no foreign transaction fee I use it in a variety of foreign countries. The card has also given me a great cash back on numerous occasions.It offers a low introductory interest rate (if you qualify), and the flexibility to use the points for any purchase you choose, and redeem them for travel. I would have to say I love my Chase Freedom Card for that reason. I can easily transfer my points to a variety of travel partners, and the points never expire.It's the first time I used a credit card online, and it was good, I like it. I'm happy with the Chase Freedom card for online purchases because I got 10,000 points in 3 months just from using the card for my purchases and paying my bill on time.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.You may be a credit card novice, which means you may have never applied for a credit card. If so, that's okay.I encourage you to consider getting a credit card, especially one that offers great perks and can be a credit builder to help you establish credit. I can't emphasize enough the importance of having credit. It helps you secure a loan when the time comes, as well as help you build a positive credit history.We've reviewed the best credit cards for the average consumer, as well as those who have a higher than average income and want more from their credit cards.So, in that spirit, I'll introduce you to the three credit cards I think are the best, as well as what you need to consider when choosing a credit card.Amazon has become the online retailer of choice for millions of consumers. The site has made shopping easy and provides a massive selection of products from all over the world.Amazon has its own Amazon Prime Rewards credit card that gives you the best perks when shopping with Amazon. If you're an avid Amazon user, consider getting this card. It allows you to earn 5% back on Amazon.com purchases, 2% back on gas, restaurants, and drugstores, and 1% on everything else.You will also enjoy free shipping for two days on purchases of $35 or more.You don't need to be an Amazon Prime member to get this credit card.Another perk of the Amazon Prime Rewards credit card is it has no foreign transaction fees.The card is issued by Chase.If you're a food lover, consider getting the Chase Sapphire Reserve. The Chase Sapphire Reserve gives you 3X points on travel and dining at restaurants and a 100,000 point sign-up bonus after you spend $4,000 within the first three months.This perk is only available if you spend $4,000 in the first three months. You also need to pay an annual fee of $450 each year.Chase Sapphire Reserve is also offering 50,000 bonus points if you spend $4,000 within the first three months. If you spend $10,000 within the first three months, you'll receive 100,000 bonus points.You'll also receive a free $300 credit for travel.If you prefer to shop at Macy's, you can get a credit card from Macy's and reap the benefits of the Macy's Star Rewards Credit Card.It has no annual fees.If you're wondering what other perks you'll enjoy, the card also gives you 2% cash back on purchases at Macy's, and 1% back on purchases at gas stations, department stores, and drugstores.If you're looking for a flexible credit card that gives you the freedom to pay for whatever you want, then consider the Wells Fargo Platinum Visa Card.This credit card is a great starter card if you don't have much credit.You also don't have to worry about any fees because it has no late fees, annual fees, or foreign transaction fees.This credit card can be a great tool to help you build credit. It reports to all three major credit bureaus (Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax).There are two credit cards that I don't recommend if you're trying to build credit. I recommend you avoid the Capital One Platinum and Blue Cash Everyday credit cards.If you're considering applying for these credit cards, you'll enjoy a $0 annual fee, a $0 balance transfer fee, and a $0 foreign transaction fee. But, you won't earn a high interest rate, and you won't receive any perks.There is no minimum credit score for any of these cards.When choosing a credit card, I recommend you read the terms of the offer. There may be things you won't like, such as a high APR or no rewards, for example.I encourage you to choose a credit card with a low APR. If you don't, it'll cost you more money in the long run. The APR will determine how much interest you'll pay, so the lower your APR, the less you'll have to pay.You should also consider what the card's credit limits are and how it affects you.If you know your credit score, make sure the credit card is within your credit limit.If it isn't, then you should consider getting a credit card with a higher limit.You may also want to check how much the interest rate is if you decide to carry a balance.When choosing a credit card, you should also know that you need to pay off your credit card bill in full each month.If you do this, you won't have to pay any interest.Also, you should avoid spending more money than you have. If you do, then you will start accruing interest.Don't forget that each time you swipe your card, you're charged a transaction fee. This fee can be as high as 3%.If you don't want to be charged the transaction fee, then choose a credit card with a low interest rate.Credit cards can be great tools to help you build credit and pay for things. You should carefully choose the best credit card that fits your needs and budget.What Credit Cards Do You Have?Which card do you have? Are there any perks you don't like? I'd love to know your feedback, so please leave a comment below.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Which one is it for you? Let us know below in the comments.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. If you ask me, there is one clear winner.According to the experts, there's one credit card that offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.This card is one of the best cashback rewards cards out there because of how much value it gives back to the consumer.The cash-back percentages are pretty low, but the way it allows you to customize the rewards is what makes this card unique.You can also get the 18-month 0% APR balance transfer and the no-fee FICO credit score tracker.The Chase Freedom Unlimited® is one of the best cashback rewards cards out there because of how much value it gives back to the consumer.According to NerdWallet, which is a free resource that provides consumer credit card and financial tools, the Freedom Unlimited® card stands out from the rest because of its $0 annual fee, 18-month 0% APR balance transfer offer, and no-fee FICO score tracker.I agree with NerdWallet's assessment that this card is one of the best because it offers such a great combination of features and rewards.Let's take a closer look at the perks, interest rates, and other details for the Chase Freedom Unlimited®.According to Business Insider, which is a business and finance news website, the Freedom Unlimited® is a cashback rewards card that gives you an unlimited 1.5% cash-back rate on all purchases you make.I think this is a great deal because the majority of cashback rewards cards come with certain restrictions on the type of purchases you can make.The Chase Freedom Unlimited® allows you to earn cashback rewards on any purchase you make. This means that no matter how much you spend, you will be rewarded for your spending habits.According to Forbes, which is a website that features a variety of business and finance articles, the Freedom Unlimited® has a 0% APR introductory period.This means that if you make a purchase with your card, you will not have to pay any interest for the first 18 months. This is a great feature because it can help you save money in the long run.According to CNBC, which is a business and finance news channel, the Chase Freedom Unlimited® also has a low interest rate.The rate on this card is currently 17.24%. This is a great interest rate because it is lower than many other credit cards out there.It also has a $0 annual fee, which is another great perk.The Chase Freedom Unlimited® has many other great features that make it stand out from the rest.For example, it offers a sign-up bonus of $150, a 0% intro APR for 18 months, and the ability to earn unlimited 1.5% cash back on all purchases you make.It also has a low interest rate and no annual fee. If you're looking for a great cashback rewards card, the Chase Freedom Unlimited® is definitely worth considering.I would recommend the Chase Freedom Unlimited® to anyone who is looking for a good cashback rewards card. It is a great option because of its low interest rate, no annual fee, and many other great perks.If you are considering getting this card, you can learn more by visiting the Chase Freedom Unlimited® homepage.Is the Chase Freedom Unlimited® the best credit card for you?No. There are many other great options out there.Maybe. It all depends on your individual needs.Maybe not. But you should still consider other options before making your decision.Yes. It is definitely one of the best cashback rewards cards out there.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I personally use the Discover It card because I am a student and can't pay my balance off each month but I would still like to earn rewards. They also have one of the best zero percent introductory rates I've seen so far (18 months.) The Citi Double Cash card and Citi Hilton HHonors also seem to be well received but I'd like to know more specifics on how their benefits compare.Any advice would be appreciated. I'm inexperienced with credit cards so please be gentle.This may or may not be helpful, but here is a link to an article on one of the popular credit card comparison sites. They have some pretty good tools for searching for the best cards for any given person.One thing to watch out for with the rewards credit cards is to not have it tied to too many recurring charges (like Netflix, etc.) which may keep you in credit card debt. I've found that I can just make one payment a month, or do a balance transfer if I need to and then get the card paid off.I use a rewards card because my wife is the one with the good credit and I'm not. I don't want to pay interest but I do like the rewards. My rewards have been less than ideal so I'm looking into the Discover card as well. I used to have a Capital One card. I liked it but when I got laid off, I didn't pay it on time. The next day they sent my credit rating plummeting by about 100 points. My rewards got eaten up when I paid the balance off but I was able to build my credit back up in time for me to get a loan to buy my house.Another thing to watch out for with some of these cards is the cash advance fee. For example, my Capital One card is only $10 to use it like a debit card, but there's an additional $5 if you take out cash.Yeah, I've looked at a lot of the rewards cards. I don't know if it's just marketing to get me to apply, but a lot of the terms are kind of misleading. I've seen a few with 15.99% APR and then the next line has 22.99% APR. A lot of the cash advance fees are pretty insane as well. I don't understand why they can't make the APR consistent across the board.I have the Citicard because I have a lot of experience with it and I know how to use it wisely. I have the Visa Gold because I get $400 in airline miles each year and the $1000 credit line that goes along with it. I just got the Discover IT because I found that the $500 credit line was a great amount for me to have to start my credit off right. I don't think I'll be able to apply for a real credit card until my score is higher.There's the Citibank Rewards Plus card. You earn 1 point per dollar spent, there's no annual fee, and there are no foreign transaction fees. Points are redeemable for cash back, gift cards, or travel. There are some pretty decent rewards (up to 3x points in some cases) and there's no balance transfer fee. There are also a ton of other great features that the website shows you.The Chase Freedom Visa card is also great. The current intro APR is 0% APR for 15 months on balance transfers and purchases. There's no balance transfer fee, no annual fee, and the current point rate is 1 point per dollar spent. The point rate also fluctuates monthly, so make sure you check the website before signing up.Also, if you have a Barclay's MasterCard, it may be worth keeping. I had one of these and it was my first "real" card. I used it all the time and never had an issue. It's not the best card out there, but it's definitely a good starter card.I'd love to get a Capital One card, but it looks like I have a hard time getting approved. I know it's not great to go on the phone with them, but I'm hoping it'll help my odds of getting approved for the Capital One 360. It's a solid card, with a nice feature set and competitive APR.A friend of mine has one, I don't know if I can go as far as saying he's been happy with it, but he's happy with it.Yeah, it seems like it's pretty solid. I haven't heard much about it though. I guess it's just not as advertised.I have one, I've been happy with it. It's a little more than the other cards, but that's about it.Thanks for the advice, everyone. I'm definitely keeping my eyes open for the Citicard, Visa Gold, and Discover cards. I've already gotten a Capital One card, but I don't think I have enough credit to qualify for their other products. I'm just looking for a way to build my credit, get some rewards, and keep my cash in the bank instead of having to pay off credit cards every month. I've been getting pretty good at the budgeting and managing my money side of things, but I need to step up the credit game.I've had the same credit cards as you for the last two years now. They're all great cards and I'm very happy with them.It really depends on what you're looking for. Capital One and Discover tend to have better rewards, but lower credit lines. I would say if you want the best rewards and credit lines, get the Citicard. If you want a low APR, get the Visa Gold. And if you want good rewards with a high credit line, get the Discover. But there are so many cards and options out there that it's hard to say which one is the best.I have the Barclaycard, the Citibank Rewards Plus, the Discover IT, and the Chase Freedom Visa. I use my Barclaycard the most, as I have a really high credit line on it and I'm able to make a lot of really big purchases.I also have the Citibank Rewards Plus and Discover IT, and I think I'm going to cancel my Citibank card. The Chase Freedom Visa card is also a good card, but it has a really high balance transfer fee. I've done it once, and it was really expensive.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.My best credit card is the Capital One Venture Rewards credit card. Capital One's 1.25% cash-back rate for everyday purchases is pretty much unbeatable (I just got $300 cash for a Capital One credit card purchase). I also love the fact that I can get a one-time bonus of 10,000 miles if I spend $2000 in the first three months (that's about $250 in cash).I've been really happy with my American Express Blue Sky credit card because it offers a zero percent balance transfer rate for the first six months of use. After that, I will have to decide whether or not to switch to a lower rate credit card or start paying interest on my balances.But I don't think that either of these credit cards is really the best option for me, because neither one offers any rewards for my everyday purchases. The best option for me would probably be something like a Barclaycard cashback card, which gives you $20 back on each $100 spent, but I've been a little afraid to use one of those because of the possible fees.What kind of credit card do you use and why do you think it's the best?The best combination of benefits is a Visa Platinum credit card from a credit union, which offers a 0% rate on purchases for up to 18 months and cash back rewards on gas and groceries.I think you should ask yourself these questions before you decide which card to choose:-What are my financial goals?-What is my budget?-How much do I pay in interest each month?-How much do I have saved up?A credit card that offers 0% APR may be the best option if you need to make a large purchase that you can't pay off right away. If you have a high balance, then it's probably better to go with a card that offers rewards for every dollar spent.What I like about the Capital One card is that it's pretty easy to earn rewards. The only thing I don't like about it is that there's no way to redeem them for cash back or travel points.The American Express Blue Cash Everyday card is a great choice if you want to earn cash back on your everyday purchases. The only thing I don't like about it is that there's no way to redeem rewards for gift cards or travel points.The best credit card is the one that best fits your lifestyle.If you travel often, then it makes sense to get a travel rewards card that gives you miles or points for every dollar you spend. If you want to earn cash back on your everyday purchases, then it makes sense to get a card that offers cash back rewards.The American Express Blue Cash Preferred card is the best choice if you want to earn cash back on your everyday purchases, but there's no way to redeem rewards for travel points or gift cards.My best credit card is the Discover card because it offers a low interest rate and no annual fee. Plus, it gives me 5% cash back on all purchases made through the website. I don't have any other credit cards, but I use this one for everything except gas and groceries. I just recently got a Capital One card and it's been great!I'm still using my Amex Blue Cash Preferred card. It has a low interest rate and no annual fee, plus it gives me 5% cash back on all purchases made through the website.The best credit card I've ever had was a Bank of America credit card. It offered a low interest rate, no annual fee, and it gave me 5% cash back on all purchases made through the website.I think the best credit card is the one that gives you the most benefits. For me, that's the Discover it Miles card because it has no annual fee, gives me 5% cash back on all purchases made through the website, and it's the only card that allows me to earn 2% cash back at gas stations and grocery stores.The best credit card is the one that offers the most perks.The best credit card is the one that fits your lifestyle and your budget.I use the Capital One Venture Rewards card because it offers a low interest rate, no annual fee, and it gives me 2 miles per dollar spent on all purchases made through the website.If you're looking for a good balance transfer offer, then I recommend the Discover it Miles card.The Capital One Venture Rewards card is the best credit card I've ever had because it offers a low interest rate, no annual fee, and it gives me 5% cash back on all purchases made through the website.I like my Capital One card because it offers a low interest rate, no annual fee, and it gives me 5% cash back on all purchases made through the website.What's the best credit card to get a 0% APR offer?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.My vote would go to the AMEX Hilton Honors American Express Surpass. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.A lot of credit cards are offering cash back on different purchases, like groceries or gas. Some of them offer points on travel or purchases at wholesale clubs like Costco or Sam's Club. Others allow you to earn more rewards in a certain category. If you spend a lot of money on restaurants, for example, a cash back card might not make sense for you because it would be hard to find a better deal elsewhere.Some people like to use their credit cards as debit cards when they don't have enough money in their checking account. They just pay off their monthly statement each month, so they never accrue any interest or fees.Others use their credit cards for emergencies, such as paying for an unexpected medical bill. They carry a balance on their card to cover the cost of the bill and then pay off the balance over time.The interest rate on a credit card is the percentage of your balance that you have to pay for borrowing money. This can be very high, especially if you have a bad credit history. The interest rate can vary from one company to another, so it is important to compare different cards before making your decision.The annual fee is the cost of owning the card. It may be a percentage of the total value of your balance, or it may be a flat fee. Annual fees vary by card and you can usually avoid them by paying off your balance each month.Cash back rewards are a common perk for many credit cards. Cash back programs allow you to earn a certain percentage of your purchases as cash, which can then be used to pay off your credit card balance or apply to other purchases. Cash back programs are generally offered on a tiered basis, with higher rewards earned for certain spending categories such as groceries and gas.A rewards program is a perk offered by many credit cards that allows you to earn rewards points or cash back on purchases. These rewards can be used to pay for future purchases or even put towards your balance.The best rewards program for you will depend on your spending habits and what you're looking for in a credit card. Some rewards programs offer more flexibility than others, so be sure to research the terms and conditions before signing up for one.Some of the most popular rewards programs include:Chase Sapphire Preferred: 3x points on travel and dining, 2x points on all other purchasesCapital One Venture Rewards: 2x points on travel and dining, 1.5x points on all other purchasesAir Canada Aeroplan: 2x miles on travel and dining, 1x mile on all other purchasesIf you're like most people, your credit card is your primary form of payment. But what happens when you lose your card? And how can you get it back?Losing your credit card can be a very frustrating experience. You might have trouble paying for things without it and may even have to cancel some of your plans. If you're lucky, you might find your lost card in a place you didn't expect. But what happens if you can't find it?The first thing to do is to call the customer service number on the back of your card. They will likely be able to help you get a new one or at least provide some information about where your old one was lost. You should also check with your bank or credit union if they offer replacement cards.If all else fails, there are other options available to you. For example, many stores offer their own branded cards that work similarly to Visa or Mastercard. These cards are typically issued by banks or credit unions and have their own unique perks and benefits.There are a few things to consider when choosing a credit card for a new cardholder:You should consider the type of credit card that you want. There are many different types of cards, including Visa, MasterCard, American Express, Discover, and Diner's Club.Some cards offer cash back rewards or travel benefits. Other cards may have an annual fee or a higher interest rate than other cards.You should also think about how much credit you have available. If you have a lot of credit available, you may want to choose a card that has no annual fee or low interest rates. If you don't have a lot of credit available, you may want to choose a card with an annual fee or higher interest rates so that you can use your credit more easily.Lastly, you should think about what type of rewards you want from your credit card. Some rewards programs offer cash back rewards or travel benefits. Others may have an annual fee or a higher interest rate than other cards.The best way to choose a credit card for a new cardholder is to do your research and ask for recommendations from friends and family members who have used the card before. You can also check out online reviews of different credit cards by reading them carefully and comparing them side-by-side before making a decision.Some cards are known for their customer service, while others have great rewards programs. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I've narrowed down some of the best credit cards available in 2019.The Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card is one of the best travel rewards credit cards on the market, offering 2x points on dining and travel purchases. These rewards can be redeemed for a wide range of travel and dining expenses. Plus, the card offers 0% APR on purchases for the first 12 months.The Ink Business Preferred℠ Credit Card is an excellent option for small business owners looking to maximize their rewards on travel and business purchases. The card offers 3x points on the first $150,000 spent in combined purchases of travel and office supplies each account year, along with a 0% intro APR on purchases for the first 12 months.The Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card is one of the best travel credit cards because it offers up to 100,000 bonus miles when you spend $5,000 on purchases within the first 3 months of account opening. The card offers an ongoing 2x miles per dollar spent, along with 0% APR on new purchases for the first 15 months.For those who want a cash-back card, the Chase Freedom Unlimited® offers a nice sign-up bonus and an intro APR for new purchases. You'll earn an additional 1.5% cash back on every purchase in your first year of account opening, plus 5% back on rotating categories each quarter up to $1,500 in combined purchases.The Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is a no-frills cash-back card. There's a bonus for new cardholders, but it's just $150 compared to the $100, $150, and $150 you could get with the above cards. The card also offers a nice intro APR on purchases for the first 15 months.While the Chase Sapphire Reserve® offers an enviable travel rewards program, it's definitely not for everyone. The annual fee is a hefty $450 and there's an upfront bonus you can earn with the card.In order to get the Chase Sapphire Reserve's 50,000 bonus points, you need to spend $4,000 on purchases within the first 3 months of account opening. While that's not a huge expense for some, it might be too much for others.The card's other perks include a $300 travel credit per year, the ability to transfer rewards to hotel and airline loyalty programs, and 3x points on travel and dining purchases.While there are many great credit cards available in 2019, it's important to remember that not all of them are right for you. Take your time to research your options before choosing a new credit card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.A couple of months ago, I wrote a story on the 10 best credit cards to get for college students. The article focused on cards that offer cash back, zero interest for a long time, and a large line of credit. While the piece received a good response, I know that most readers aren't college students or recent graduates.So I decided to take a different tack with today's article. I've decided to focus solely on the best credit cards for those who want to get the most bang for their buck. For example, I know that many of you value convenience above all else, and this article will explain the cards that give you that convenience and more. Others of you value cash back and rewards programs, and you'll learn about the best cards for that as well.All of the credit cards listed below have earned their spots by offering the best combination of convenience, flexibility, and rewards for consumers. If you're ready to put the time and effort into finding the best rewards card for your needs, then read on.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card is widely considered the best credit card on the market. Why? Because of its low interest rates, large welcome bonus, and numerous rewards programs.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card offers users a low interest rate of 14.24% (variable APR). For this reason alone, the card could be useful for consumers who are trying to pay off a big credit card balance but don't want to make a payment every month.The card's welcome bonus, which is 2x the number of points earned in the first three months of account opening, also contributes to its value. If you open the account with a $1,000 initial balance, then you'll have $2,000 worth of points after the first three months. These points can then be used for airfare, hotels, rental cars, and more.Finally, the card offers you three points for every dollar spent on travel and dining. It also gives you two points for every dollar spent on select entertainment and grocery purchases. To top it off, you'll earn one point for every dollar spent on other purchases.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card is the best credit card on the market because it gives you the largest return on your dollar.The Chase Freedom card is Chase's most widely available credit card. The main perk of the card is its high cash back rate. Chase gives you 5% cash back on purchases in specific categories for the first six months. These include:3% cash back on dining3% cash back on travel3% cash back on drugstore purchases3% cash back on popular streaming services3% cash back on fitness memberships and gyms3% cash back on home improvement stores3% cash back on popular online shopping sitesIf you spend just $2,000 in these categories for the first six months, then you'll get back $100 in cash. After those six months, you'll get 1% cash back in all of those categories. That's just 1.67% cash back, which is fairly standard. But if you add up the rates, then you'll get 18.67% cash back.The Chase Freedom card is the best cash back card on the market because it gives you the highest rate in select categories. If you want the best cash back possible, then this is the card to get.3. The Wells Fargo Cash Wise CardThe Wells Fargo Cash Wise Card is one of the best cash back cards on the market. The card offers a high 3% cash back rate on common purchases such as gas, groceries, and restaurants. It also gives you 1% cash back on all other purchases.The card's $100 sign-up bonus is a nice touch, too. And with the 0% introductory APR, you can save some money by not paying any interest charges on your purchases.Finally, there are no annual fees associated with the card. So it's a good deal in general, even if it doesn't offer the highest cash back rate.If you're looking for the best cash back card, then the Wells Fargo Cash Wise Card is the one for you.The American Express® Gold Card is a high-end credit card that offers a variety of perks to users. For starters, the card has a low annual fee of $250. It also offers a sign-up bonus of 50,000 Membership Rewards points, which are worth about $625 in cash or gift cards.But the real value of the American Express Gold Card comes from its ability to give you great cash back. For example, if you spend $2,000 on purchases each month, then you'll earn $250 in cash back. That's an effective annual rate of 5%.And if you make $5,000 worth of purchases in a month, then you'll earn $750 in cash back. That's an effective annual rate of 15%.Of course, there are some caveats to these rates. For example, you'll only earn 2x the amount of cash back on purchases made at restaurants, U.S. supermarkets, and certain other stores. And there's a $100 annual fee for the card.But overall, the American Express Gold Card is one of the best cash back cards on the market. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I've heard good things about Amex, but I think Chase's points are more useful. I'm just trying to gauge how the community feels about credit cards.I use CapitalOne Venture card and the Reward are pretty good, plus I don't have to pay any annual fees. The rate is lower than a lot of other cards too.You might want to consider checking with some of your local banks too. They may not be able to offer the bonuses or other perks that the bigger banks have, but it will be free of charge and will come in handy for emergency situations.Sky_e22I don't really care for credit cards but I have one because some stores and restaurants accept it and it's convenient. I prefer using my debit card because it's just too easy to rack up a huge amount of credit card debt.I currently use an Amex card but I'm looking to switch to a Chase card due to the better rewards program.I've had both Amex and Chase and the Chase is hands down better. Amex is pretty good if you want to build your credit up and Chase offers decent rewards if you use it responsibly. Chase is my personal recommendation.Most of the credit card companies do not allow cash back. Some do, but it's very hard to come by and they also take a large cut of the amount. You can always call the credit card company and ask, however, and see what they can do for you.I think that the Chase Sapphire is the best rewards card right now, especially if you travel. The rewards are really solid and the card allows you to travel pretty much anywhere in the world. It also helps to get some good perks as well as the ability to redeem for cash if you need to.I'm not really that interested in credit cards. It seems like you have to do a lot of research into each one and then there's no guarantee that it'll be right for you. I don't even have a credit card.I think it would be wise for everyone to look around for what card would fit their needs and budget. There are a lot of things to consider when choosing a credit card. I am currently with Amex and I love it. It's not the biggest company but they do have really good perks and rewards.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Are you looking to maximize your rewards or pay off your balance before you're charged interest?Personally, I'm not a big rewards guy. I like the idea of a low-interest card that doesn't charge foreign transaction fees, a low APR on my balance, and a good customer service. That's why I've used the Citi Diamond Preferred card for years. In case you're unfamiliar with the card, it has a 21-month promotional period and charges a 12.99% fixed APR. You must apply directly on the Citi site (see the link below) for the 21-month promotional period. It's also a pretty good option for anyone who's working on improving their credit score, since it only requires a credit score of 640+ to qualify. That being said, your application for the card will be denied if your credit score is lower than 640.The Citi Diamond Preferred Card charges an annual fee of $0 and does not allow you to transfer your balance from other credit card companies. That said, the card does allow you to transfer your balance from a Citi credit card. There is a 5% balance transfer fee (if you need a balance transfer, you will need to transfer to a card that doesn't charge a fee), but the card offers a low fixed interest rate (11.99% - 21.99%) and you can get a 21-month promotional period if you're approved. Citi also provides excellent customer service if you have any questions or need assistance with your balance. The company is a member of the Better Business Bureau and has an A+ rating. Additionally, the Citi Diamond Preferred card doesn't charge a foreign transaction fee, which can be useful if you're traveling abroad and need to make a purchase in a foreign currency. The company also offers an optional roadside assistance benefit. If you enroll, you can get help with lockout assistance, towing, emergency gasoline delivery, and other roadside assistance services. If you choose to apply for the Citi Diamond Preferred Card, you can do so here.While the Citi Diamond Preferred card is an excellent option, if you're looking for a credit card with rewards and perks, the Capital One Venture Rewards credit card might be more your style. The card offers unlimited 2 miles for every $1 spent on all purchases. As a Capital One cardholder, you can also take advantage of a bonus offer of 60,000 miles ($750 in travel), which is good for flights booked directly with the airline or through Capital One Travel. That's worth $750 in travel. Additionally, the card offers a $100 Amazon.com gift card after spending $1,000 in purchases in the first 3 months from account opening. The card has no foreign transaction fees, a 15.49% to 24.49% variable APR, and a low-to-average introductory APR of 0% on purchases for 15 months from the date of account opening. The card does charge a $0 annual fee, and the card does not allow balance transfers. You can enroll in automatic payments on the card to avoid interest on purchases, and you will earn rewards if you use the card abroad.The card comes with a $95 annual fee and requires a credit score of at least 670 to be approved for the card. While this card offers excellent perks and has a great signup bonus, it's important to note that the card does have a relatively high APR and an annual fee. If you choose to apply for the Capital One Venture Rewards card, you can do so here.While it's difficult to say which credit card is the best, I believe that the Citi Diamond Preferred card offers the best balance of low-interest rates, benefits, and rewards for the majority of consumers. If you're looking for a card with great rewards, you might want to consider a different card. That said, the Citi Diamond Preferred Card has many perks and features that make it an excellent option for consumers looking to rebuild their credit and pay off their balance before being charged interest.This is a sponsored post by CardRatings.com. The opinions are our own.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.The best credit card for you will depend on a number of factors, including your credit score, how much you plan on carrying a balance each month, how often you travel, and more.While the ideal rewards card can't be found in a single article, we hope you'll find a card that's worth your time.If you're looking for the best credit cards for rewards or cash back, you're in the right place. Plus, you'll earn unlimited 1% cash back on all other purchases.You can see rates and fees for the Chase Freedom Flex here.The Best Rewards Card for Airline MilesThere are tons of great rewards cards out there, but the best rewards card for airline miles is probably the American Express® Gold Card. This card offers 4X points at U.S. restaurants and U.S. supermarkets, as well as 3X points on flights booked directly with airlines or through Amex Travel.You can see rates and fees for the American Express Gold Card here.The Best Credit Card for GasThe U.S. Bank Cash+™ Visa® Card is one of the best gas credit cards because it offers 5% cash back on eligible gas purchases. Plus, you'll earn 2% cash back on dining and 1% cash back on all other purchases.The Best Credit Card for Cash BackIf you want the best cash back credit card, then the Capital One® Quicksilver® Cash Rewards Credit Card is a top choice. This card comes with no annual fee and offers 5% cash back in bonus categories that you activate.You can see rates and fees for the Discover it® Cash Back here.The Best No Annual Fee Credit CardThere are many no annual fee credit cards out there, but the Chase Freedom Unlimited® is one of the best. This card offers 1.5% cash back on all purchases and comes with no foreign transaction fees.The Best Cashback Rewards Card for Small BusinessesIf you're looking for the best rewards card for small businesses, then the Ink Business Preferred℠ Credit Card is a top choice. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.But even if you have your own favorites, it's also interesting to see how other people in the TPG community prioritize different features in the cards they carry. With that in mind, we asked on our Facebook page: What do you value most in a credit card?Related: What's Your Favorite Card? Vote NowThere was a healthy amount of diversity in the responses, but one theme rose above the rest: flexibility. Here are the top five most popular responses:"Flexibility — for me this means being able to transfer my points to another program, not just one," said Brian P. "The ability to choose where you want to redeem is critical in this era of program devaluations."Andrew H. added: "A high sign-up bonus without being restricted to a particular airline or hotel chain."Luis L. agreed: "I want to be able to redeem points with several different airlines and hotels. I do not want to be restricted to a single brand."Some also mentioned having options when redeeming points or making a purchase:"I value my flexibility. I use several credit cards that offer rewards that fit my lifestyle, including travel. I have to earn miles and points from airline, hotel and everyday use cards.""Flexibility and convenience. I have a few different cards, and I like to use the one that makes the most sense for each transaction.""I have the Chase Freedom, and I love that I have access to many different airline and hotel programs. Also, when traveling, I like to be able to use cash, pay with points or even transfer points to miles."And of course, a good rewards structure doesn't hurt, either."I want cash back and the ability to redeem it for gift cards," said Katherine H.Another person noted: "I look for a high rewards rate and points-earning structure."But even those two answers didn't sum up the community's answers. In fact, several other options were mentioned, including low APR, low fees, and ease of use.And we'll leave you with this thought from Randy H.: "For me, it's flexibility, but for the most part, the top features are a good cash-back card, a card with a good rewards structure, and a card that has low fees."</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.A little while ago, I wrote about credit cards for freelancers. There, I suggested three cards that provide strong protection for freelancers. I'm curious to know if the freelancers out there would choose any of those three cards or go for something else entirely. And I'm curious to hear from those of you with more traditional full-time jobs too. What card works best for you?Here are a few reasons why I think the Capital One Spark Cash card (from Capital One) is one of the best credit cards available right now:It offers a 2% cash back rate on purchases in a wide variety of categories and earns a flat 1% cash back rate on all other purchases.There's no annual fee.The Spark Cash card is flexible: You can choose to redeem your cash back as a statement credit to reduce your balance, as a check in the mail, or as a direct deposit to your bank account.With no foreign transaction fees, it's a great card to have if you travel abroad or buy from international companies.The card features an introductory rate on new purchases of 0% APR for 15 months.The card also features an introductory rate on balance transfers of 0% APR for 15 months.It's a very good card if you're building your credit or have average to above average credit. (Read more about the card's credit requirements here.)If you have good credit, the Capital One® Venture® Rewards Credit Card (from Capital One) is also worth a look. Like the Capital One Spark Cash card, it's a flexible card that lets you redeem your cash back as a statement credit or as a check in the mail. It also provides an introductory rate on balance transfers of 0% APR for 15 months.But the Venture Rewards Card's annual fee is $59. I don't think that fee is excessive, and you could redeem your cash back for travel through Capital One's travel site and earn double miles for flights purchased through the site. But, I do think the Spark Cash card provides the better value for your money if you don't travel a lot.Finally, if you'd like to have a card that lets you earn points for every purchase you make rather than cash back, I like the Chase Sapphire Preferred card. It's available to those with average to good credit and earns two points for every dollar you spend in a wide variety of categories. Those points are redeemable for gift cards or travel. Like the Capital One Spark Cash card, the Chase Sapphire Preferred card has an introductory interest rate of 0% APR for 15 months on new purchases.I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Let me know by leaving a comment below.Tagged: Credit Cards, best credit cards, cash back, low interest, points and miles, travel credit cards, Venture Rewards</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.While there is no single card that is best for everyone, there are a number of factors that should influence your decision. So I'll start by asking, "Do you have good or bad credit?"If you've got good credit, it's time to choose a card with a low interest rate and a big sign-up bonus, such as the Chase Freedom, BankAmericard, or USAA Cash Rewards card.You can also choose a card with low interest, such as the USAA or BankAmericard, and still get a generous sign-up bonus.If you're a bad credit risk, you'll want to choose a credit card with no annual fee and a high APR. The USAA Secured Card and Discover It Secured are two of the few such cards still available.These are just a few of the options you have available. Check out my credit card guide to learn more and to see cards that are right for you.Here's the story of how I chose my card, and what I'd do differently now.In college, I used a Citi card and a Discover it for all of my purchases. The Discover card offered no annual fee and I liked its 10% cashback on gas and groceries. The Discover card also came with no interest, which was important to me as a student.Over time, the Discover card started charging interest. The card also had a high penalty APR, meaning I'd have to pay 29.99% interest on any balance. I paid off this balance and then used the card occasionally.I continued with this pattern for several years. My FICO score was around 660. I'd apply for a credit card with a low interest rate and then stop using it. It took me a few years to graduate to my next card.I got my first credit card with a sign-up bonus. I was in my mid 20s and used it to build my credit. The card had an annual fee of $75, which I didn't mind paying since it had a 0% introductory interest rate.After about a year, the interest rate increased to 16.99%, and then again to 17.99%. At this point I began using it more frequently.My FICO score was around 670 and I got pre-approved for a BankAmericard with a 19.99% interest rate. This was a no-fee card with no sign-up bonus.About a year later, I was pre-approved for a Chase Freedom with a 21.99% interest rate and a $150 sign-up bonus.At the time I was thinking that the interest rate on the BankAmericard was low enough, so I switched.I used the Chase Freedom for the next few years.Over the course of my career, I've had a total of 15 credit cards. But the one that I've had the longest and have made my largest payments on is the BankAmericard.My FICO score is 714 now and I haven't applied for any new cards in years. I have been getting offers in the mail for cards with no annual fee and low interest rates. But for now I plan to stick with the same card.Do you have good or bad credit?If you've got good credit, it's time to choose a card with a low interest rate and a big sign-up bonus. There are many options, but here are some cards to consider.If you're a bad credit risk, you'll want to choose a credit card with no annual fee and a high APR. There are a few such cards still available, such as the USAA Secured Card and Discover It Secured.Whether you have good or bad credit, it's important to make a credit card choice that best meets your needs.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.My experience with credit cards has been an odd one. I've never really had a good relationship with them. In college, I always had one that I swore was going to be the one I could actually afford, so I would spend as much as I wanted on it. But, inevitably, I'd get a few hundred dollars in credit card bills and wouldn't be able to afford the interest rate on it.For the most part, I've tried to stay away from credit cards ever since. I've found other ways to get what I need without having to worry about how much I owe.However, as an adult, I've been considering getting a credit card again. It seems like the best option for me at the moment, as I don't have any credit cards right now and my spending habits are pretty decent. But which one should I get? I want something that has decent perks and low interest rates, but not so low that I can't afford the interest payments on it. I also don't want to be locked into a contract or anything like that.So what do you think? What credit card do you think is the best option for me?I have a credit card and I've been paying off the balance each month for years now. I've never had any problems with it. But I've been thinking about getting a different card with better benefits and lower interest rates, and I want to know what other people think.I'm wondering what you guys think about the current state of the credit card market. I think we've seen some interesting changes over the last couple of years, especially in the last few months. What do you think is going to happen next?If you've got a credit card, you've got something to worry about. In the past, credit cards were a way for people to borrow money, but now they're just a way to make purchases. And the way that people use them is changing. Credit cards are now more of a payment method than a borrowing tool.What does this mean for you? Well, if you're like most people, you probably have a credit card. If you don't, you should get one. But you need to be careful. Credit cards are becoming more expensive, and they're becoming more risky. That's why it's important to keep an eye on your credit score.This is where a good credit card monitoring service can come in handy. These services will keep an eye on your credit history and send you alerts if anything changes. They can also help you fix any problems with your credit card history, such as late payments or charges for items that you don't need.If you're interested in getting a credit card, there are a few things you should know. First, make sure you have a good credit score. Second, be careful about how you use your card. Last, use a good credit card monitoring service to keep an eye on your credit score and credit history.Best Restaurant Point Of Sale Software 2016</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.That being said, this doesn't have to be a one-size-fits-all question. I'd love to know what people like you use (and like) about each card. What makes you choose the card you choose? Are there any specific perks (i.e. sign-up bonus, cash-back, etc.) that make you choose this one card over others?Here's the official rules for this thread:1) One entry per day per person. You may only answer one question in the current thread. Once you do, the moderators will move the rest of your answers to the other thread.2) Do not create any duplicate threads on this topic. If there are two threads in the same section that are about the same thing, the thread that appears earlier will take precedence and will become the new official thread.3) Do not reply to any question with a question. That's what the reply button is for.4) Do not ask any questions in the thread (as opposed to answers to questions).5) Do not create a new thread on a new day for any reason. If you need to reply to a post that is already part of this thread, that's what the reply button is for.6) Do not post any images in this thread.7) Do not use ALL CAPS, bold, italics, or other methods to call attention to yourself in this thread. If you wish to highlight your answer, use the bold button on the toolbar (not the CAPS lock button).8) Do not edit any part of your answer after the first edit. Editing your post after the first edit may result in a warning or an infraction.9) Do not post multiple times in a row in this thread. If you need to reply to a post that is already part of this thread, that's what the reply button is for.I'll be the first.I use the Barclaycard Arrival Plus World MasterCard, mainly for its 2% cash-back. I use it for everything, and even to pay my rent. That cash-back is a no-brainer. There's nothing better than getting cash back for every dollar I spend. It's a no-fee card with great reviews, and it allows me to earn cash back in the form of miles to transfer to Delta, which I love.I also have the Capital One Venture Card, which I use on my car, house, and other stuff that's not groceries. I use the card I got from my bank for gas.So really, my answer is "the Arrival Plus and my other cards." But you asked for one card, so I said Arrival Plus. I can explain why I have so many cards in another post.My "one card" is the Citi Prestige card. I love the 4th night free when I book a 4-night or longer hotel stay with a Citi Prestige card (this benefit was just introduced earlier this year). And I get 5x points per dollar spent at the airport/airline lounges and on airline tickets. I have the 50k sign up bonus and got my first 25k rewards last month. This is the card that I'm planning on redeeming for an American Airlines flight next month (after transferring points to a British Airways card so that I can fly British Airways to Europe for 5k points per person).I also have the Discover IT (which I don't love because the 5% cash back isn't that great and the 1.5% cash back on everything else doesn't impress me much). But I like Discover's "freeze your credit report" function.As far as travel rewards cards, I have the Citi ThankYou Premier and Chase Sapphire Preferred cards, as well as the Barclaycard Arrival Plus and a no-fee Southwest card. But the Arrival Plus is the one card I use for everything.So many great answers in here!I'll play this game, too. My one card is the Chase Sapphire Preferred. I love that it has no foreign transaction fees and that it has a reasonable annual fee and a 20K point bonus. Plus the 2X points on travel and 1X points on everything else are hard to beat.The Discover IT card sounds like a great option, too. 5% on dining is really good. The Southwest card and no-fee Southwest card are also fantastic. My dad is going to be using the no-fee one for his next international trip, which will give me some bonus points.It's also interesting that several people use their bank cards for everything. My parents have the same approach. They get cash back from all their purchases through their bank, which is great!My current one card that I have now is the Citi Thank You Premier. Before that, I had the Citi Thank You Preferred. It's still a good card, especially for new cardholders. I got 10,000 bonus points when I signed up for the card and I used those points for a free two night stay at a Hyatt. I really like the Thank You Premier as a travel rewards card for two reasons:1. The 2X rewards on travel. This is one of the best aspects of the card.2. The 1.6X rewards on restaurants. I like the 1.6X rewards since my wife and I like to eat out.I had the Citi Thank You Preferred before and I loved that card. It was good for earning rewards, but I also liked that card because I got 5,000 bonus Thank You points when I made my first purchase on the card.One card that I would recommend is the Chase Sapphire Preferred. The only downside is that you don't get a sign-up bonus like the Citi cards, but it's still a great card.The Chase Sapphire Preferred has no foreign transaction fees and it's 2X rewards for travel. Plus, the rewards that you earn from this card can be redeemed for travel or for cash.I use a Chase Sapphire Preferred card, but it's not my "only" card. It's just one of the many cards that I have.I think the best travel rewards card is the Citi Thank You Premier or the Citi Thank You Preferred. The best rewards card that I have is the Capital One Venture.Chase Sapphire Preferred and United Mileage Plus Explorer are my current cards. I use the Sapphire Preferred for all of my everyday spending and travel. I've had it for about two months and I really like it. It has no annual fee and you get 50,000 Ultimate Rewards points for signing up. I used mine for a free night at a Sheraton in downtown Chicago. The United Explorer card is similar, but you have to spend at least $2,000 in the first three months. I plan on using it for traveling next year.I would also recommend the Capital One Venture card. I love that you can earn 2X miles for all your purchases and then transfer those miles to United Airlines and other partners. I have no other travel rewards card because I don't want to earn points on travel and I don't want to use a card just for travel. I'm happy using Venture for all of my non-travel purchases.I'll play this game, too. I have a Citi ThankYou Premier. I have a sign-up bonus of 20K points, but my main reason for getting the card was its no annual fee. I also like that I get 2X points on travel. I plan on using the card to pay for a cruise I'm taking in the fall. The 2X points on travel are great!I have the Barclaycard Arrival Plus World MasterCard. It's not my "one card," but it's still a good card and I like it. I get 2% cash back on all my purchases, plus I'm looking forward to a new sign-up bonus of 50K miles. The only reason that I didn't give this card my "one card" designation is that I only like it because of the 2% cash back and not the rewards, which aren't the best.My answer is the Citi Thank You Premier. It has no annual fee and it has the 2X rewards for travel. I've been getting 20K bonus points for opening up a new credit card, which is great. Plus, I have enough Thank You points for a round-trip flight anywhere.I also have the Capital One Venture card, which is good for 2X rewards for all my purchases. I also have the Discover It card, which is good for 5% cash back on dining. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What are your top choices?Personally I've always held a Gold Delta AmEx card. I'm not in the best financial standing, but it allows me to have free upgrades to Delta flights as long as I pay my bill on time, as well as free checked bags. The 20% off restaurants, car rentals, hotels is a big plus as well.I don't think I could have said it better. I'm 26 and just got my first credit card about 3 months ago. I used to think credit cards were bad, and even went so far as to avoid it because of the credit score thing, etc. It's all a bunch of fear mongering. If you don't like the way the cards work, don't get them. It's that simple. There's tons of great options out there, and no need to be in debt. I have a couple different credit cards, and use each card for different things. I've never been sucked into "debt" and I'm always paying off my cards when they come due, so it's not like I'm paying off interest. It's like using any other debit/credit card. Some places will charge you a % of the purchase on your CC, while others don't care. You just have to know which places don't care.If you don't want a credit card, just don't get one. I see a bunch of people who think a credit card is bad and they are. They are if you use them wrong. You don't have to have a credit card to get the rewards, points, etc. My mom used to go to the travel agents and get "travel points". So it's all about what you want and how you use it. It's not like we are going to get sucked into debt because we used a credit card for a few days in our life.Anyone who uses a credit card should know it's not the end of the world. The best cards are the ones that have 0% interest. That is how it's supposed to work. No interest for a year if you pay off your bill in full. I've been using cards since I was 19, and never had any problems. If you use them right you won't have any problems either. You need to know how to use them right.I have an AmEx Blue Cash Card which gives me 3% on groceries, and 2% on gas and department store purchases. I've held it for about 3 years, and it's paid itself off.I just recently upgraded to the AmEx Platinum Card.Both are from American Express.I would definitely go with a travel card. That is what I did and I am very happy with the choices and rewards.American Express seems to be very good if you travel for business or pleasure.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.A good credit card is one that provides you with cash back, rewards points, or other perks without hiking your interest rate or imposing other penalties on you.Because of these benefits, credit cards allow people to pay for everything from purchases of groceries and clothing to plane tickets and hotel rooms with an incomparable ease and convenience. In fact, many people would argue that they're the very best payment method to use for a wide variety of goods and services.What is the best credit card?The best credit card for you will depend on your needs and goals. If you're a frequent traveler, for example, then a card that provides you with miles or points could be ideal for you. If you're more focused on getting cash back on your purchases, then it makes more sense to get a card that offers you cash back for every dollar you spend.But perhaps the most important thing to keep in mind is that when you apply for a new credit card, you should consider your credit score and your credit history before deciding to do so.It's especially important to pay off your credit card balances in full each month, so you don't pay more in interest fees than you can afford. A credit card that offers 0% interest on balance transfers can also be a great option for someone who wants to consolidate their debt and get out of it.If you have a strong credit history, then applying for a new credit card can be a great way to take advantage of all the perks that come with it, such as cash back or miles on your purchases. The key, as mentioned before, is to do your research and select a card that offers the benefits that you want at a rate and annual fee that you can afford.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What credit card would you use if you could use any one credit card in the world? Here are some of the reasons I like certain cards. What are your favorite credit card features?My choice is The Blue Cash from American Express. This card has a $0 annual fee, no late fees, no international fees, no penalty APR, and an introductory interest rate of 0%. If I carry a balance, that's the rate I pay. I can get 3% cash back at supermarkets (where I do 95% of my shopping), 2% back at gas stations and department stores, and 1% back on everything else. There's also no limit on the cash back I can earn. I could buy a car with this card. It offers the best financial flexibility of any card on the market today.How about you? What's your favorite credit card?</s>

In the end, you have to decide which features of a credit card are most important to you.Best Business Card for Food Service IndustryBest Business Credit Card for Fair to Excellent CreditWhat are the best small business credit cards?The best small business credit cards for 2023Small business credit cards can be a helpful tool for managing cash flow and expenses for small businesses. The right small business credit card can be a valuable financial tool to manage and grow your business.How to Choose a Small Business Credit CardA small business credit card can be an efficient way to manage cash flow and expenses, but the process of choosing the best one can be a challenge. The following tips can help you select the best card for your small business needs:Find a card that earns rewards on business-related purchases and provides cash back or a low-interest rate on all purchases. Some small business credit cards earn higher rewards in specific categories, such as office supplies or travel, while others earn bonus rewards on all spending. Some cards provide a fixed introductory APR on balance transfers and new purchases, while others offer an ongoing low interest rate on balance transfers.You may be required to meet certain minimum credit score requirements in order to qualify for a card with an introductory APR, or the introductory APR may not be available if your credit score is below a certain level.Avoid cards that charge an annual fee or a foreign transaction fee. Many small business credit cards are free of both fees.Be wary of annual fees and high interest rates. Although many small business credit cards are free to use, others may charge annual fees. Some business credit cards also charge higher interest rates than regular credit cards, especially for those with poor credit.Consider whether you need to redeem your rewards for cash back or gift cards, and compare the rewards rates of different cards.Business Credit Cards with Low Interest RatesBusiness Credit Cards with No Annual FeeBusiness Credit Cards with No Foreign Transaction FeesIn recent years, the rise of online shopping has increased demand for businesses to offer online payment options. For this reason, many small business credit cards offer extra benefits and perks when shopping online, such as price protection, travel accident insurance, extended warranty protection and purchase protection. If you use your credit card to pay for an item online, you may be able to get help if the item is damaged or defective.For example, the Capital One® Spark® Miles for Business offers up to $10,000 in protection for eligible items purchased within the first 60 days of card ownership.
