<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Personally, I'm in a great situation right now. I've gotten a low interest credit card that I've only used to make purchases on. I pay it off every single month. So, it's a bit of a no-brainer. I have no interest in the perks. I have no interest in getting the lowest interest rate. I've got a 36 month car loan that I'm currently paying off with a balance transfer.I have a second credit card which I've had for almost 5 years and which I still have no balance on. I haven't even been using it to buy things, but it does give me about $250 in rewards to spend each year at Christmas and on other special occasions.So, I'm curious if any of you have any other advice or opinions?My recommendation: Use your lowest interest credit card for the purchases you need to make that you know you will pay off in 1-2 months. You'll pay interest on the balance, but it will be the least amount you'll pay.Then, have another card you use if you need to charge something and the lowest interest card isn't an option for some reason.Your credit is good enough to qualify for a lot of credit cards. You can use this as a way to start shopping around. See which cards give you the most rewards or perks for the money you spend on the cards. You don't have to sign up for every card, though. Just sign up for a few cards, test them out, and see which ones work for you.I would just like to say, I'm surprised there was no one who recommended not carrying a balance. Even the lowest rate credit card carries fees, interest, and other charges that can outweigh any benefits that the card offers. Paying it off in full each month and you get free money for your purchases. No interest rates, no fees, no payments.I don't carry a balance. I never have and never will.I have 3 credit cards. 2 are for purchases, 1 is to earn rewards. The 2 cards I use to make purchases are low rate/low fee/low payments.My 3rd card is for rewards. I charge my phone bill to that card, plus any gas I buy, and other little things. That way, I can earn rewards. The rewards I've earned have been better than my reward accounts at the bank. It has been worthwhile.I don't know about the OP, but I would guess that he/she is trying to keep good credit. The only way to do that is to not let your balances get out of hand. If you only use your cards once or twice a year, then your credit is not affected. Also, I believe that by keeping your credit usage low, you will be eligible for better interest rates on loans. That is a biggy to me.I use a credit card to pay my rent once a month. I pay it off in full, so I get free rent.I use it to pay my bills. I pay it off in full.I use it to buy things. When I buy things, I pay it off in full.So I have no balances, so I have no interest, and no fees.I don't have to carry cash around to buy things. I can buy things anywhere in the world, and pay for them when I get home.I have a rewards credit card.Whenever I am paying with cash, I can get back rewards. I can also save money by not buying things from places that do not accept credit cards.I have a few credit cards. I pay them off monthly, so I have no debt.The only time I use one is to buy something at a store that I want to get points on or to get cash back.There's no downside to using credit cards, just like there's no downside to driving a car. The difference between the two is, if you drive a car and you run out of money, you could die, but if you use a credit card and you run out of money, you'll just get a phone call asking for it back.I have 2 cards. I use one for groceries, the other for gas.You can't go wrong with either, they are both excellent credit cards.I get the perks and points on the first and the low interest on the second.I don't think there's any right or wrong with credit cards. I've heard people say it's bad to use one if you can't pay it off in full each month, but I don't think that's necessarily true. It can be a good thing for you if you don't use credit cards at all. It sounds like the OP is doing a good job.Credit cards are a necessary evil. Without them, it is virtually impossible to rent a car or to buy an airplane ticket. So you need one to do those things, and you are stuck with paying interest and a high annual fee for the "privilege" of doing so.I do not use a credit card to make purchases. I use a debit card for that.Credit cards are just one more reason why the US is drowning in debt.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.My current situation is as follows:- I pay 0.9% interest- I'm on the cash-back plan- My credit is super strongI'd like to get a new card that I can use to re-build credit for my sister-in-law. However, the last thing I need is to be paying a lot of interest. Any thoughts?I have a similar situation except that I'm on the reward plan. I am looking for a new card as well.I'd like to hear other ideas.We have the Amex Platinum with 100K bonus points but no rewards points, just airline miles. I don't like the idea of being in debt with the airline companies since they all go out of business. I have heard that Chase has great rewards cards. Does anyone know which card to go for?Thanks in advance for all your input.Chase Freedom card. Earn 5% cash back in rotating categories. There is a 3 month wait before you can get another card so the sign up bonus is $100.I have one. It's the "blue" one that says "Chase Freedom" on the front.How long have you been waiting? I haven't been able to get one since 2005, but that's because I just haven't been in a good financial position to qualify. If you're able to get it, I'd say it's a really nice card to have.I had the Platinum Chase card and had great service from them.The best card is the US Air Card that you get with Air MilesI've been waiting to get another AmEx card for a few months.I know that there is a 3-month waiting period before you can get another AmEx card. However, what I'm curious about is whether the 3 months starts from the day that you cancelled your last card or the day you applied for the new card.I cancelled my last card about 2 months ago and have been thinking of applying for a new card. I'd love to get a new AmEx card but am worried about being blacklisted by AmEx if I apply for a new card too soon.I'm not an AmEx user, but I think the blacklisting you fear is called the 2/4/6 rule. I'm not sure what the penalty is if you go over 4 cards per 12 months, but that's where it starts.My husband has the AmEx Blue and has for many years. I haven't looked into all the details, but I do know that they have a higher approval rate for women than men. I think it may also have to do with your age and other factors. He's 40 and they're always happy to give him a new card.In my own opinion, I would rather go with a credit union than with Chase. You can get really great rewards from credit unions and I've had much better luck with them then Chase.Anyways, I'd just look into different credit unions. Maybe your bank has a credit union affiliation.I had a Chase credit card for quite some time before switching to a Credit Union a few years back. I have a few different cards now and they all give cash back or rewards for gas purchases or airline miles (or both).The cash back is automatic every month and it comes in the form of a debit to my checking account. You can check the balance of your reward points online anytime. If you're on the cash back plan, then every 2 months you should get a statement on how much cash you have back in your account.I've never had to call customer service since I've had the card. They have online chat, but I haven't used it.I've gotten better interest rates and rewards from Credit Unions.I have a cash back card that gives 1% on everything. I get 3% on groceries, gas and drug stores, so that makes it 4%.But it was Chase and they had some type of promotion where they increased the cash back from 1.5% to 2% for 6 months.The thing I don't like about cash back cards is that the interest is low. But I guess it works for me because I pay the entire thing off every month.I would definitely avoid American Express if you want to have good credit because they will limit you to 3 cards per year (2 if you're under 30 I think). If you don't know what it's like to have a lot of credit, then you won't understand the impact this will have on your credit score.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.As many of you know, I'm quite enthusiastic about the benefits of the Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card. The card has been in my wallet for many years, and its $95 annual fee is well worth the annual travel rewards and perks.In this post, I'd like to compare the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card to two other credit cards that I consider as my top choices for an "everyday" credit card: the Bank of America Premium Rewards Card and the Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card.Although I'll try to provide as much insight as possible, keep in mind that I'm in no way a financial advisor. I'm just an enthusiastic traveler who's always looking for the best way to get the most out of every travel dollar.Without further ado, let's take a closer look at these three credit cards.If you're not familiar with the Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card, let me tell you a little bit about it.The card offers two types of rewards points:- Chase Ultimate Rewards- Chase Sapphire Preferred Travel PointsThese points can then be redeemed for travel at 1.25 cents per point on airfare, 1 cent per point on hotels, and 0.8 cents per point on everything else. For example, if you redeem 20,000 Chase Ultimate Rewards points for airfare, you'll receive a $250 airline travel statement credit.In addition to the travel rewards, you'll earn two points per dollar spent on travel and dining (2 points per $1 spent), one point per dollar spent on all other purchases (1 point per $1 spent), and earn $500 as a sign-up bonus once you spend $4,000 within three months of opening your account.As for the annual fee, you'll need to pay $95 each year.The Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card is another excellent card to consider. In addition to the $95 annual fee, you'll receive a $100 sign-up bonus once you spend $3,000 within three months of opening your account.The card's primary rewards program is called Capital One Miles, and you can redeem your miles in several ways. First, you can use the Capital One Miles program to book airfare and hotels at a rate of 0.7 cents per mile (1 cent per mile in Canada). Alternatively, you can transfer your miles to any of Capital One's more than 20 travel partners. For example, you can transfer your miles to Singapore Airlines KrisFlyer at a rate of 1.3 miles per dollar (2 miles per dollar in Canada).While I like to use the Capital One Miles program to book airfare and hotels, I typically transfer my miles to Singapore Airlines KrisFlyer to earn the maximum amount of miles. If I were to book a Singapore Airlines flight, for example, the cost of my flight could range from 50,000 miles to 110,000 miles. For example, I recently paid $4,043 for a round-trip business-class ticket to Japan, and I only needed 55,000 miles to complete the purchase.Capital One Venture Rewards Cardholders Can Earn Extra MilesAs a Capital One Venture Rewards Cardholder, you can earn extra miles on every purchase. For example, if you were to make $10,000 in purchases during the first year, you'd receive a 20,000-mile bonus, bringing your total rewards to 20,000 miles (the $10,000 in purchases includes the $3,000 sign-up bonus, so you'll actually be receiving 23,000 miles).As you can see, the Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card offers a lot of flexibility in terms of redeeming miles and transferring miles to different airlines. I like this flexibility because I enjoy using my miles to book flights and hotels when it's most convenient for me, not just when it's most convenient for Capital One.Alternatively, you can also cash in your miles with a statement credit. For example, if you have 20,000 Capital One Miles, you'll receive a $200 statement credit.I find this feature especially valuable because you don't have to worry about your rewards being devalued or limited in any way. I'd rather have the flexibility of choosing how I want to use my miles.Now that we've talked about some of the Capital One Venture Rewards Card's unique features, let's move on to the Bank of America Premium Rewards Card.The Bank of America Premium Rewards Card offers some pretty amazing perks for its $95 annual fee.The card offers two different rewards programs:- Bank of America Cash Rewards- Bank of America Travel Rewards- 3% cash back on gas purchases, 2% cash back at grocery stores, and 1% cash back on all other purchases (on the first $1,500 in purchases every quarter)- 25% boost to the value of Bank of America Travel Rewards (capped at 3.5% cash back)The Bank of America Premium Rewards Card also offers two bonus options:- $200 in cash rewards when you make at least $500 in purchases during the first 90 days of opening your account- $100 in cash rewards when you make at least $2,000 in purchases during the first 90 days of opening your accountThe card offers a 0% APR promotion, and it comes with the same security benefits as the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card.Finally, the Bank of America Premium Rewards Card offers $100 in airline credits, and you'll receive an additional $100 credit if you use the card to pay for your airline tickets through Bank of America's preferred partners.The Bank of America Premium Rewards Card offers a ton of great perks for its annual fee, and I'm very impressed with how much value the card offers. However, I don't think the card is right for me.Why? Because I prefer the flexibility of the Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card's rewards program, and I don't like having to transfer miles to other airlines.However, this card is perfect for someone who is a Bank of America customer and likes to travel a lot.Bank of America is an excellent credit card for people who like to travel, and the $100 annual travel credit makes it even more attractive.Now that we've talked about the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card, Capital One Venture Rewards Card, and Bank of America Premium Rewards Card, let's talk about my favorite credit card.I have many cards in my wallet, but none are more versatile than the Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card. I love the card's flexibility, and I especially like how I can earn unlimited travel rewards without worrying about devaluation.The Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card also offers $95 in annual credits, and I love how I can use those credits to offset the cost of my travel expenses. For example, I recently used the credit to cover the cost of my hotel room, which saved me a lot of money.Finally, the card offers a ton of travel benefits, including travel insurance, trip protection, and a 24-hour customer service number. The Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card is definitely my favorite travel card, and I don't see myself ever changing my mind.So, what's your favorite credit card? Is it the Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card? The Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card? The Bank of America Premium Rewards Card? Let me know in the comments below!</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm also curious to know what you would tell a friend who was looking for a new credit card, and what you look for in a credit card.My card of choice: The American Express Gold Card.I signed up for the American Express Gold card after reading a lot of good things about it on websites like Huffington Post and Business Insider. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Best perks: American Express Black card.Best low interest rates: Capital One VentureOne card.Best flexibility: Capital One Spark Miles card.Capital One VentureOne Rewards Credit CardBest perks: American Express® Gold Card.Best low interest rates: Citi® Double Cash Card.Best flexibility: Citi® Double Cash Card.How we chose the best credit cardsIn order to make this list, we only considered the credit cards with the best overall combination of benefits and perks for a particular card type. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm currently looking at a few options including the following:1. Citi Prestige - 3x airline miles on all purchases2. Amex Platinum (or the regular Amex) - 5x points at restaurants3. BNY MasterCard - 5% cash back at gas stations4. Discover More - Double Cash back, up to $2,000I appreciate any comments and insight, particularly regarding the value of the various offers. Also, do you find the perks offered by cards (i.e., $100 TSA fee credit) to be valuable?Find More Posts by nlittleCiti Platinum. The $300 credit for airfare is great, and the 5x is great. I don't know how many years I'll actually use the benefit, but I think the chance that I'll ever get there is high enough that I don't feel bad about having it.The 3x for airfare isn't a huge deal for me because I usually book the cheapest ticket that doesn't have stopovers or a crazy layover. I just don't travel enough to take advantage of that much.Amex is a great card, but it's not great for my spending habits. I don't eat out nearly enough to make the extra 5x points worthwhile. I also don't fly enough to make the 5x for travel worthwhile.BNY isn't available for me, and I don't have a Discover card, so I can't speak to them.I don't use the free TSA credit, but I think it's awesome that it exists.Citibank/AAdvantage Platinum CardAmex Platinum or BofA Platinum Honors Rewards (if 5% back is worth anything)Discover More (if you actually use your Discover card)Find More Posts by bhk11Originally Posted by nlittleAs someone else who is on the fence between two of these, I'd also love to hear what folks think. My biggest concerns are 1) the 5X points at restaurants (vs. 5x at hotels which is what most of my spending goes to), and 2) if I can really use the $300 airfare credit (i.e. on things like taxes, etc...).For me, if I end up getting the Amex, I might be able to switch my Chase Marriott card (2x at Marriott) to this so I end up with 4x at Marriott (and the ability to do transfers to United).Find More Posts by the.beavI had a Chase Sapphire Preferred and used it for airfare and hotels. I had a $300 credit per year, which I had to be a little strategic about. It took me a while to use up the entire credit. I was able to use it on car rentals and taxes and fees, etc. For me, I'd say it was the best credit card I've ever had. But I'm not sure if that was because of the Chase Sapphire Preferred or the Chase Ultimate Rewards system in general.I'm not super into points and miles (not because I don't like to travel, but because I don't like having to worry about how much something costs) so I don't know how it works in the "reward" world.Originally Posted by bhk11This would be my choice as well. I know I'll be able to use the annual fee credit for at least two round trip flights.The Chase Ultimate Rewards is the most flexible program around. I'm not really familiar with Discover's system, but I know that if you transfer to a major alliance program, you will be able to use your points to book a flight (i.e. AA, BA, US, etc.).My biggest concerns are 1) the 5X points at restaurants (vs. 5x at hotels which is what most of my spending goes to), and 2) if I can really use the $300 airfare credit (i.e. on things like taxes, etc...).I'm assuming that you are getting the Citi / AAdvantage Platinum card, and not the Citi Prestige (with the travel credit). I think that 5x at restaurants is really valuable, so I would say that it is worth it, regardless of how much you actually eat out.The airfare credit doesn't really work for me. When I fly, I have to go through a couple of credit cards before I pay for anything, and I almost never pay for a flight outright. I always have to pay for taxes and fees with the airline website or by telephone. I had to use the credit once and got $30 off, which didn't even cover the taxes on my flight. I'm planning on canceling the card before the annual fee is due next summer, just so I don't have to figure out what to use the credit for.I have a different BofA card that I use for most purchases (the BofA Platinum Honors Rewards card, which has 5x points at groceries and 2x at restaurants). This is also a really good card. If I need to use an airline credit, I'll use the BofA Platinum Honors card, since I get so many more points. I find that I really enjoy earning points. I don't care much about how many points I get for a specific purchase, but I really enjoy knowing that I'm getting something in return for what I spend. It gives me more of a sense of control.I'm probably not the right person to ask, as I have never used this card. If you are interested in it, I would recommend searching for opinions on flyertalk, where there is a dedicated forum for this card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.For me, the Citi Simplicity card comes pretty close.For a single annual fee of $95, I receive a $0% intro APR on balance transfers for the first 18 months I'm a cardholder. I can use that time to consolidate all my other credit card debt onto one easy-to-manage card.I'm also rewarded $200 every year I make a purchase on the card. I can use that money to pay off any of my outstanding debt, or spend it how I choose.My balance will never become too much for me to pay off, either. The Citi Simplicity card doesn't have a cap on my credit limit. Instead, I can continue borrowing money as long as I repay what I've already borrowed.In my experience, the Citi Simplicity card is a much better choice than the Capital One card. For one thing, I don't have to worry about Capital One changing my interest rate as often as Citi does.Citi changes my interest rate every six months based on my credit report, while Capital One will change my interest rate based on a 25-year rolling average.Citi will also increase my APR based on how I use the card. If I spend more than 30% of my available credit, my interest rate will go up. If I pay my bill before the due date, my interest rate will go down.Citi Simplicity doesn't work this way. If I'm in a position where I have to pay interest, I don't want it to be based on anything other than my actual finances.I've heard from other people who love the Capital One card and swear by it, but I don't want my credit card to depend on how I use it. I prefer to have control over my financial situation, rather than the other way around.I like that I can get a $0% intro APR on balance transfers with the Citi Simplicity card. I think they're an important factor to consider before signing up for a credit card.The Capital One card offers 20% more cash back than the Citi Simplicity card, and the Citi Simplicity card charges a $95 annual fee.Both of these cards have similar perks, but the Capital One card is cheaper for me to use on a regular basis.I'd like to have a choice between two credit cards that have similar perks, but one of them is much cheaper than the other.If I want to have a credit card with great benefits, I need to choose one with a lower annual fee. The Capital One card has that benefit, and I think it's a good way to start off my credit card career.I'm interested in finding a credit card that offers a $0% intro APR on balance transfers. I want to consolidate all my other credit card debt onto one easy-to-manage card.I'm interested in a credit card that lets me earn money back on every purchase I make. I want to be able to earn 1.25% back on every purchase I make. The Capital One card also lets me use the money to make a purchase at any of my favorite stores.I'm looking for a credit card with a $0% intro APR on balance transfers. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I am a Canadian resident and am interested in opening an account, I am currently looking at the CIBC Advantage MasterCard or the CIBC Rewards Card.Which of these credit cards would you recommend I get?Thank you for your question. I am also in Canada.I have the CIBC Advantage Mastercard and I like it. It is a good no-frills card with no annual fee. I also got a 20% bonus on my CIBC deposits when I switched to this card from another. There are a lot of bonus offers so make sure to read the fine print.I am with you on the no frills card, especially since the CIBC Rewards Card has an annual fee of $15. I've read some great reviews on the CIBC Advantage Card and it sounds like the perfect card for me. I'm hoping to get the bonus as well, although I've only recently started looking into it.As a reminder, I am looking for a good credit card that has the lowest interest rate and is reliable.Thank you for the recommendations. I'm not too interested in the rewards aspect of the card as much as I am in the benefits and stability of the card.I have had the CIBC Advantage Mastercard since 2007, I don't recall there ever being a limit on it, and I have never had problems paying the balance off monthly. The interest rate is a bit high, but as long as you don't carry a balance on the card, it is a good one.I have the RBC card, it has the lowest interest rate, but I pay my balance off in full every month, and there are no perks with it.I don't have the CIBC Advantage Mastercard, but I am familiar with it. It is a great card and the interest rate isn't that bad. The only issue I see with it is that it does not offer a free credit report. There are a lot of cards out there that offer this service, and I personally like the idea of having a credit report for free. It will help me keep my credit score healthy and it also allows me to keep track of my credit card activity.I have been using the CIBC Advantage Mastercard for a number of years now. I've never had any problems with it and I really like the fact that it is a no-frills card. The interest rate isn't that great, but that's not why I'm using it. I pay my balance off every month and I don't really see any reason to switch.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. To put things in perspective, the average American household has at least four different credit cards. Some cards are for specific types of purchases, like travel rewards cards. Other cards are good for paying off large amounts of debt because of low interest rates. Still, other cards are used for buying groceries, clothing, and everyday necessities. The best credit card for most people is the one that provides the best value for their unique lifestyle. If you don't think you need four or more credit cards, you're in good company.Do you have a favorite credit card? Let us know what you like about it, or why you think your current credit card is the best in the world.I'm currently only using the Citi AAdvantage MasterCard, so I'm obviously biased. However, I think that it offers a great combination of perks, low interest rates, and financial flexibility. To start, Citi's cardholders get a free companion pass every year. That alone is worth a lot of money, and it makes it possible to travel for free or close to it on the back of a single credit card.I also really like the flexibility of the card. I've never been subjected to a credit check, and I can also carry a balance without getting hit with any interest charges. I've found that this flexibility makes it a great tool for paying off the occasional large expense. Lastly, I really like the perks and benefits of the card, which include lounge access and a 50% discount on airport parking. The AAdvantage MasterCard has its cons too, and I'll be the first to admit that the rewards points program is pretty bad. It takes a long time to earn anything significant, and there are some better programs out there.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card has quickly become my favorite credit card for the following reasons. I get a 50,000 point bonus every time I open a new account, and the points are worth more than you would get with other cards. For example, I can earn $625 in travel rewards for each $4,000 I spend. The credit card also comes with a decent rewards program. I've already used the free travel credits to cover travel expenses, and I like the idea that my rewards will never expire. Finally, the card has the highest purchase and travel protections out of any card I own. It's a great all-around credit card.My favorite card is the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. I love the flexible travel rewards program, but the best part is that I don't have to pay an annual fee. For me, this is a huge perk because I'm a low-income college student. Most cards that I've looked at require a minimum income to waive the annual fee. The Sapphire Preferred Card gives me 2x rewards on travel and dining and it's the perfect fit for my lifestyle.When I first got my credit card, I was told that it was the best card in the world. I didn't believe it at first. It was expensive and hard to use. After a while, I learned that it wasn't so bad. I got rewards, and I had a way to pay for things. The card has been a huge part of my life since then.I use the Capital One Quicksilver Rewards Card for all of my personal expenses. I love that it gives me 1.5% cash back on all purchases and a 10% rewards bonus when I spend at least $5,000 in a year. I also really like that it doesn't charge an annual fee. It has some great features, like no foreign transaction fees, no cash advance fees, and a chip that protects me from fraud.If you're looking for a great credit card, I'd recommend the Chase Freedom Unlimited. The perks of this card are:Unlimited 1.5% cash back on all purchasesFree credit score monitoringAccess to Chase's online banking portal, where you can make payments and track your spendingA $100 sign-up bonus when you spend $500 in the first three monthsA 0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers for the first 15 monthsNo annual fee, but you must maintain a qualifying direct deposit of $500 or more each month to keep the cardThis card has a lower interest rate than most other cards, and you don't have to worry about being charged for overseas transactions or foreign transaction fees. The biggest drawback is that the rewards are pretty limited. You get 1.5% back on everything you buy, and you can only redeem your rewards for cash or gift cards. You can't use them to book travel or transfer them to another card.If you want a card with more flexibility in how you can redeem your rewards, you should consider getting the Chase Sapphire Preferred or the Chase Sapphire Reserve.I recently switched my main card to the Chase Sapphire Reserve because of the increased value I get from its rewards program. This new card also comes with 1:1 point transfer to Hyatt and United, which is great for me.In order to use this card, you need to have a solid credit history, good credit, and a high income. These requirements are standard for most cards in the United States. I personally use my credit card to make purchases, but I'm not going to go into the specifics of how you use it. If you don't know what a credit card is, it's basically a piece of plastic that allows you to pay for things without cash. You can't take out a loan with it, but you can use it to purchase things and pay them off later.There are different types of cards, including store cards, debit cards, and rewards cards. Each type of card has different benefits and drawbacks, so you should decide which type of card works best for you.The Chase Freedom Unlimited card is a great option for most people. It's not as expensive as other rewards cards, and it offers a lot of benefits. You'll get a $100 sign-up bonus when you spend $500 in the first three months, and you'll earn 1.5% cash back on all purchases. You'll also get no foreign transaction fees, no annual fee, and free credit score monitoring.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card is my favorite because it has a large sign-up bonus, a low APR, no annual fee, and free credit score monitoring. You'll also earn 2x points for every dollar you spend at restaurants and gas stations. The best part is that you can use the rewards to pay for travel, which is something that I love to do.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. It can be the Chase Sapphire Preferred, American Express Gold, or Capital One Venture Rewards—but the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card may be the right choice for you. This card, while offering a meager welcome bonus of just 20,000 miles, gives you access to a huge range of perks that can add up to some serious value over time.In order to take advantage of everything it has to offer, though, you need to be sure you understand what it does and doesn't include. It's time to find out what makes this a card that's worth your consideration and how it can help you save and earn more.The Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card offers 1.25 miles per dollar spent and a 0% introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers for the first 12 months (then 16.99%–25.24% variable APR).How Does the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card Work?In order to fully understand this card, it helps to know a few basic facts about how credit cards work. While you may know how to read a credit card's terms and conditions, the most important thing to know is that your credit card company doesn't actually lend you the money that you spend—it's your credit card issuer that lends you money. They'll charge you a certain interest rate in exchange for lending you that money.As we've mentioned before, a 0% introductory APR is a pretty good deal. With this deal, your purchases will not be charged interest for a set period of time. There are plenty of credit cards that offer introductory 0% interest rates, and this one is a good deal if you plan on spending more than you normally would and paying it off afterward. This can be a great option if you're planning a trip, for instance, and want to get a jump on paying off the cost of it without having to pay the interest.How the VentureOne Rewards Card's Sign-up Bonus WorksThe VentureOne Rewards Card offers a pretty small sign-up bonus—just 20,000 miles. However, when you compare it to other options, it makes the VentureOne Rewards Card a pretty attractive choice. You can easily find credit cards that offer sign-up bonuses of 50,000 miles or more, and the VentureOne Rewards Card makes it possible to have a healthy travel rewards balance fairly quickly.To put that bonus to good use, you'll need to redeem your miles for travel through Capital One Travel, and you can only redeem a minimum of 10,000 miles at a time. The good news is, you can use your miles for a variety of travel-related expenses, and you can also save a ton on travel if you have a decent travel credit card that offers reimbursements for certain travel expenses.Perks You Can Use With the VentureOne Rewards CardAs with any card that comes with benefits, the VentureOne Rewards Card offers some pretty interesting perks. For starters, there's an introductory 0% APR offer that can help you save money on interest and can also give you a bit more financial breathing room if you have an expense that needs to be paid off over time.Another perk you can take advantage of is Capital One Travel. This service is a great resource for finding and booking travel for less. It can save you money on travel because it can help you find cheaper travel options by aggregating travel pricing across the internet.A 3-Day Price Match Guarantee also comes with the VentureOne Rewards Card. If you book travel with Capital One Travel and you find a better price later, you can have Capital One Travel refund the difference to you. This can make it easier for you to know you're getting a good deal, and that can make you more confident when booking travel.There are also a couple of perks that you may find helpful for managing your credit cards. First, there's a free credit score monitoring feature that can help you keep a closer eye on your credit and see what changes you can make. It's also important to know how to use the perks and features of your card to keep it in great condition, and that's where the Capital One Cardholder Assistance feature comes in handy.How to Sign Up for the Capital One VentureOne Rewards CardSigning up for the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card is pretty simple. You can visit the Capital One website, apply for the card, and get it in the mail. You'll have to enter your personal information to complete the application process, and if you qualify, you'll be able to start using your new credit card within a few weeks.How Much Is the Annual Fee for the VentureOne Rewards Card?There is no annual fee for this card.What Are the Other Benefits of This Card?The VentureOne Rewards Card is a no-fee card. You won't have to pay an annual fee in order to use it. If you do end up paying a fee for your card, it will have to be an annual fee, and this one is not. This is great for cardholders who don't want to pay an annual fee and those who can't quite qualify for another credit card due to their credit score.Other perks of this card include a travel insurance package and a mobile wallet feature. These features can make travel more convenient and can make it easier for you to manage your money when you're away.Should You Get the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card?There are a few things to consider before applying for the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card. One of the most important is your credit score. If you don't have a strong credit score, you may find that it's not possible to qualify for this card. If you do qualify, you'll still have to pay some attention to your credit utilization rate, as this card has a minimum 5% required credit utilization rate and a maximum limit of $1,000.The Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card also has a minimum income requirement that you'll have to meet in order to qualify. If you don't meet that requirement, it may not be the best fit for you.Is the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card Right for You?There's no one-size-fits-all credit card, and it's important to take a look at the specific features and benefits offered by the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card to decide whether it's the right card for you. This card offers an introductory 0% APR and the opportunity to earn miles on your purchases. If you're interested in having access to a variety of travel rewards perks, this may be the card for you. If you have a travel credit card that you're happy with, it's probably best to avoid signing up for a card with this type of travel perk.Should I Use My VentureOne Rewards Card to Pay for Travel?Paying for travel with the VentureOne Rewards Card is a great idea for a few reasons. First, it gives you an opportunity to use your travel rewards to pay for travel. Capital One Travel is a great resource for finding travel deals, and redeeming your travel rewards for those travel expenses can help you save on those travel costs.Another reason to consider using your VentureOne Rewards Card to pay for travel is that you can take advantage of the Capital One Price Match Guarantee and get your travel purchases for less. If you find a better deal on travel after you've made a purchase, you can have Capital One Travel refund the difference to you.Should I Use My VentureOne Rewards Card for All My Purchases?It's a good idea to use the VentureOne Rewards Card to pay for travel-related purchases. The travel rewards you earn can help you save money when booking travel, and you can take advantage of the Capital One Price Match Guarantee and get your travel purchases for less.However, there's no reason to limit yourself to using the VentureOne Rewards Card for travel purchases alone. There are plenty of other ways to use this card and reap the benefits. For instance, you can use your VentureOne Rewards Card to make everyday purchases without having to worry about paying interest. There's no minimum income requirement, so you don't have to worry about not having enough money in your bank account to make a purchase. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I use a Capital One Venture Card for most of my spending and an Amex Platinum for travel, so I'm probably a little biased.I find myself thinking about this a lot more these days because I am getting into investing. I've never done it before, but it's been on my radar for a few years now and I've taken a little more action than normal recently. It's not that I'm going to get rich overnight, but I do think it's important to diversify a little, especially at this stage in my life.My newest venture has been with an investing service called Betterment. They charge 0.25% of your money per year and manage it for you. They claim to make smarter investment decisions than the average person, so I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt and giving them my money to hold and invest.You should know that Betterment is a "robo-advisor" which means they automatically adjust and diversify your portfolio, as the market goes up and down. I don't have the knowledge, skill, or the time to make these adjustments on my own, so I am hoping Betterment can improve my results.They are definitely better than nothing, but the returns I've seen so far are a little underwhelming. I'm hoping they will ramp up in the future.The best credit card I know of right now is a no brainer: the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. They've got a great sign-up bonus (50,000 points after spending $4,000 within the first 3 months), a low interest rate (14.49%), and the rewards are good, too (double points on travel and dining).I've read that some people pay off their credit cards in full every month, but I know I'm not one of those people. I pay it off as much as I can, but it never quite reaches zero because we buy stuff, have expenses, and don't quite make enough money to cover all of our living expenses.Even though I pay off my credit card every month, I have never paid interest on it. I use the free-money trick I learned from MoneyBoss.The first step is to find a no annual fee card that gives you a generous sign-up bonus. I use a Capital One Venture card and their current offer is 50,000 points (worth $500) after spending $3,000 in the first 3 months.I get a lot of rewards points on my Capital One Venture card, but I do feel like I'm a little over-extended with 13 credit cards.I'm not sure I've found the perfect credit card yet, but it's hard to beat a no annual fee card with a huge sign-up bonus.I feel like I could do a better job of saving and investing.I think it's important to start as soon as possible.It's hard for me to think about getting older because it seems like it's happening all too quickly, but I know it's happening, and it will continue to happen at a much faster rate from here on out. I'm only 29, but it feels like I'm already middle-aged.It's hard to imagine that in 40 years, I will be almost 70 years old.I've heard that people should save 10% of their income, but I'm not sure I could do that.I think a good goal is to save 5% of your income. That should be easy enough to do if you keep your expenses low, and it will give you a good buffer to fall back on in case you lose your job or get into an unexpected situation.The trick to saving more money is to figure out how you can cut your expenses. The obvious stuff like eating out and buying new clothes is the obvious stuff to cut out of your budget, but you may be able to find other opportunities to reduce your spending.I have a friend who rented a 2 bedroom apartment for a while before she moved to another state. She got a discount because it was off-season and she took a chance on renting a room in someone else's apartment.It worked out well for her because she saved a ton of money on rent and she also met some new people who became friends. If you can find a similar deal, it could be an easy way to save some money.I'm not sure if the math works out, but I think it would be fun to calculate how much money you've saved by doing certain things, like living with your parents. The cost of living seems like it gets higher every year and you have to start planning your retirement before you start saving for it.I'm not sure if the math works out, but I think it would be fun to calculate how much money you've saved by doing certain things, like living with your parents. The cost of living seems like it gets higher every year and you have to start planning your retirement before you start saving for it. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. In other words, which is the card to have? I'm guessing this is a card that will offer the most rewards for airfare and hotels.With 2% cash back on all other purchases, the card is more than just for travelers.I've been reading that the Citi Prestige card is the best card for people like myself who fly a lot. It seems that many frequent fliers get the Chase Sapphire Preferred card, as it gives 25% more rewards for travel and other purchases, plus the 1:1 conversion from travel to cash. So my question is which of the two cards offers the best bang for the buck, and why? I'm also curious as to whether there are any other cards out there that are better than either of these. I do not have good credit, so if you could recommend some other credit cards, that would be great too.If you're serious about maximizing your credit card rewards, you've probably been studying up on the subject of travel cards.And you've probably noticed the glaring similarities between the Citi Prestige and Chase Sapphire Preferred cards. They both charge an annual fee of $450. They both offer excellent rewards and some of the best travel perks available. They both have strong travel insurance coverage. And they both earn an easy two cents per dollar on all purchases.So why would anyone want one over the other?I know it sounds like heresy, but I can tell you that I think there are good reasons for choosing one over the other -- and none of them is based on cashback.If you travel frequently, then the Chase Sapphire Preferred card will be better for you.It is the better card for travel, but it will cost you $55 more every year.Let's look at the rewards.If you travel frequently, then the Chase Sapphire Preferred card will be better for you. It is the better card for travel, but it will cost you $55 more every year.While you'll get more cashback overall from the Chase Sapphire Preferred card, you have to understand that rewards are just one way to look at it.The Prestige offers better perks. It includes a statement credit to cover the cost of your Global Entry or TSA PreCheck membership. Global Entry is great because it allows you to zip through U.S. immigration when traveling internationally, saving you a lot of time. TSA PreCheck gives you access to a separate security lane at most U.S. airports.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card doesn't offer these benefits. If you use them regularly, that extra $55 will save you hundreds of dollars.The Chase Sapphire Preferred card doesn't offer these benefits.It also gives you priority boarding and access to airport lounges, and a $250 travel credit after you spend $3,000 in the first six months.The Prestige offers better perks.And if you like the idea of earning airline miles on all your purchases (especially when you don't travel enough to get free flights every year), then the Citi Prestige offers you 5x on airfare and hotels, versus just 2x on the Chase Sapphire Preferred.So, it comes down to this: the Chase Sapphire Preferred is the best card for travel, but you'll get a lot more out of it if you're a frequent traveler. For everyone else, the Citi Prestige is the way to go.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm considering two cards -- Chase Sapphire Preferred ($0 annual fee), and Chase Freedom ($0 annual fee).For those unfamiliar with Chase cards, they typically require that you maintain at least $5,000 on the credit card. This amount of monthly income can be met by the average person and it doesn't impact your credit score, which can be a big bonus if you're trying to build credit.You can earn two free nights at any of the Hyatt category 1-4 hotels each year.If you spend $4,000 or more per year, then you'll earn two 25% cash-back bonuses, which can be used to pay down your credit card.You'll earn three points for every dollar you spend on groceries, gas stations, drugstores, restaurants, airfare, and hotels. You'll earn two points for every dollar you spend on all other purchases.You'll earn 2% cash back on up to $1,500 in grocery store purchases each quarter.You'll earn 1% cash back on all other purchases.Chase Freedom is the only one of these cards to require a minimum $5,000 monthly income, but they both offer low interest rates.The Chase Sapphire Preferred also offers two free nights at any Hyatt hotel every year, along with a $0 annual fee.Which card do you think is better?I'm in favor of Chase Freedom for several reasons: First, I've read online that the Chase Sapphire Preferred card doesn't let you transfer your points to other credit cards, which seems to put Chase Freedom in the lead.Second, if I want to redeem my Chase Freedom points on Hyatt hotels, I only need to spend $5,000 in a year and I'll get two free nights per year. If I want to redeem my Chase Sapphire Preferred points on Hyatt hotels, then I'll need to spend $12,000 in a year.Third, Chase Freedom also lets me earn 2% cash back on groceries, which can save me $250 per year. If I want to redeem my Chase Sapphire Preferred points on groceries, then I'd get only 1% cash back.Chase Sapphire Preferred offers two free nights per year, but only for Hyatt hotels and you'll need to spend $12,000 in a year to earn the free nights.Chase Freedom offers two free nights per year, but it also offers 2% cash back on groceries, which can save you $250 per year.Either one of these cards is better than other credit cards I've seen that require a minimum $5,000 income.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What's most important to you? Do you care more about frequent flier miles, free groceries, or low interest rates? Do you want a card that gives you a lot of options or a card that makes it simple to manage your cash?How do you evaluate credit cards?I've been thinking a lot about how I pick a credit card, and it's clear that there are as many ways to evaluate a credit card as there are cardholders.I'm an avid user of the AmEx Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express. It pays me back 6% for grocery purchases, 3% for gas purchases, and 1% for all other purchases.The grocery benefit is huge for me. I know that, on average, I'm going to save at least $400 on groceries each year (after the $250 spending limit). The low gas benefit doesn't matter to me, because I don't buy gas with a credit card. I like to put everything I can on a credit card, and then pay off my balance each month. I don't carry a balance on the card.I also like that my credit card offers a low interest rate of 10.24% for purchases. It's not a huge benefit, but I like to have that peace of mind that I'm not going to be hit with huge interest payments every month.The American Express Platinum card is popular for a reason -- its benefits are top notch. The $500 airline credit alone makes this card appealing. The card also offers an impressive array of travel benefits, including airport lounge access, an annual airline fee credit, upgrades on airlines and hotels, and more.But it's not perfect. The $450 annual fee may be a bit much. For frequent travelers, the annual fee is worthwhile -- but not everyone can use all of the perks the card offers. If you don't plan on traveling, this card may not make sense.Besides the credit card industry, what other businesses are you considering for a switch to a competitor? What are the factors that most determine your switching decision?I'm considering making a switch from AmEx to Capital One for my grocery credit card. The new Capital One card offers the same 6% rate for grocery purchases. I'd also save money on the annual fee: $0 compared to $75.The Capital One card also offers 2% cash back on restaurants and entertainment, as well as 1% back on everything else. The cash back rewards are good, but I don't see myself using them.My family and I love flying on Southwest Airlines, so we have the Southwest Rapid Rewards Priority Credit Card from Chase.In addition to earning free flights, the card also offers up to 365 days of extended rental car coverage when you rent with Hertz, up to $1,500 in baggage insurance, free in-flight Wi-Fi, and more.It's a great card, but the annual fee is $89 per year. If I'm paying the annual fee anyway, I may as well pay the AmEx fee and earn rewards that I can actually use.If you want to take advantage of low interest rates, you may want to consider a credit card with a low interest rate. I'd recommend the Discover it card. You can qualify for a 0% introductory APR on purchases and balance transfers for six months. After that, the regular APR is a low 10.99% to 22.99%.Another credit card with an outstanding interest rate is the U.S. Bank Altitude® Go Visa Signature® Card. With the U.S. Bank card, you'll receive an introductory interest rate of 0% APR on purchases and balance transfers for 20 billing cycles. After that, the regular interest rate is 13.99% to 23.99% APR.The interest rate on this card is low, but it's not the only benefit. You can earn 3% cash back at U.S. supermarkets (up to $6,000 per year in purchases). Plus, you'll earn 2% cash back on gas and 1% cash back on all other purchases.The card also offers an introductory APR of 0% APR on balance transfers for 21 billing cycles. After that, the regular APR is 14.49% to 24.49% APR.The Bank of America Cash Rewards credit card is another great card for earning cash back. You'll earn 3% cash back in the category of your choice (gas, groceries, dining, travel, or online shopping). The introductory APR is 0% for 12 months on purchases and balance transfers, and after that, the regular APR is 13.99% to 23.99% APR.If you're not a fan of cash back rewards, you may want to consider another type of rewards card. The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers 2X points on dining and travel.The card offers 3X points on other purchases such as groceries and gas. The introductory APR is 0% for 12 months on purchases and balance transfers, and after that, the regular APR is 14.49% to 23.49% APR.Are you satisfied with the credit card you have now? Why or why not?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I personally use the Chase Sapphire Preferred. I get 2 points per dollar spent on all purchases, and 5 points for travel and dining. There's an annual fee of $95, but it's so easy to get this money back. Also, you get to redeem your rewards through Chase or through one of their partners, like Expedia.If you've got a card and you like it, please do post in the comments. Thanks!I'm actually curious why you chose the Chase Sapphire Preferred over the Chase Ink Business Cash. 5% back on office supply stores, gas, cell phones, land lines, internet, cable and electric. Also, the card has no annual fee. What are your thoughts?The Chase Ink Cash sounds great, but for me, I've got a small business, and I can only really benefit from the bonuses by using it for business purchases. I can't really get to $6,000 in purchases with the card since I'm already using my personal cards for the vast majority of purchases. The Chase Sapphire Preferred is much more versatile, and I'm not spending money on a card to get 1 point per dollar spent for personal purchases.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.The only catch? You're not allowed to use any of your own credit cards!Instead, you must rely solely on the cards you can choose from on this list.There are 4 cards you can choose from. And the best card wins!A) Barclaycard Arrival Plus World Elite MasterCard (14.99%)22X points on all purchases3X points on all airline, hotel, and car rental purchasesPoints are redeemable for all airline, hotel, car rentals, and cruisesB) Chase Sapphire Preferred (11.99%)5X points on travel and diningBonus point offers on travel, dining, and new cardmember spendingFree trip cancellation/interruption insuranceC) Capital One VentureOne Rewards Card (12.90%)10X miles on all purchases20,000 mile bonus on $3000 spent in the first 6 monthsD) Discover It (10.99%)Bonus rewards on restaurants, gas stations, and pay at the pumpE) Credit Card of your Choice (13.99%)The card that doesn't fit in any of the other categoriesThis is where the best credit card comes into play, and you'll earn 1 point for every dollar you spend.So you're limited to spending up to $50,000 per year. (Because you can't pay off your balance at the end of the year, which would make this card more lucrative.)There are no fees, no interest, and no spending caps.The only caveat is that this credit card is a bank issued credit card.You don't have to pay any fees, but you don't earn rewards points either.This card only makes sense if you're looking for a simple, low interest, no-frills credit card that you don't have to worry about paying your credit card bill on time.This card comes with a 10-point interest rate.It has a 2-point balance transfer rate and a 3-point balance transfer penalty.This card also comes with 10X points on all purchases.B) Chase Sapphire Reserve (13.99%)This card is designed for people who want to travel around the world, but don't want to pay a lot of interest.The card has a 1-point per dollar cash back rate and a 2-point balance transfer fee.This card comes with a 1-point transfer rate.The card also has a 1% cash back rate and no fees.This card comes with 2X miles on airline, hotel, and car rentals, and 1X points on all other purchases.This card comes with no fees and a 1.5% cash back rate on everyday purchases.The only catch is that this card comes with a 2% interest rate.C) Capital One VentureOne Rewards (14.90%)This card comes with 1X points on all shopping, dining, and travel, and 2X points on all airfare and car rentals.This card comes with no balance transfer fee and a 2-point interest rate.The card has no annual fees and a 2-point balance transfer fee, and a 3-point balance transfer charge.The only thing that can make this card better is if you are a frequent traveler.This is the card I'm most likely to use.A) Barclays Arrival Plus World Elite MasterCard (14.99)This credit card is perfect for someone who wants a low interest credit card that comes with perks, including free travel and a great rewards program.If you like to travel and you want a great card that comes with perks and low interest rates, then this is the card for you.This is the card I've been using for years and it has been perfect for me.I use it to travel for business, so it's great for me, but I have a ton of family members who also love this card, so they love it as well.I have a few friends who have been using it for years too.It's perfect for them, and they like the perks.This one is the best for me.A) Barclaycard Platinum Card (15.99%)I have a bunch of friends and family that use this card, so that makes it a really great credit card for them.It's the perfect card for people that are on the go, and that's what makes it the best one for me too.The card that's perfect for my wife and I is the one that comes with free travel.That's the card I would recommend, and my wife loves it.This card also offers 3X miles per dollar spent at restaurants and gas stations.This one is also perfect for our family.This card does not have a balance transfer penalty, and the card comes with a 3X bonus points on all gas, groceries, and drugstore purchases.This one comes with an annual fee of $99.B) Chase Freedom (14.99%)The card you've been waiting for, and this one has a 1% cash back rate.It comes with a $95 annual fee, and a 1% transfer penalty.This one's the perfect card for those that are looking for a credit card with a 3% cash back rate and a $100 annual fee, which is a nice perk.This one is the best for me because it has no balance transfer fees.It doesn't have any balance transfer charge, either, so that's another perk.This card also offers no fees for transfers, but it has a 1 point per $1 cash back rate, which is the same as a 1.5% transfer fee.This card is perfect for my wife's parents.This is a great card for them because it gives them the opportunity to travel.A) Barclay Arrival Plus World Elite (15.99%)This card offers the perfect credit card for those with families who need to travel.It also offers free travel and cash back rewards.This card will give you a 10% cash back rate with no balance transfer fees and no interest.This card is perfect if you have a big family and want to save money by getting a great credit card with great rewards.B) Chase Freedom (13.99%) and Capital One VentureOne (14.9)These two cards offer the most flexibility in terms of what you can spend and how much you can save.These are both great cards for families with a lot of money, and there are no balance transfer penalties with either card.The only catch with these cards is that you have to pay the annual fee on each card.These cards also come with no fees when you transfer money to them.This is a card that will work for families who like to pay off their bills at the end, but want to avoid paying off their balance.These cards come with 3X cash back rate at restaurants, and 5X cash back rates at grocery stores.Both of these cards come with an annual fee of 5%C) Barclaycard Sapphire Reserve (14.99 and 15.99%)This is the perfect card if you want a credit card for travel, but don't want the hassle of paying off bills each month.It also has a 1X cash back points rate and no balance transfer penalties.These are the two cards that I'm using for my travel, and I would highly recommend them.These cards come with no annual fee, and you get free travel with each card.The only catch is that they don't come with any bonus points for the first year of the card.D) Capital One Quicksilver Rewards (14%)This is a great credit card to use if you like to travel with friends and family.These cards come with 1X reward points per dollar spent at restaurants.These two cards are perfect for people that like to get free <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'd be interested to know your criteria for what makes a great card and the benefits you're looking for in your card. What are the things you consider important and which cards did you pick and why?For me it has to be low interest rates and no foreign transaction fees. I want a credit card that I can leave in my wallet for the entire time I have it and only use it if I really need to or there's some bonus points I can redeem for travel. The only exception I've found so far is my Discover it Miles which has an annual fee and a higher than 1% foreign transaction fee.I'm wondering what you guys think of these cards and how you would rank them?-The Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card offers 50,000 bonus miles when you spend $3,000 on purchases within the first 3 months and gives 2 miles per $1 spent on all purchases.-The Chase Freedom Unlimited offers 3% cash back on all purchases and no annual fee.-The Citi Double Cash card offers 2% cash back when you pay for purchases.-The Citi Simplicity card offers 0% APR for 21 months on balance transfers and for 12 months on purchases. It also offers no penalty APR.I know this is a bit of a cop out and I do think you can definitely get a better card than these, but I'm going to go with a Capital One 360 Money Market.Why? The main thing is the lack of fees. There is no annual fee, no ATM fee, and no fees on out-of-network ATM withdrawals.The interest rate is also pretty decent. This card charges an average of 13.45% to 21.90% (I was recently approved for a card at 16.90%).Lastly, the ability to link it to your savings account makes it a pretty good tool for earning interest while keeping your money in an FDIC-insured account.Any time I can get a no-fee card with a decent interest rate and still have it feel like I'm getting something in return I consider it a big win.I like the Chase Sapphire Preferred, because I'm a loyalty customer and it has a really high sign-up bonus.You do not have to redeem the points for travel-related purchases. If you use the points to redeem for a travel experience, the points have to be used on the same website as the purchase. If not, you get less value for your points.For example, if I buy a $300 flight from Expedia, I can use 3,000 points to cover the flight, but I'm getting a better value if I use the 3,000 points towards a 4-night stay in a $600 hotel. In this example, I'm getting $120 worth of hotel for my $300 flight. I prefer to use the $300 flight on my next flight instead, so I use the points towards the hotel.The other benefit of the Chase Sapphire Preferred card is that I can charge things to my account and then, later, pay it off with the travel points, which I redeem for a cash reward instead of a travel reward. I recently charged $2,000 to my Chase Sapphire Preferred card and paid it off 2 months later. I did not pay any interest on that $2,000 because my card has a 0% introductory rate for purchases.For $95/yr, I get 2x points on travel and dining and 1x on everything else. That gives me a 5.25% return on my spending.And I can take it to the limit every quarter - Chase Sapphire Preferred lets you earn 100,000 points every year by spending $50,000. So if I spend $100,000 in a year, I'll get $2,500 in travel rewards every year ($30,000 * 5.25%).I just signed up for the Capital One Venture Rewards and I'm so excited! 50,000 miles after you spend $3,000 on purchases in the first 3 months.I love Capital One Venture Rewards! The main reason is that they have no foreign transaction fees so I can use it abroad without paying extra.The other thing I like about this card is that it lets you earn 1.25x miles on all purchases. So if I spend $3,000 on travel and dining in the first 3 months, I'll earn 3,750 miles. That's a 12.5% return on my spending!I'm considering the Capital One Quicksilver Cash Rewards. 1.5% cash back is pretty high and there's no annual fee. I have a Discover It Miles and that card charges no foreign transaction fees but that comes with an annual fee of $95.I don't think I could live without a cash back card, so for me the best card to have would be a cash back one, no annual fees and the ability to redeem for cash. For me that would be the Chase Freedom Unlimited and I'm pretty much set with it.This would probably depend on my needs at the moment and the type of travel I'm going on. I'd like a credit card with no foreign transaction fees and the Capital One Venture Rewards is currently my favorite one.For me it would be the Chase Freedom Unlimited because it's a cash back credit card and it's easy to use and doesn't charge foreign transaction fees. I don't use my card abroad so it's great to have that feature.My preferred card is the Citi Double Cash card because I don't like annual fees or foreign transaction fees. I think that's a good combination of perks.It depends on what I'm using it for but I'd like to have an annual fee that's low and no foreign transaction fees.I'm all about simplicity with a little extra. My ideal card is the Capital One Venture Rewards card. 50,000 bonus miles after you spend $3,000 on purchases in the first 3 months is a pretty good deal.I don't think I could do without a cash back card. I get the Chase Freedom Unlimited and I like the idea of the ability to redeem my rewards for cash. I also don't think I'll ever be in a situation where I'll need a card with a high interest rate.For me it's the Capital One Venture Rewards because it's got a $95 annual fee and 50,000 bonus miles after you spend $3,000 on purchases in the first 3 months. I love cash back rewards so this card is a great option.For me it would be a credit card with no annual fees and no foreign transaction fees. My credit cards are my safety net so I don't want to have to worry about extra fees for using them abroad.What are the things you consider important and which cards did you pick and why?For me it's the ability to earn cash back with no annual fees. I've been using the Chase Freedom Unlimited for a while now and it's a pretty good option. I think it's also important to consider whether or not a card will charge you a fee to use it abroad so you don't end up paying more than you have to for using your credit card.I don't know that I'd say these are the best cards in terms of perks, low interest rates, and financial flexibility, but I think they're pretty good. I'm thinking about getting a Chase Freedom Unlimited card for the 1.5% cash back I'll earn on my spending.A cash back credit card would be the best combination for me. That's a pretty straightforward combination and you don't have to worry about foreign transaction fees or interest rates.</s>
