<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.What's more, what are the rewards that most appeal to you? If you have a specific bank in mind, I'd love to know what their cards offer that you find appealing and why.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. This is a personal finance forum and I would appreciate honest feedback.BTW, I don't own any credit cards.Which credit card offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility?I don't think I can answer that question, but I can tell you which ones I use.Chase United Explorer: The main thing I use this one for is the two miles for every dollar spent and no foreign transaction fees. I love the annual fee waived. I have had this one for 10 years.US Bank Flex Perks Visa: My 2nd favorite credit card. I got the travel accident insurance to cover me and my wife when we travel. Also have the price protection and auto rental insurance. I use it for online purchases and pay for everything with it.FairPoint Visa Signature: This one is good for local grocery store purchases at Hannaford and Shaw's, it has a 15% discount at those stores and gives you one point for every dollar you spend. This was the last one I got because it had no annual fee. I use it for the discount.I have had all of these for 10+ years and have never paid a single penalty for late payments. I would not suggest opening any of them as there is no real benefit other than the perks I stated above.If you are like me and want to go on vacation you do not need to pay interest on it as you will pay it off.This is just my opinion but I would not waste my time. I use a couple of them to get the perks but my main one is the United Explorer and I use it for everything, but online purchases I usually do with my debit card.Most credit cards have a yearly fee that you must pay to use the card. This fee can range from $50 to $100 depending on which card you are getting. You need to find a card that offers you the best perks and doesn't have an annual fee. Some credit cards offer rewards to customers who spend a certain amount every year on the card. This is called cash back. Other credit cards will offer you a certain amount off your purchase every time you use the card for shopping.Some credit cards will have interest rates that are much higher than others. Credit cards can be dangerous to use if you do not have a plan to pay it off every month. If you want to buy a nice big TV on sale at the store but only have $200 then you will end up paying a huge interest rate on your credit card for the rest of the amount you are short. Credit cards are good to use for emergencies if you do not have a large enough emergency fund or for a nice vacation, but you do not want to have to keep paying a huge amount of interest every month for shopping you did earlier.Which Credit Card Is Best?Which is the Best Credit Card for an Emergency?What Is the Best Credit Card?What's the Best Way to Find a Job as a Credit Manager?What's the Best Way to Pay off Your Mortgage Loan?What Is the Best Way to Pay Back Money I Borrowed from a Friend?What's the Best Way to Pay for a Home Renovation?What's the Best Way to Pay Off My Mortgage in 5 Years?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. If you ask around, most people will probably recommend the Amex Platinum credit card as being the most sought-after credit card among frequent travelers. It offers 60,000 bonus Membership Rewards points after you spend $5,000 within the first 3 months of account opening. Membership Rewards points can be redeemed to book airfare, hotels, car rentals, and even cash-back opportunities. But how does this compare to other credit cards on the market? Are there other options available that are more lucrative for your needs?When I'm looking for a good credit card that allows me to maximize my money, I have a simple checklist that I refer to. I always make sure that the card I'm applying for meets the following requirements:Low interest rates. When choosing a credit card, I like to select a card that has an interest rate lower than 13% for new purchases. This gives me more leeway to use the card if I need to for unexpected travel or car repairs.Annual fee under $50. Annual fees can be over $100 nowadays, and I don't think they are worth paying if you're just using the credit card for its perks. I'll even pay the annual fee to get a credit card with great benefits if I can avoid it.Great perks for me. Perks vary from person to person. What's important to me might not be important to you. I don't get anything out of car rentals, so I don't carry a card that has perks for renting cars. But if you travel a lot, then a good rental car perk might be a must. You can also find perks for dining, shopping, and even more general perks like cash-back opportunities.Rewards program. You don't have to go with a high-end card to get a rewards program. I carry a credit card with a lower annual fee and I get points to use at certain places. But I also earn a small amount of cash-back, which is useful for paying for necessities or even buying the occasional extra.While these requirements are all I ask from a credit card, I'm sure that not all of you are going to agree. Some of you may want a low interest rate, while others might care more about the annual fee and the amount of perks you can get. That's why I'm curious to hear what people think are the best credit cards available.If you could choose any credit card, what would it be? Would you pick the Platinum card or the Citi Prestige? Let me know in the comments below!How To Make The Most of Your Rewards ProgramSavings Incentive Programs: Are They Right For You?Most Travelers Use Rewards to Book TripsI’m looking at all the options of cards, but what I’m hearing the most is “get the card that makes you happy”.I feel that way, too!For me, it’s the combination of a low interest rate (below 13%) and no annual fee.I’ve been looking at the Barclays Arrival Plus for this – but I still have to figure out how their points system works for me.I’ve also been looking at the Barclaycard Arrival Plus. But I need to figure out how their points system works for me.I’m currently looking for a card with low interest rates and a low annual fee.My wife has the Barclays Arrival card, which has no annual fee and a pretty decent points structure. However, the Chase Sapphire Preferred has a much lower annual fee ($95 vs $95). The CSP also comes with a $500 travel rewards bonus, which is pretty tempting, especially given how low the annual fee is.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm in a 12.5% tax bracket, I have a mortgage on my home and have a substantial amount of credit card debt. I've had good luck with Barclaycards in the past and I know that many people like the Chase Sapphire Preferred but I don't think that it is a good fit for me given my financial situation. I'm considering some of the following options, but I would like to hear what you think about other cards before I make a decision:Barclays Arrival (6%)Chase Freedom (7.75%)Amex Everyday (0%)If you've had good luck with any of these cards, or if you've had a card that you've had a similar experience with, please post. I'm a newb, so it'll be helpful if you're able to provide some additional insight.Thanks in advance for your thoughtsApril 24, 2014 at 2:46 PM · You have a ton of choices. I'm with you on the Chase Sapphire. To me, it is a bit of an overkill for your situation.Since you're in the 12.5% bracket, the Citi Diamond would be an option (0% for 18 months with a balance transfer fee of 5%, $5k limit).If you like the Barclays, I'd look at the Barclays Rewards as an alternative.April 24, 2014 at 4:32 PM · If your goal is the lowest interest rate, there's no question about it - it's the Citi Simplicity.If you can qualify for Amex cards (the Everyday is notoriously hard to get), I'd go with the Blue Cash.April 24, 2014 at 7:57 PM · I'm in the same situation as you and I am using the Barclay Arrival (with $2,500 cash back after meeting minimum spending requirements and $100 bonus after first purchase) and the Chase Freedom. With the Chase, you get 5% cash back on purchases with a $1,500 minimum spend per quarter (and you can have 5 active Chase Freedom cards for $100 per card). With the Barclays card, I get $350 cash back after $1,500 spending in the first 3 months. Both cards get you 2% cash back on purchases (up to $1,000 spending per quarter on each card) and a $100 statement credit after making a purchase of at least $1,000 in the first 90 days on each card. The Barclays card is a bit more flexible in the sense that you don't have to meet a minimum spend on each quarter in order to get the cash back. I like the Barclay Arrival more than the Chase Freedom in this case because it gives you $350 for $1,500 spending in the first 3 months (plus $2,500 after meeting the minimum spending requirements) and it gives you 2% cash back on all purchases as opposed to only 5% cash back on purchases with a $1,500 minimum spend per quarter on the Chase Freedom.April 24, 2014 at 10:24 PM · The 5% cash back is nice, but you're not earning the cash back on the balance that you are transferring over, which is the debt that you need to pay off most quickly. So while it sounds good, it's probably not the best fit for your situation.April 25, 2014 at 12:55 AM · Chase FreedomMay 27, 2014 at 11:34 PM · I also just started the Barclay Arrival Plus (0% intro APR for 12 months) and Chase Freedom (0% intro APR for 15 months). If I'm able to pay off my debt in 24 months, I'll still come out ahead, even if I pay interest on a small part of it.August 1, 2014 at 1:10 PM · It depends what you want to spend the rewards on. If you are trying to pay off the debt, the Chase Freedom is a great option as long as you keep to the minimum spend requirements. If you are looking for the best travel rewards, then the Chase Sapphire Preferred might be the best option. However, I have the Barclay Arrival Plus and I would say that it is the best credit card in the market for average consumers. The rewards are flexible, easy to use and the card is easy to use. If you use one of the Barclay card, you will probably also use the other two.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm currently a long-time customer of Capital One but my loyalty is being tested by the company's decision to significantly raise the interest rate on their most popular product and limit access to cash.If I could, I'd stick with Capital One. I like their no-hassle approach and I prefer to stick with the same bank for my personal finance needs. Unfortunately, I may be forced to switch my spending to another credit card in search of better benefits.Which credit card is your favorite and why?I'm currently a Chase Sapphire Preferred cardholder and love their benefits (2x points for travel and dining, no annual fee, etc.).While there is a $50 fee for a lost card, Chase covers all fraudulent charges (thanks to my mom and her stolen wallet, I've seen that first hand!).The downside is that their rewards program is not as generous as Capital One's. I still use the Capital One card for purchases, though. I like the Capital One card because I'm not required to pay an annual fee, they cover fraudulent charges, and they even send you a new card if it's lost (I believe I can have a new one mailed to me after 10 days, which allows me to cancel the old one in my possession).There are two reasons why I prefer Chase. First, it's a co-branded card (like Marriott Rewards and Ritz-Carlton Rewards). This means that I earn 2X points for all spend on the card. This is a great deal compared to Capital One or Amex.The second reason is the lack of an annual fee, and the $0 fraud liability protection (this is a great benefit, since I've experienced fraudulent charges).</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.As of January 2018, according to WalletHub, the top rated card for financial flexibility is the American Express® Gold Card.I'm wondering if there are any other options out there. What do you use and why?We had a bunch of cards that we'd gotten over the years and we just closed them down. We just stick with Amex now and keep it very simple.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Credit cards can be a valuable tool if used responsibly. They allow you to earn rewards, save money on interest, and build your credit score. But with so many options available, it can be difficult to decide which credit card is right for you. Here are some factors to consider when choosing a credit card:If you’re looking for a credit card with the best rewards program, you’ll want to look for one that offers a generous sign-up bonus, high cashback rate, or a combination of the two.If you’re looking for a credit card with the best interest rate, you’ll want to look for one with a low APR and no annual fee.If you’re looking for a credit card with the best overall value, you’ll want to look for one that offers a variety of perks and benefits, such as travel rewards, cashback rewards, and a low APR.Once you’ve decided what you’re looking for in a credit card, it’s important to shop around and compare different options. Be sure to read the terms and conditions carefully, as well as the fine print. And always make sure to use your credit card responsibly, paying your balance in full each month and avoiding late fees.Whether you’re looking for a credit card to help you build your credit score or you just want a credit card with the best rewards program, there are plenty of options available. So don’t be afraid to do your research and find the credit card that’s right for you.We've all been there. You're at the grocery store, about to swipe your debit card, when your mind starts to wander. What if there's not enough money in your account? What if the transaction doesn't go through? What if you have to pay overdraft fees?For some people, this is a recurring nightmare. But for others, it's just a fact of life. And for those who struggle with overdraft fees, there's a solution: a credit card.A credit card can help you avoid overdraft fees because it allows you to borrow money that you don't have in your checking account. When you make a purchase with a credit card, the bank extends you a loan. Then, when you pay off the loan, the bank pays the merchant.Of course, this comes with a price: interest. Interest rates on credit cards are usually high, so you'll want to be careful not to rack up too much debt.But for many people, the peace of mind that comes with a credit card is worth the occasional higher interest rate. If you're someone who struggles with overdraft fees, a credit card can give you the peace of mind you need.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I'm sure many of you have a favorite credit card that you swear by.There are many good ones out there, but the credit cards that I like the best offer low interest rates, no foreign transaction fees, and great travel rewards.The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card is my favorite travel rewards credit card.It offers a great deal of flexibility, including the ability to redeem points for travel through Chase or transfer them to partners including United Airlines, Southwest Airlines, Marriott, and Hyatt.With the Sapphire Preferred, you'll also get some solid benefits like primary rental car insurance, cell phone insurance, and baggage delay insurance.You can earn a sign-up bonus of 50,000 Chase Ultimate Rewards points (worth around $625) when you spend $4,000 in the first three months of owning the card.The only downside is the $95 annual fee.If you can justify the annual fee, the Sapphire Preferred is a card you can use for years to come.When I go abroad, I don't like to think about the potential fees I might have to pay on my credit card. That's why I think the Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card is the perfect card for travelers.It's one of the few credit cards that doesn't charge foreign transaction fees.It also offers no limits on what you can redeem your points for, including redeeming them for travel as a statement credit.This is one of the few cards I'd recommend carrying a balance on, as you'll earn 1.25 miles for every dollar you spend (up to $10,000 in purchases a year).You'll also earn a one-time bonus of 40,000 miles when you spend $3,000 in the first three months of owning the card.This bonus is worth around $400 in travel and is easy to earn because Capital One doesn't count any transfer partners as foreign transactions.You'll pay a $95 annual fee, but I think it's worth the benefit of not paying foreign transaction fees.While the Sapphire Preferred is my go-to credit card for travel rewards, I also like to carry a card for everyday use.That's why I like the Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express, which offers 6% cash back at US supermarkets on up to $6,000 in purchases annually and 3% back on gas stations and select US department stores.The card also offers 1% back on all other purchases.When you factor in the 0% introductory interest rate for purchases and balance transfers, this is a great everyday card for those who need flexibility in their financial life.It does carry an annual fee of $95, which makes it one of the most expensive everyday cards on the market.But if you can afford to pay it, it's a great deal.This article was updated on February 6, 2019.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm a big fan of the Citi Prestige card, though I know a lot of people like the Sapphire Preferred and the Citi Premier card.I've been researching the subject because I'm looking to get a new card, and I thought I'd ask here before going ahead with anything.Thanks for all your insight. I'll be sure to update this thread after making a final decision on the card.You know, I was in the same boat as you last year, and I got a Citi Double Cash card, and I couldn't be happier with it. The 2% cash back is very easy to understand and I've gotten around 12% return on my investment.I never wanted to be a "points" person. I'd just rather have my cash than points. I didn't want to have to spend 10 hours in an airport looking at an offer board. I just wanted my money. The Citi Double Cash card delivers.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm a little confused with all of the various options.There's also the Chase Sapphire Preferred (http://www.chase.com/credit-cards/credit-cards/sapphire-preferred) which seems to be one of the best.As you might imagine, we have a lot of readers here with strong opinions on the subject. Let us know which credit card is your favorite and why!It's no surprise that I picked the AMEX Blue Cash card. With a 3% cash back on gas, 2% on groceries and 1% on everything else, you can do a lot of shopping and earn a decent amount. On the other hand, Chase has a great card, but I'd rather pay the 4% interest rate over the 2% cash back.If you're interested in getting a credit card, check out our best credit cards page which will point you in the right direction.Best Credit Card for Everyone?What's the Best Credit Card for Everyone?Readers, what's the best credit card that offers a low interest rate, no annual fee, and cash rewards? Please let us know in the comments.While there are a number of credit cards with no annual fees, few have the features of the AMEX Blue Cash. The interest rate is also very competitive.We need to distinguish between a rewards credit card and a cash back credit card. If you need to carry a balance for several months and plan to make some purchases for which you would like cash back, then the cash back cards are definitely for you. If you need a card with lower interest rates for carrying a balance, then a card like the Citi DoubleCash is better. The reason is that if you carry a balance over several months, you are not only paying a higher interest rate, but also paying interest on interest.Cash back cards are best for those who do not carry a balance over several months. There are cards like this which don't charge you interest if you pay your balance in full.As for cash back cards, there are two main types. One is for purchases only, while the other allows you to earn rewards on certain purchases. For example, the Citi ThankYou Preferred is a card which allows you to earn a 10% bonus on purchases at Citi Supermarkets and Supercenters. It also has a 1% cash back reward on other purchases. This is similar to the Chase Freedom card, which also offers rewards on certain purchases. If you prefer a no fee card, check out the Discover It card, which has a 5% cash back bonus on purchases in certain categories.I'd like to hear what readers think. Are there other credit cards that have cash back rewards and no annual fees?I'm thinking about getting the Chase Sapphire Preferred card, but I'm a little confused about the annual fees.I'm trying to decide if it's worth paying the annual fees if the points will be able to cover it in the future, or if I should just avoid the annual fees entirely. Any thoughts on this?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.While no credit card is ever truly free, the Chase Sapphire Preferred is about as close as you'll find. If you can find a no-fee credit card, you'll typically find that it doesn't provide as many perks as the Chase Sapphire Preferred.The card comes with a $0 annual fee and a competitive APR of 15.24 percent to 24.24 percent (variable), based on your creditworthiness. The card also gives you up to 50,000 bonus points after you spend $4,000 in three months.I find the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card is the ideal card to use in place of a debit card because it offers many benefits, such as rewards, travel insurance, and more. I also prefer it because it does not charge an annual fee.Although there's no doubt that the Chase Sapphire Preferred card is a top contender for the best no-fee card, it's not without some drawbacks. For example, you may find that its high rewards rate is only valuable to frequent travelers who prefer to book through Chase's Ultimate Rewards website. You could also run into a situation in which your card isn't accepted, since it isn't part of Visa or MasterCard networks.If you're looking for a credit card with low interest rates, the Chase Freedom Unlimited Card is for you. The card offers a 0 percent intro APR for the first 15 months and then a variable 15.24 percent to 24.24 percent (after the introductory period ends).Although the Chase Freedom Unlimited Card doesn't have an annual fee, it does come with a few cons, such as the fact that you don't receive the same cash back benefits as you would with some of the other cards on this list. This means that if you spend a lot of money on gas, dining out, or entertainment, then this card is probably not going to be your best option.If you're willing to pay a little bit of a fee for perks, then the Capital One Savor Cash Rewards Credit Card might be the card for you. It has a competitive APR of 14.49 to 23.49 percent (variable) and a welcome bonus of $150.One of the perks of the Capital One Savor Cash Rewards Credit Card is that it can be used anywhere that accepts Visa, which is good if you travel frequently. You'll also find that the card comes with a nice rewards rate of 2 percent on dining and entertainment.Although the card offers a lot of advantages, such as free credit score monitoring and an excellent rewards rate, there are a few drawbacks to keep in mind. For example, you'll find that your credit limit is a little bit lower than other cards on this list, and it's limited to $100 in cash back rewards in a month.The Citi Double Cash Card is a good option if you are looking for a credit card that doesn't have an annual fee. In addition to being free, the card also offers some nice perks, including a 1 percent cash back rate on all purchases and a 0 percent intro APR for the first 12 months.You should be aware that the Citi Double Cash Card does not have the same perks as other cards on this list. For example, you'll find that there is no rewards program, so you'll need to do a lot of your own research to figure out how to get the most value out of your purchases.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. You may use it for large and small purchases. The answer to this question is crucial since it enables you to make an informed choice between different financial products. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What would be your personal choice?For me, I love Chase's Sapphire Preferred card which offers a 2% cash back rate, access to Chase's airport lounge network (including AmEx Centurion lounges), and an annual $50 travel reimbursement after spending $3,000 in a year. However, in recent years, Chase's offerings have changed and I've had to cut back a bit. For example, I don't have access to their airport lounges because I'm not a Chase checking account customer. I don't have $3,000+ in spending in a year for my travel reimbursement and the cash back I earn in the card has never paid for anything more than an airport food coma.So, I'm curious to know what credit card would be your first choice? What perks do you get? What rates are you locked into? What interest rates are you paying and how much interest would you like to eliminate?Re: Your #1 Choice Credit CardPost by djpetesky » Tue Nov 21, 2017 6:41 pmI don't have a primary credit card. I have one for emergencies in case my debit card doesn't work, but I also carry cash and don't like using cards as my primary payment method.Post by TGD » Tue Nov 21, 2017 6:48 pmI have a Citi AAdvantage World Elite Mastercard that I use almost exclusively for travel. I do have a second, secondary Chase Sapphire Preferred that I used when I was traveling for work more, but haven't used in years.Post by sscritic » Tue Nov 21, 2017 6:54 pmI use a Chase Freedom Card that earns 5% cash back on rotating categories (up to $1500 in purchases per quarter). That gives me about $150 in cash back per quarter, which I have found to be a useful source of income.I use a Capital One Venture card for travel. I earned enough miles for a one-way ticket to London and a one-way ticket from Los Angeles to Boston.For most of my credit card use, I use the Bank of America Visa (2.6% rebate for $1000 or more per month). I have a $500 credit line and don't have to pay a penalty for paying it off early (I always pay it off every month). I also get a 0% intro rate. I like having a good Visa.If I had to choose, the best would be the Bank of America Visa. I would prefer to have more miles to fly, but I like this card better. I've never had to worry about getting banned for credit card abuse. I also don't have to pay annual fees or penalty fees if I pay off the card early. I think the 0% intro rate is valuable. It allows me to spend a few hundred bucks I may not otherwise spend.Post by dbr » Tue Nov 21, 2017 6:56 pmI have a Chase Sapphire Preferred that I like very much, except that they seem to arbitrarily shut down a cardholder's account every few years. This happened to me twice in recent years, and once to my spouse. The last time it happened to me, it took about two months to restore service.I have another, very old, Chase Visa that I occasionally use, but it is not a primary card for me.The only other primary card I have is a Citi AAdvantage Platinum Select that I also like, though it does not come close to the Sapphire Preferred in any of its features.I have a Bank of America credit card that I like. I have used it for emergency expenses and not had to pay a late payment fee.I used to have the Chase Freedom card and the Chase Sapphire Preferred. I've had to cut back because Chase has changed how they operate.I do believe that if I were to get a new card, it would be the Chase Freedom Unlimited card.Post by rkhusky » Tue Nov 21, 2017 7:01 pmsscritic wrote: ↑I just had to cancel my Chase Freedom card and transfer out. Chase closed my account for being an "unusual" user. Not sure why I was flagged as an unusual user, but it happened to several people I know. I was able to get another card from Chase, but it was just a plain credit card, no bonus.I just signed up for a United credit card.I am pretty sure I don't need to carry a credit card any more, but I do.Post by oldcomputerguy » Tue Nov 21, 2017 7:20 pmI have had a Chase Freedom for many years and used it when I had no other cards. In the last few years I have been issued several cards by Chase, but never a Freedom. I had to call Chase to find out what the Freedom is. When I get another Chase card it will be the Sapphire. I like the idea of 2% back on everything and the free airport lounge access. I also like that Chase has not shut down any of my cards in the last 10 years.Post by The Wizard » Tue Nov 21, 2017 7:27 pmA few years ago, Chase had a promotion where you could earn 50k Chase points (now I think it's 60k Chase points) in a year. I figured it would be fun to do.My choice was the Chase Sapphire Preferred. However, my wife was denied the Chase Sapphire Preferred because she got the offer 2 weeks earlier than me. I had to use the Ink Preferred instead because I was late to the party and missed out.It turned out that I actually like the Ink Preferred better than the Chase Sapphire Preferred. I got the Ink Preferred when it first came out and the Ink Unlimited when that card was introduced.The Chase Sapphire Preferred offers 2 points per dollar for everything. You can redeem the points for 1.25 cents each. However, you have to pay $1,000 every year in purchase to get the 2 point rate. You will get 1.5 points per dollar if you pay more than $1,000 every year.The Ink Preferred is my favorite. I'm getting 2 points for everything. I can redeem the points for 1.25 cents each, or I can get 1.5 points for every dollar I spend on business related purchases. I can redeem the points for $50 at Amazon or $75 at Home Depot. The latter is useful for getting things shipped for free.The Ink Unlimited has a 1.5 points for every dollar spent rate. However, you get 1.25 cents per point for redemption and the Ink Unlimited does not get you the 1.5 points per dollar rate if you spend more than $1,000 every year.I find the Ink Preferred to be better than the Chase Sapphire Preferred in nearly every way, except for the $1,000 annual spending requirement.I use all 3 Chase cards as primary cards.Post by The Wizard » Wed Nov 22, 2017 9:21 amsscritic wrote: ↑ I do believe that if I were to get a new card, it would be the Chase Freedom Unlimited card.Post by sc9182 » Wed Nov 22, 2017 10:34 amPost by Mister Imperceptible » Wed Nov 22, 2017 12:42 pmI was a Chase Ink Unlimited customer (and now ex-customer) for many years. I liked the 1.5X for all categories and then 2X on the first $150,000 spent on travel and shipping/online purchases per calendar year. It worked out really well for me (and Chase) - my rewards were almost always $150,000 or less.I still had a Sapphire Preferred card - it was a gift from Chase after my Ink account closed. So, I used that card to earn the 50,000 points. Chase didn't like me having 2 Chase Visa cards, so they closed my Sapphire Preferred account.I'm an AmEx guy now. I have the Blue Cash Everyday card and the Platinum card. The Blue Cash is a no-brainer for me - 6% on groceries, 3% on gas, and 1% on everything else. If you have a targeted offer for a big sign-up bonus, you can get a lot of $ back from groceries alone.The Platinum card has many benefits, but the one I use the most is the Centurion lounge access. They are great lounges, and if I have a long layover with kids, it can be a lifesaver. I'll also use it for other perks like room upgrades or free breakfast.Post by sc9182 » Wed Nov 22, 2017 3:31 pmThe Wizard wrote: ↑ I just had to cancel my Chase Freedom card and transfer out. Chase closed my account for being an "unusual" user. Not sure why I was flagged as an unusual user, but it happened to several people I know. I was able to get another card from Chase, but it was just a plain credit card, no bonus.Yep. They will only issue you one. I believe the reason for closing accounts is if they see you opening and closing a lot of cards, they think you're a churner.I've never had a churning problem, but I'm on my 3rd bank and credit card in as many years. And that's just because I got an offer I couldn't refuse.I got 60,000 United miles when I applied for their credit card. I also get 2 miles per $1 spent and I have two roundtrip upgrades and three night stays that I can use whenever.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Here's a breakdown of some of my favorite offers:• 0% APRYou can lock in a 0% APR for 6 months with the BankAmericard Credit Card. You will need to make a minimum monthly payment of $10 (the card has no annual fee).• Rewards programThe Barclaycard Ring MasterCard offers a rewards program that allows you to earn 1 point for every $1 spent (or 2.25% cash back) on purchases. You can also earn bonus points for online shopping and gas purchases. Points can be redeemed as cash back, gift cards or donations to charity.• 15% cash backThe American Express Cash Back Credit Card offers a simple way to earn 15% cash back at stores and on purchases (or 10% at restaurants and for travel) with no annual fee.• Free TSA PreCheck membershipThe Southwest Rapid Rewards Premier Credit Card gives you an automatic TSA PreCheck membership ($85 value) for the life of your card membership. You'll also earn double the Rapid Rewards points on Southwest Airlines purchases.• $50 cash back bonusYou'll get a $50 cash back bonus after making $500 in purchases within the first three months of card membership.• 2% cash back at restaurantsThe Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express offers 6% cash back at U.S. supermarkets on up to $6,000 in spending per year (then 1%). You'll also earn 3% cash back on select U.S. streaming services, transit, and gas and 1% cash back on other purchases.Which card do you like best?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I've been using the Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card for several years now and love its low interest rate (1.99%), 2% cash back on purchases, and ability to transfer cash to a wide variety of frequent flyer programs and hotel rewards programs. However, a reader recently told me he prefers the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card because of its flexible travel rewards program.And with so many options on the market (including the new Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express), I wanted to see what you think is the best credit card available. Let us know which card you prefer, and if you have any comments about the survey, please feel free to share them below.It appears that the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card has been selected by a plurality of readers. Interestingly, this card has the highest average credit limit and the highest average interest rate among all cards listed, yet people appear to like its rewards and low interest rate.While the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card seems to offer the best combination of perks and low interest rate, I think many readers may not know that they can earn cash back on their purchases. For example, a Capital One representative told me that customers using the VentureOne Credit Card are earning 10 times more cash back than customers using other major travel cards. You can earn 1.25% cash back on everything, which adds up to a whopping $4,000 per year. The VentureOne Credit Card also offers a lower interest rate (11.24%-21.24%) and no foreign transaction fees.What's the best credit card available?I have two questions: 1) why didn't the Citi Hilton HHonors Card make the cut, and 2) do you find the Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express to be a good alternative to the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card?The Citi Hilton HHonors Card was removed from the survey since we don't accept credit cards that offer airline mileage or car rental bonuses. This is an issue of fairness because we're only asking readers to select the credit card they feel offers the best combination of perks and low interest rates.There is an exception, however, to our rule about airline mileage bonuses. We've listed the Starwood Preferred Guest American Express Card because it offers some of the best travel perks and is one of the few cards that is not affiliated with a major airline.I haven't tested the Blue Cash Preferred Card, but it does appear to offer some of the best cash back on purchases for certain people. It charges an annual fee of $75, and offers 3% cash back on certain purchases. If this card works for your spending habits, it's probably the best deal available.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm currently considering the Chase Freedom card, which offers 5% cash back for groceries, gas, dining, and drugstore purchases up to $1,500 per quarter (then 1% thereafter). Does this seem like a good offer, or is there something better out there? I appreciate your thoughts.There are a number of different credit cards out there with a variety of different perks, rewards, and features. If you're considering the Chase Freedom, I think it's a pretty great card to have in your wallet.The Chase Freedom offers 5% cash back on groceries, gas, dining, and drugstores. This is quite a bit more than what many other cash-back cards offer. It also has no annual fee, and the ability to earn an unlimited amount of cash-back.One of the most important things to know about cash-back cards, and the Chase Freedom specifically, is that you'll earn that cash back on purchases you've made, minus what you've already earned. So if you've spent $2,500 in the first quarter of the year, you'll earn $125 in cash back. The $125 in cash back will automatically go into your bank account, and you'll be able to use it for whatever purpose you like.One of the things that I like most about the Chase Freedom is that it doesn't have an annual fee, which is a huge benefit for me. You'll earn 5% cash back on your purchases for the first $1,500 you spend per quarter, and then 1% thereafter. So if you spend $2,000 per quarter, you'll earn a total of $150. If you spent $2,500, you'd earn $125.One of the most important things you can do with your credit cards is to pay off your balances every month. That way, you'll not only be saving money on interest, but you'll also be earning cash back.As far as interest rates go, I would recommend that you shop around to find the best one for you. There are many different options out there, and you'll want to find one that works best for you and your needs.What should my next steps be?There are a lot of different things you should keep in mind when you're comparing different credit cards. But the one thing that I think is most important to remember is that you'll be earning cash back on your purchases, minus what you've already earned.So, for example, if you spend $2,000 in the first quarter of the year, you'll earn $125 in cash back. If you spent $2,500, you'd earn $125. If you spent $2,000 in the second quarter, you'd earn $75. And if you spent $2,500 in the third quarter, you'd earn $65.If you were to add it all up, you'd earn $125 in cash back on your first $3,000 in purchases, $75 on your second $3,000, $65 on your third $3,000, and $50 on your fourth $3,000.As far as interest rates go, I would recommend that you shop around to find the best one for you. There are many different options out there, and you'll want to find one that works best for you and your needs. You'll also want to check out the different terms and conditions of each card. This will help you determine what card is best for you.I would also recommend that you consider the different features each card offers. For example, some cards have no annual fee, while others do. Some cards have more perks than others. Some cards have more rewards than others. Some cards have lower interest rates than others.So, as far as what you should do next, I think it's important to shop around, compare different credit cards, and figure out what works best for you. You'll want to compare features, annual fees, interest rates, perks, rewards, and more.Once you've done that, you'll have a much better idea of which credit card is the best one for you.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.I was surprised to see the Amex Delta cards topping the list of the best cards based on the benefits they offer. And as for selling mattresses, my brother has been dealing with that company for 20 years or so and has never had a bad experience with Amex.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. The list of options is pretty long: There are cards that give you 0% interest for up to 15 months (and then only 13.99% after that), cards that offer free flights on their anniversary date, cards that give you a discount on movie tickets, cards that offer a free rental car on your birthday, cards that give you a cash back bonus for everyday purchases, cards that waive foreign transaction fees, cards that give you a 10% discount on Amazon, and so on.If you can afford to pay your balance off in full every month, the best card for you is probably one with a great rewards program. For example, I recently opened a Discover More Card with 5% back on rotating categories, like gas stations and restaurants. If you don't have the cash to pay off your bill in full every month, it makes sense to find a card with the lowest interest rate possible. For example, I've seen a card with 0% APR for the first 15 months and then only 13.99% after that. But it's possible to find an even lower rate with a card like the Bank of America's Travel Rewards card.All of these options, as well as some that haven't been mentioned, are available on BestCards.com. Just be sure to read the fine print, since the terms and conditions can vary widely between different cards.The 15 Best Credit Card Sign Up Bonuses</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm talking about credit cards that can be used to purchase anything from groceries to travel, and that also offer a decent cash back or reward program. Here are my top picks.Chase Freedom offers a $150 bonus for signing up and spending $500 within the first three months of opening an account, as well as 1.5% cash back for all your purchases. This card also offers 5% cash back on select purchase categories every quarter. There is no annual fee.Capital One offers a $200 cash bonus when you open an account and make your first purchase within three months. You'll also receive 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first 15 months, with no annual fee.Citibank's ThankYou Rewards is another credit card worth considering. It comes with a $300 cash bonus when you spend $1,500 within the first three months. You'll earn 2% cash back on gas purchases, 1% cash back on grocery store purchases and 1% cash back on all other purchases, and there are no annual fees.Bank of America's Cash Rewards card offers a $100 cash bonus when you open an account and spend $500 within three months. You'll also earn 3% cash back on grocery store purchases and 2% cash back on gas purchases for the first six months. There is no annual fee.Chase Slate offers 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first 15 months, with no annual fee.Capital One offers 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first six months, with no annual fee.Capital One offers 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first 15 months, with no annual fee.Discover it card offers 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first six months, with no annual fee.Bank of America offers 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first 18 months, with no annual fee.Bank of America offers 0% APR on balance transfers and new purchases for the first 15 months, with no annual fee.Hopefully this helps you in your search for a new credit card. Just be sure to read the fine print.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. Here's my short list of the top 5 best credit cards, but it doesn't mean that these are the best for everyone. So please share your own opinions in the comments section.1. Citi Forward Card with ThankYou PointsProbably the best all-around credit card is Citi Forward with ThankYou Points, which has one of the highest cash back rates around:0% APR for 12 months on purchases.1% cash back on all purchases.$200 sign-up bonus for new cardholders.2. Chase Freedom Card2.5% cash back on the first $1500 spent each quarter at one of 5 different merchants of your choosing.0% APR for 15 months on balance transfers.3. USAA Visa Card6.25% cash back on all gas and grocery purchases.0% APR for 18 months on balance transfers and 0% APR for 6 months on purchases.$200 sign-up bonus if you spend $1000 in your first 3 months.4. PenFed Visa Signature Rewards2.5% cash back on the first $1500 spent each quarter at one of 5 different merchants.5. Capital One Cash Rewards5.0% cash back on all purchases for the first 6 months.3.0% cash back on gas and supermarkets for the first 6 months.0% APR for 12 months on balance transfers.2.5% cash back for new cardholders for the first 6 months.Citi ForwardI believe that the Citi Forward is one of the best credit cards for everyday purchases, and I'm sure that I'm not alone. With this card you can get 1% cash back for everything, no matter where you're shopping or who you're buying from. This cash back rate is very competitive, and in fact, it is one of the highest rates in the market today.In addition to this cash back rate, you also get a sign-up bonus of $200 if you spend $1000 within the first 3 months of becoming a new cardholder. You get an additional $250 if you have at least 3 other people (other than yourself) sign up for the Citi Forward, and you receive an additional $200 if you refer 3 more people to the Citi Forward, making your total sign-up bonus $650.In addition to this bonus cash back rate, the Citi Forward also gives you an introductory 0% APR on balance transfers for 12 months. The card does not have an annual fee, but you can make 5% balance transfers with a fee of $5 or 3% balance transfers with a fee of $5 or 2%.Because of its 1% cash back rate, 18-month 0% APR on balance transfers, and introductory 12-month 0% APR on purchases, the Chase Freedom Card is probably the best card for someone with a substantial amount of debt. I think it is especially good if you have large medical expenses.The Chase Freedom card is a "category card", so you can earn extra cash back if you choose specific merchants where you do a lot of shopping. Every quarter, you choose the merchants that you shop at most, and you get a percentage back on every dollar you spend. You get 1.5% cash back on one of the five merchants of your choice. The other 3 merchants are chosen at random, and you will get 1.0% cash back for purchases at these merchants. The merchants change every three months, so you'll have a chance to try out new places to shop.Here is a list of all of the 5 merchants and their rewards for 2009:Food & Drug Stores (includes restaurants) - 5%Automotive Maintenance/Repair - 5%Home Improvement - 5%Department Stores - 5%General Merchandise - 5%You will get a cash bonus of $150 if you spend $500 in the first 3 months. If you refer 2 other people to sign up for the Chase Freedom Card, you will get an extra $50 cash bonus. If you refer 10 other people to sign up for the Chase Freedom Card, you will get a $100 cash bonus.I believe that USAA is one of the best credit cards in the market, and I think that their Visa Signature Rewards card is the best card for a USAA member, because of its 6.25% cash back on gas and groceries. This is in addition to its 1% cash back rate on all other purchases. The 6.25% gas and grocery cash back rate is really good, and it is much higher than most other cash back credit cards.The USAA Visa card also offers you 0% APR for 18 months on balance transfers. If you are interested in getting a balance transfer, you will have to contact USAA by phone for more information. USAA will not tell you the details of its balance transfer offer, and they will not transfer any balance transfers until you talk to a live person at USAA.This is the perfect credit card for anyone who spends a lot of money at the gas station or grocery store, and I think that this card should be an important part of any financial plan. You have to be a USAA member to get this card, but if you are a military member or the spouse or dependent child of a military member, then you are probably eligible for USAA membership.This is a great cash back card for someone who spends a lot of money at grocery stores or gas stations. In addition to its 1% cash back rate on all purchases, you also get 5.0% cash back for the first 6 months on gas and supermarkets.You get a sign-up bonus of $200 if you spend $1000 in the first 3 months. If you spend an additional $1000 in the next 3 months, you get an additional $250. If you refer 3 people to become new PenFed cardholders, you will receive an extra $200 cash bonus. If you refer 10 people to become new cardholders, you will receive an extra $250 cash bonus. If you get your spouse, parents, grandparents, or any other relatives to sign up for the card, you can get a $200 referral bonus for each relative who signs up.5. Capital One Cash RewardsI believe that the Capital One Cash Rewards card is one of the best credit cards for everyday shopping. You get a 5.0% cash back rate for the first 6 months, which means that you will be able to save a lot of money. The introductory 5.0% cash back rate is especially good if you do a lot of shopping at places like Wal-Mart, Target, or Kmart.Capital One will not tell you the details of its bonus cash back rate until you have talked to a live person. To qualify for the 5.0% cash back rate, you have to make at least 2 purchases per week. Capital One will not tell you which purchases you need to make to qualify for the 5.0% cash back rate, and they will not give you a cash bonus until you make your first purchase.Capital One will not let you transfer your balance to the Capital One Cash Rewards card until you have a credit score of at least 720. Capital One has a different credit score range than the rest of the credit card companies, and if you have a low credit score, then Capital One might not let you transfer your balance.6.0% cash back for the first 6 months, which is especially good for grocery and gas purchases.This is a great cash back card for anyone who spends a lot of money at the grocery store, but it does not offer as high of a cash back rate as the USAA card. This card also has a 0% APR for 12 months on balance transfers.I don't think that this card is the best card for a USAA member, because USAA offers a higher cash back rate and a lower 0% APR for balance transfers.What's the best credit card for you?I don't think that the best credit card is for everyone. If you have good credit and are able to pay off your credit card balance each month, then I think that any of the above cards will be great for you. But if you are just starting out and have a low credit score, then I don't think that any of the above cards are going to be the best choice for you.If you have poor credit, then I would recommend that you look at the Capital One card. It is the only card that allows you to make a balance transfer even if you have a low credit score. This card has a lower cash back rate than other cash back credit cards, but it has a higher 0% APR for balance transfers.If you don't mind spending some time learning how to manage your money, then I think that you should look at the USAA Visa Signature Rewards card. This card has the highest cash back rate that I've ever seen, and it also has a lower 0% APR for balance transfers. This card is not available to everyone, and you have to be a USAA member to get it. But if you do sign up for the USAA Visa card, I think that it will be well worth your time.What's the best credit card for you? Let me know in the comments section below.What's the best credit card for you? I've used all of the cards on my list, and I think that the Citi Forward is the best card for everyday purchases. It has a 1% cash back rate for everything, and it also has a 18-month 0% APR for balance transfers. If you spend a lot of money at gas stations or grocery stores, then I think that the USAA Visa card is the best card for you. It has a 6.25% cash back rate on gas and groceries, and it also has a 0% APR for balance transfers. If you're looking for a great cash back rate, then I think that the Capital One Cash Rewards card is the best card for you. It has a 5.0% cash back rate for the first 6 months, which is especially good for grocery and gas purchases.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. You know, the best-of-the-best credit card.I've put together the results of my own little poll in this post, and I'd love to hear your thoughts as well.I believe the Best-Of-The-Best Credit Card would have a relatively low interest rate, with the flexibility to carry a balance without having to pay a fee. I'd also like the ability to earn cashback rewards on my purchases, and possibly enjoy some perks such as travel insurance.What would you include as key features of the Best-Of-The-Best credit card?When considering the Best-Of-The-Best credit card, which of these features is most important?What does the best-of-the-best credit card have?How often do you use your credit card?How much do you carry on your credit card?Which statement below best describes your credit score?I would like to have my credit score improved.What other features would you include on your Best-Of-The-Best credit card?What do you think? Are there any key features you'd include on the Best-Of-The-Best credit card? If so, share them with us!I think I’m going to go with the RBC Avion Visa. It has a 1.99% rate, a 15,000 sign up bonus, and you get to pay with any Canadian credit card. I think that’s the best combination of perks, low interest rates and financial flexibility.I like this blog a lot. I think you should look into your BBB card. It sounds like you are describing my credit card with your poll. I also get to use a Canadian credit card and it has no fee. If I am going to carry a balance, which I do often, I don’t want to pay more in interest than I have to. I don’t travel internationally but I love the insurance. I would take this poll again.Hey Nicole – Thanks for the comment. If you don’t mind me asking, what’s the best part of your Avion Visa?I don’t mind. I think the flexibility is the best part. The 1.99% rate is great but it’s a rate only. If I’m going to pay something, I want to pay something small. The 15,000 sign up bonus is also great. It’s great because it’s not too much but it’s more than the minimum. And finally, if I have a choice between a Canadian credit card and an international one I would choose the Canadian one every time.Hi Nicole, thanks for commenting. I agree – the flexibility of the Avion Visa is really nice. And the signup bonus is definitely one of the most appealing features.I think the Avion Visa is the best credit card. The interest rate is only .99% and you can use your Canadian credit card anywhere. I also like the fact that I can earn more than just the 1.99% interest rate. I like that I can choose any of the different types of rewards such as cash back or travel miles. This card also has no balance transfer fee, no annual fee and no foreign transaction fee.I think the best credit card has the most benefits.I’m curious to see the results of this poll.I am really glad you asked this question! I think we’re all getting more and more confused by the plethora of credit cards out there. What makes this one the best for me may not make it the best for you. And, if your credit score is not good enough to get approved for this card, then what are you to do?As for my best credit card, I have no idea what you have in mind, so I don’t know which one is best for me.You could always have a credit score of 700 and get rejected for a credit card because they think you’re too risky!I find that when I go looking for credit cards, they are all marketed at me, and I don’t know if they’re good for me. So I don’t want to spend too much time comparing. I just want to find a card that’s good for me.I’m with Kirsten on this one. We all know what is good for us. There is a reason why there are so many credit cards out there. If I can only choose one card, it’s going to be my best one. I can still be frugal if I know the card gives me perks. So I can’t compare and see which is best for me. That’s why I just go for it. If I can get approval for it, I’ll be happy to have it.I’m with Kirsten and Debra on this. I’ve found that the credit card I currently have works great for me. There are times when I may need to do a balance transfer, but that is the only time I use my card. I can always find a way to pay for things and use cash or a debit card. That is why I am not interested in a balance transfer card.I am a person who likes to save money. That’s why I choose the Scotiabank Momentum Visa card. I have been with them for years and I like their cash back perks. I like that I can transfer my rewards into my Scotiabank bank account and use it for whatever I want. They also offer a lot of different perks including insurance and car rental protection. I think that is really nice. I would say that the Scotiabank Momentum Visa card is the best credit card out there right now.If I’m going to be carrying a balance I want to be sure to use my Scotiabank Momentum Visa as it has the lowest rate on the market and the flexibility to use anywhere in the world and I can save even more money by earning the 5% cashback in categories I spend in!That is why I would say the Momentum Visa is the best of the best credit card.There’s definitely a lot of confusion with all the credit cards out there.I’m with you guys – I believe the Scotiabank Momentum Visa card is the best choice. What do you think?I am a little nervous about carrying a balance. It is never a good thing. If I have to carry a balance I would rather it was as low as possible. So I think the best credit card would have the lowest interest rate possible, and I would also like to get a credit card that offers more benefits to me than any other credit card out there. I think that is the best way to go about this.I have never had to pay a balance transfer fee so it’s not important to me.When choosing a credit card I always look at interest rates. The Momentum Visa has the lowest in Canada and with the balance transfer fee waived I save even more!I have been using my Momentum Visa since 2006 and have never paid a balance transfer fee.There’s no better time to signup for your Scotiabank Momentum Visa and take advantage of their 0% balance transfer rate!I agree. I’m all about low interest rates and perks, and the Scotiabank Momentum Visa is definitely the best option in that regard. What’s your reason for choosing that credit card?Hey Scott! Great comment. I’m glad to hear you’re a big fan of the Scotiabank Momentum Visa. I’m also a big fan. What’s your reason for choosing this credit card?This poll needs some more options.I like the Scotiabank Momentum Visa. I’m not sure I would call it the best of the best, but it’s a very good choice for people who want cash back with the ability to use it anywhere in the world.Great poll idea! My favorite card so far has been the MBNA Platinum Plus MasterCard. It has a relatively low rate, great perks (free rental car insurance, etc.) and a pretty decent cashback program. I’m also pretty good about paying off my credit card balances on time each month, so I don’t need a card that has to offer me a low interest rate. I would say that the MBNA Platinum Plus MasterCard was the Best-Of-The-Best credit card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.We've compared the top 11 credit cards on the market and narrowed them down to the top three. If you don't have a credit card yet, check out this comparison to determine which one best suits your needs.What we like: We think it's hard to top this card for overall financial flexibility. It features a 0% APR introductory period that's among the longest on the market, no annual fee, and an excellent credit limit. If you have a lot of credit card debt, this card is also an excellent choice for consolidating your balances.What we don't like: This card does not offer a rewards program.Our take: This card offers the longest 0% introductory period among cards with no annual fees. It's also an excellent choice if you're looking to consolidate high-interest credit card debt.What we like: We think this card offers the lowest interest rates among cards with no annual fees. It's also easy to qualify for the card, making it a good choice for those with fair credit. Plus, you earn 2% cash back on purchases made directly from Amazon.com.What we don't like: There's no sign-up bonus for the card. Plus, there's a limit to how much cash back you can earn and no interest-free period on new purchases.Our take: If you're looking to earn cash back on your Amazon.com purchases, this is a good card to consider. It's also an excellent choice for those who have fair credit.Which Credit Card is the Best?I think the best credit card is the Capital One SavorOne card, and here's why:The Capital One SavorOne card offers a 0% APR introductory period for new purchases and balance transfers. You also get a $500 cash bonus if you spend $3,000 in the first three months and 3% cash back for every dollar spent on dining and entertainment.The card also has no annual fee, so you can use it without worrying about additional costs. Plus, it has a low interest rate, which means that you won't be hit with high interest payments if you carry a balance from one month to the next.The Capital One SavorOne card is also great for those with bad credit. It offers an 18.99% APR (subject to change), which is much lower than what you would pay on a credit card with no annual fee.Finally, the Capital One SavorOne card is one of the few cards that offer a rewards program. This program gives you points that you can use for cash back or travel rewards. You can also transfer your points to airline miles or hotel points.The Capital One SavorOne card is also great for those who want to earn cash back. You get 3% cash back for every dollar spent on dining and entertainment. This is a great deal because it's one of the few cards that offer this kind of bonus.The Capital One SavorOne card is also good for those who want to consolidate their debt. This is because it has a low interest rate and no annual fee. It also offers a 0% APR introductory period for new purchases and balance transfers.In conclusion, the Capital One SavorOne card is a great option for those who want a credit card with a 0% APR introductory period for new purchases and balance transfers. It also has no annual fee and a low interest rate. Finally, it has a rewards program that gives you points that you can use for cash back or travel rewards.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. There's no shortage of options, but it comes down to preference and how much you value the perks on one card versus another.I use the Chase Sapphire Reserve Card, which has a $450 annual fee but reimburses me for $300 in travel expenses, including lodging. The 50% off Lyft rides and airport lounges is a huge plus, as well as the 3x points for travel purchases. With the exception of the annual fee, this card is a no-brainer for someone who likes to travel, especially internationally.Personally, I don't know anyone who's complained about how much they've saved on interest rates after switching to a new card. It really comes down to individual preferences and personal finance goals. Do you prefer the flexibility that a no-fee, 0% APR card offers? If so, then you can always pay off your debt before the intro rate expires.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. There is a new American Express card, called The Platinum Card®, that sounds quite impressive. It offers $450 in airline credits per year, a $200 Uber credit every year, and five points for every dollar you spend on flights and hotels (and one point for every other dollar you spend). There's even $100 credit towards your hotel stay, and $100 in Saks Fifth Avenue credits each year.I've done a lot of searching, but so far I haven't come up with another credit card that seems to offer such an impressive combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility.Anyone familiar with other cards that compare?</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I have been using American Express's SimplyCash Card for Business since 2013, which is a flat-rate card that offers 5% back on all spending in its preferred categories (office supplies, cell phones, and cable and satellite) and 1% back on all other purchases. The card also has no annual fee and no introductory interest rate offers. The only drawback is that it's not a travel rewards card, which I would prefer. My business expenditures are generally not large enough to justify paying interest.A new option is Chase's Ink Plus Business Card, which offers 5% back on certain purchases (office supplies and cell phones), 2% back on gas and office supplies, and 1% back on all other purchases. The card also offers 2 points for every dollar spent, which can be redeemed for travel rewards. There is no annual fee or introductory interest rate offer.I'd be curious to know if you have any suggestions for an even better combination of perks, low interest rates, and financial flexibility. I'm not interested in paying an annual fee for the privilege of earning rewards, as I find that the annual fee is often higher than what I would earn.Ask an Expert: Which is the best business credit card?I would argue that the Chase Ink Plus Business card (link to chase.com) is the best business credit card you can find. The 5% back that you mention is true. But, the 5X rewards you earn is even better. It's 5x on travel and select business categories. It's 2X on gas and office supplies, and 1X on all other purchases.I would agree with your assessment that the American Express Business SimplyCash Card (link to amex.com) is also a good option. I would consider this one of the best options out there as long as you don't plan on using it much for travel.In order to take advantage of the 5% cash back bonus, you will have to purchase the card's required amount in the specified time period. This can be done in one large purchase, or you can simply buy it over time until you reach that threshold. The important thing to remember is that once you make that initial purchase, you don't have to spend any more money on the card in order to get 5% cash back!The American Express SimplyCash Business card also offers 5% cash back on some select categories, as well as 1% cash back on all other purchases. While there is no annual fee for this card, you should be aware that there is an introductory rate of 0% for the first 6 months. After that, the APR will be variable and could range from 15.24% to 24.24% depending on your creditworthiness.If you don't mind paying an annual fee, then I would recommend the Chase Freedom Unlimited credit card (link to chase.com). It offers 5% cash back on travel and dining purchases, as well as 3% cash back on drugstore and home improvement store purchases, and 1% cash back on all other purchases. There is no sign-up bonus for this card, but it does offer a 0% introductory APR for the first 12 months.Both the Chase Ink Plus Business card and the American Express SimplyCash Business card are great options for those who want to earn rewards on their business purchases.The Chase Ink Plus Business card offers a 5% cash back on office supply and cell phone purchases, 2% cash back on gas station and hotel/motel purchases, and 1% cash back on all other purchases. There is no annual fee for this card, but you will need to have good credit in order to qualify for the 5% cash back bonus.The American Express SimplyCash Business card offers a 5% cash back on all purchases made in the first 3 months from account opening, then 1% cash back on all other purchases made during the remainder of the year. There is no annual fee for this card, but you will need to have good credit in order to qualify for the 5% cash back bonus.If you're looking for a low-interest rate credit card for business use, the Chase Ink Plus Business card is definitely worth considering. With no annual fee and 0% introductory APR for 12 months, it's a great option for those who need to finance a large purchase or want to take advantage of the 5% cash back bonus on office supplies and cell phone purchases.</s>

The Citi Double Cash cardThe Citi Double Cash card is an excellent option if you're looking for a simple card with no annual fees.This particular card comes with a $0 annual fee and earns you a 1% cashback rate when you make a purchase and another 1% cashback rate when you pay for that purchase. The Amex EveryDay Preferred cardThe Amex EveryDay Preferred card is a great card for those who want a simple credit card with no annual fees.This particular card comes with a $0 annual fee and earns you a 2x points rate on purchases at US supermarkets on up to $6,000 per year (then 1x) and a 1x point rate on all other purchases. It also offers a $100 annual airline fee credit, which is helpful if you use this card to pay for travel-related expenses.The Amex EveryDay Preferred card has a $0 annual fee and earns you a 2x points rate on purchases at US supermarkets on up to $6,000 per year (then 1x) and a 1x point rate on all other purchases. It also offers a $100 annual airline fee credit, which is helpful if you use this card to pay for travel-related expenses.It's important to note that all of these cards come with various fees and charges, so make sure you read the terms and conditions before you apply for any of them.</s>
