<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. You're unlikely to find a credit card that ticks all of these boxes, but I suspect that some of you may have managed to find something pretty decent. If you'd like to share the results of your research, feel free to jump into the comments below.Credit cards aren't all bad - they're a pretty useful financial tool as long as you can take advantage of them appropriately. When used responsibly, they can be a great way to rack up points and miles or to make purchases without paying for them all at once. Credit cards also make it a lot easier to build your credit score. So, when it comes to rewards, do you have a preference?I'm currently using the Barclays Arrival Plus World Elite MasterCard, which gives me an impressive 50,000 miles for spending $3,000 in three months. I haven't been happy with the lack of credit line increase, and Barclays is notoriously stingy about extending credit, but the sign-up bonus is just too good to pass up.The Chase Sapphire Preferred is another card that provides significant value for new cardholders, and you can get a $500 bonus for spending $4,000 in three months.Sometimes, though, it's better to focus on a no-frills option with a low interest rate and straightforward terms. In my opinion, the Citi Diamond Preferred is one of the best cards available for this purpose. The 21.49% APR is high by today's standards, but it's not hard to pay it off within a year if you're disciplined about your budget.Do you have a favorite credit card or are you willing to share your card rewards strategy?Happy 10th birthday to The Simple Dollar!I do have a favorite credit card and I’ve written about it in a few other places. That would be the no annual fee Chase Freedom Unlimited card.This is the card that is the most flexible for me. I use this card for all of my day to day spending – grocery stores, gas, utilities, eating out, etc.I also have the Chase Freedom Unlimited in my wife’s wallet and it is the card that she uses the most. She is also able to earn 1.5% back on the money she is spending.It is pretty rare to find a card that offers this flexibility and simplicity.For me, this card also has a very simple sign up bonus. All you have to do is spend $500 within 3 months of opening the card to receive the $150 sign up bonus. You can also earn a one time $200 referral bonus by having one of your friends apply with your referral code.Since this is the card that I use most often, I always keep an eye on the bonus categories. These are usually rotating and there is a different category each quarter.These categories are great for racking up some extra points in the year. Last year, I was able to earn 10,000 points in the first 3 months because I spent more on dining than normal and I was also able to earn 10,000 points because I spent a lot of money on Amazon in the fourth quarter.The Chase Freedom Unlimited is a no annual fee card and I have not had a single fee charged to my account since I’ve been using it. There is no foreign transaction fee and there is also no minimum balance or minimum spending requirement.Beyond the bonus categories, Chase has also introduced something called “QuickPay.” This is a feature that you can enable in the app and this enables you to pay any Chase card, including the Freedom Unlimited, with Venmo and PayPal.This is one of the best credit cards that I’ve ever had. It is very flexible and the rewards are good. If you’re trying to build credit, I would recommend this card over others.That said, I don’t think I’d ever pay $150 for a sign up bonus. There are cards that have much higher bonuses and I’d definitely give those cards a shot before jumping on this one.I really like the Citi Double Cash. I have the old version that earned 2% cashback, but the newer version earns 1%. I got it a few months ago after my 0% balance transfer deal ran out. I still have a few hundred dollars in balance transfer debt on the card, but I pay it off as quickly as I can, which helps me avoid paying interest.I use it for pretty much everything, except for travel and I don’t have any other cards that have a travel rewards option. I like how easy the cashback is to use and I don’t have to worry about bonus categories, minimum spending, etc.I also like the no annual fee and no balance transfer fees. I don’t plan to keep it long term. I plan to pay off my balance in a few months, then close the account and move it to a different bank.I had the Barclays Arrival card and the no annual fee Chase Sapphire for a while, but I found that I wasn’t getting very good rewards from the Chase Sapphire so I canceled it. I didn’t like how the Chase Ultimate Rewards point system was set up. I wanted to use points to make travel reservations and it was always a hassle to make those reservations through Chase.I also had the Freedom Unlimited, but I cancelled that one because I wanted to get rid of one of my Chase cards (the no annual fee Freedom card).I think it’s better to keep the Chase Sapphire Unlimited, even though it does have a fee, than to go with the no annual fee Freedom card. It has the sign up bonus and it has the 2% bonus on dining and travel, which is great.It also has no foreign transaction fees and I like the $0 fee on balance transfers, but the one negative thing is the 1.5% fee on all transactions. That can add up over the course of a year if you’re not careful.The Barclays Arrival card is fine for getting a 50,000 mile sign up bonus, but I think the Chase Sapphire has a lot more value if you want to spend it on travel.For me, the best cashback credit card is the Citi Double Cash because it’s easy to use, no annual fee, no foreign transaction fees and no interest charges. It’s pretty easy to use and I always use it to make purchases because of the 2% cashback. I also have the Citi Double Cash at two different addresses and it’s easy to manage.My second favorite cashback card is the Citi Simplicity card, which earns 1% cashback on everything. I don’t use it as much because I don’t spend a lot on it, but I also don’t carry a balance.When I do use the Citi Simplicity card, I also like that it has no interest charges and no late fees, which makes it perfect for keeping my credit utilization low and for paying my balance off quickly to avoid paying interest.I like that I can set up autopay with my bank account to make payments automatic and it’s also easy to set up with autopay. I don’t use my Citi Simplicity card very often, but I use the Citi Double Cash card all the time. I use it to buy groceries and pay for everyday expenses. I don’t need to do anything special to get rewards, I just make the purchases and I get the rewards. It’s pretty simple and I like it a lot.The no annual fee Chase Freedom Unlimited card is the best cashback card I’ve ever had. It earns 1.5% cashback on everything, but the most it can earn in one quarter is 2% cashback, which is great.I like that it earns cashback on all purchases and I can get the cashback in the form of a statement credit, a bank account transfer, a gift card, a check, or a direct deposit into my checking account. It’s really easy to use and I just like the rewards that I get from it. I like that it has no foreign transaction fees and that there is no interest charged on purchases. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. You have a number of options, so let's look at some of your options.Chase Sapphire Preferred. For starters, you earn 2x points on travel and dining purchases, 1x point on everything else. You get a 20,000 point bonus if you spend $1,000 in the first 3 months. Points are worth 25 cents each and there is a $95 annual fee.Ink Plus. With the Ink Plus, you earn 5x points for office supply purchases, 2x points for gas purchases, and 1x points on everything else. The Ink Plus also offers $0 balance transfer fees for 12 months and it is one of the few cards that doesn't charge foreign transaction fees. You'll receive a $95 annual fee, but no sign-up bonus.Chase Freedom. With the Freedom, you earn 1% back on purchases and 5% back on rotating categories. This makes it one of the best cards for earning extra cash back on dining and gas purchases. There is a $95 annual fee, but you receive a $100 bonus after you spend $500 in the first 3 months.American Express® Premier Rewards Gold Card. The Premier Rewards Gold earns 2x points at gas stations and restaurants, 1x point on everything else. You get a $100 statement credit if you spend $1,000 in the first 3 months. Points are worth 25 cents each and there is a $175 annual fee.Citi PremierPass. The Citi PremierPass earns 2x points on travel and gas purchases, and 1x point on everything else. There is a $75 annual fee.I have used and currently use the Chase Ink.I love that the signup bonus is the same as everyone elses, and that it doesn't expire.The ability to transfer points to airlines is a huge plus. The travel website is easy to use. I usually get 40k plus a signup bonus per year on a $500 purchase.I use my Citi ThankYou Premier for everything I can. For example, I used it to book an airline ticket for 10,000 ThankYou points. It was the only way to use a Citi credit card to book an airline ticket online.I currently have the Amex Premier Rewards Gold Card (I think I'm on my fourth or fifth card from that series). For my purposes, it offers the best rewards, as I don't mind paying a bit extra in interest to not have to track and redeem points, and I travel enough to meet the $1000 spending requirement every year. It also has the most useful "extra features" of the cards I'm considering. I like that I can have travel and emergency evacuation insurance, a few different kinds of rental car insurance, and no foreign transaction fees. The ability to pay using the card in most foreign countries is nice too (I know that my Discover card will charge me a 3% surcharge for using it in Canada, and there is no fee for using the Amex). I also like the "Pay With Points" feature - I've been trying to find a reason to use it on something expensive like an Apple product (iPad or Apple Watch), but I have yet to find the right opportunity.I have the Chase Sapphire Preferred card. I have earned a ton of free flights and hotel stays for my family and I.My main interest in credit cards is to earn free travel. I currently have the Citi Premierpass card which earns 2 points for every dollar spent. That means a $3,000 spend this year should result in a $1,200 travel credit. I have never spent more than $500 in a year so this card works great for me. I also have the Chase Sapphire Preferred which is another great card as it is tied to the Chase Freedom card which gives me a lot of spending flexibility. I use the Chase Sapphire card for international travel where I get the points and the Chase Freedom for domestic purchases where I get the cash back.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. If you want the best of the best, then this list is definitely for you!Credit cards are among the top financial tools used by Americans today. In fact, the most recent data from the Federal Reserve Bank shows that almost 70 percent of households own at least one credit card.But not all cards are the same, which is why consumers should consider all of the options available to them before choosing one. After all, a credit card can be a major financial resource if you know how to use it correctly!To help you do just that, we’ve compiled the following list of the best credit cards available today.Though the cash back rate is low, there’s no doubt the Chase Freedom Unlimited Card is the best all-around credit card.As the name suggests, the card offers unlimited 1.5% cash back, with no annual fee, no expiration dates, and no caps.The only downside is that this card doesn’t offer a bonus upon signing up. So you’ll need to take some time to rack up enough rewards in order to maximize your returns.Still, if you use your card to pay for groceries, gas, dining, or any other recurring expenses, the 1.5% return rate will soon add up.It also comes with a ton of added perks, including a mobile app, extended warranty protection, roadside assistance, purchase protection, auto rental insurance, and more!The Chase Freedom Unlimited Card is best suited for consumers who use their card to buy everyday items.It’s the perfect card for travelers who can take advantage of its zero liability protection, price protection, trip cancellation/interruption insurance, and travel accident insurance.For travelers, the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card is by far one of the most rewarding credit cards on the market. This travel card offers up to 5X points per dollar on travel and dining, with no cap.If you don’t spend on travel and dining, then your points will still count toward your overall rewards. The card also offers a new 60,000-point bonus (worth $750 in travel rewards) if you spend $4,000 within the first three months of account opening.The Sapphire Preferred Card is one of the best travel credit cards out there because it offers a 25% boost on all points, which means you can redeem your rewards for even more travel.Additionally, this card comes with a number of other great perks, including cell phone protection, purchase protection, extended warranty protection, zero liability protection, travel and emergency assistance, lost luggage reimbursement, and more!This card is best suited for travelers, or anyone who’s looking to maximize their rewards through everyday purchases.Though it’s not the best cash back credit card, the Citi Double Cash Card is one of the most useful and flexible credit cards available.This card offers a 2% cash back rate on all purchases (1% when you make the purchase and another 1% when you pay for the item).The card also features a 0% introductory APR for 18 months on both purchases and balance transfers.There’s no cap on the cash back, so the rewards will continue to accrue as long as you continue to spend.Another reason why the Citi Double Cash Card is the best cash back credit card is that there’s no annual fee, no foreign transaction fees, and no late payment fees.The Citi Double Cash Card is best suited for consumers who spend a lot and like to save big with every purchase.Even though the American Express Platinum Card doesn’t offer any rewards, it’s still a pretty great card.With the Platinum Card, you’ll get automatic travel insurance, travel and emergency assistance, car rental loss and damage insurance, purchase protection, extended warranty protection, and more.In addition, the card offers a host of unique benefits, including airport lounge access, hotel elite status, dining credits, and Uber credits.If you use this card to make purchases, you’ll enjoy up to $200 in Uber credits and up to $200 in hotel credits. Plus, you’ll receive complimentary lounge access when you’re flying, a TSA PreCheck or Global Entry statement credit, and complimentary Delta Sky Club access.The American Express Platinum Card is best suited for business owners and people who travel frequently.The only downside is that it’s a charge card, which means there is no preset spending limit. You simply have to make your minimum payment every month. But the upside is that there are no interest charges.As the name suggests, the Capital One Venture Rewards Card is perfect for anyone who’s always on the road.This travel card offers unlimited 2 miles per dollar on all purchases. The card also offers a new 50,000-mile bonus if you spend $3,000 within the first three months of account opening.What makes this card one of the best travel credit cards is that your miles can be redeemed in any way you like.These rewards can be redeemed as airfare, hotel stays, cruises, gift cards, cash back, or even towards an existing balance. The Venture Rewards Card is also free of foreign transaction fees and charges no annual fee.This card is best suited for business owners and people who are always on the go.There’s also a lower-tiered version of this card, the Capital One VentureOne Card, which features the same rewards system but without the $0 annual fee and the big sign-up bonus.The Capital One Venture Rewards Card is best suited for people who like to redeem their rewards for cash or travel.It’s also ideal for people who want to travel internationally because there are no foreign transaction fees.The U.S. Bank FlexPerks Travel Rewards Visa Card is another excellent travel card that can be used to earn unlimited 1.5x reward points on all purchases.There’s also no expiration date for rewards, no caps on rewards, and no restrictions. The card also features a sign-up bonus of 40,000 points if you spend $4,000 within the first three months of account opening.In addition, the card offers a 25% boost on rewards when redeemed for travel, and an additional 10% when redeemed for gift cards, merchandise, and more.The U.S. Bank FlexPerks Travel Rewards Visa Card is best suited for anyone who wants to earn unlimited rewards on all purchases.But be aware that this card does come with a $40 annual fee, so be sure to factor this cost into your calculations before applying for this card.The Chase Sapphire Reserve Card is another excellent credit card for travelers, as it offers a ton of travel perks.With the Chase Sapphire Reserve Card, you’ll get automatic travel insurance, travel and emergency assistance, cell phone protection, purchase protection, extended warranty protection, zero liability protection, and more.The Chase Sapphire Reserve Card is best suited for travelers who want to maximize their rewards and enjoy all the perks and benefits that come with the card.It’s the perfect credit card for consumers who like to travel internationally because there are no foreign transaction fees.And if you’re planning to apply for the Chase Sapphire Reserve Card, be sure to check your credit report and credit score first.In general, you’ll need a good credit score to qualify for this card. If your credit score is low, you may want to consider some of the other options available, such as the Chase Freedom Unlimited Card or Citi Double Cash Card.And if you do qualify, the rewards you’ll earn can be worth it.The Chase Sapphire Reserve Card also offers a sign-up bonus of 50,000 points if you spend $4,000 within the first three months of account opening. <s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. I'm wondering what you use for your credit card now, and if you have plans to apply for any different cards in the near future.Most people use credit cards for convenience, rewards, and even for their low interest rates. Credit cards, when used appropriately, can be a powerful tool to help build and repair credit scores. In fact, a majority of credit scores are heavily influenced by your payment history.Paying your bill on time each month helps increase your FICO scores, and the higher your FICO score the better your overall credit health. As a matter of fact, a majority of the population would be hard-pressed to get a decent mortgage rate or even a decent interest rate on a personal loan if they had low credit scores. That's why it's important that you understand what's best for you.My wife and I recently applied for and were denied a home equity loan because our FICO scores weren't high enough. It was very disappointing and a real setback because we needed to remodel the basement of our home. We had a couple of options, such as taking a personal loan, but the interest rate would have been exorbitant. Fortunately, I was able to get my FICO score back up to 800. That's good enough to get us a low interest rate on the home equity loan.Credit cards come in all shapes and sizes. And, as such, they offer a wide range of benefits and perks. Credit cards have become an essential part of life in the United States. The convenience, rewards and the low interest rates have caused most people to use credit cards almost exclusively when making purchases.Credit cards have come a long way since their inception over 50 years ago. Nowadays, credit cards are more commonly used by those with low credit scores to help them increase their creditworthiness. In fact, it's not uncommon for people to have scores in the low to mid 600 range, but have credit cards with limit of $15,000 or higher. These cards have helped these consumers build and repair their credit scores.There are many credit card choices for consumers to choose from. But which one is best for you? This is a hard question to answer because of the many features, benefits, and rates associated with credit cards. Each person's financial situation is different. One credit card might be better for someone with a good credit score, while another might be more beneficial for someone with a bad credit score.There are also some credit cards that come with annual fees and other fees, so it's important to weigh the pros and cons of each credit card to make sure it's right for you.Which credit card is the best for your needs? In my opinion, it's all about how much money you make and how often you use it.I know a lot of people who use credit cards to make large purchases and then pay off the balance at the end of the month. However, this isn't always a good idea. There are a few things that you need to consider before using a credit card, such as interest rates, rewards programs, and whether or not it's worth it for you to have the card in the first place.If you want a credit card that has a high rewards program and low interest rate, then you might want to look at Capital One's Venture card. If you want a credit card that gives you cash back on every purchase, then you might want to look at Discover's Cashback Bonus card. If you want a credit card that gives you a lot of flexibility and isn't as expensive as other options, then you might want to look at Amex's Blue Cash Preferred card.I'm not going to make this article too long. In short, I think that the Capital One Venture card is the best credit card for most people. It's got a low annual fee, it has an awesome rewards program, and the interest rate is low compared to other cards.There are two types of people in this world: those who use credit cards and those who don't. For those who don't, they often have a hard time getting a good interest rate on a credit card and are forced to pay cash for most things they purchase.If you're a person who uses credit cards, then you know that there are a ton of great options out there. There are rewards cards, low-interest cards, and even no-annual-fee cards that can help you save money and build credit. But with so many options, it's hard to know which one is best for you.The best credit card for me is the Capital One Venture card. I have been a loyal Capital One customer for years and have never had any issues with them. The Venture card gives me an annual fee of $59, and I can get 2 miles per dollar spent on all purchases (except for airfare and car rentals). I can also transfer my miles to other airlines or hotels if I want to redeem them for a trip.I have a Venture card. I've had it for about a year now, and it's worked great for me. I love the rewards program, and I use it for everything I can. I also love that I can use my points to book flights and hotels, so it's a really versatile card.The only downside is that there's a $59 annual fee, but that's pretty standard for a travel rewards card.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. What card(s) do you recommend?I’ve been a member of both AMEX and Citi’s Dividend Card programs. I’ve received some nice perks and discounts, but have never had much luck getting any of the really great rewards that others have shared in these forums. I was wondering what type of points/cash back rewards programs other folks participate in.How much rewards do you earn on a regular basis?How do you redeem your rewards?Does anyone know of an airline or hotel reward program that provides a lot of rewards for the amount of money spent?I currently receive about $120 in rewards per year through the Citi card. I redeem them through Citi as a statement credit, or to offset the cost of my credit card balance.For air travel I participate in United's mileage program (I love to travel, and I am a frequent United flyer). My primary use is to travel internationally to visit family (especially for trips that include a significant distance such as China, Canada, and Germany). I also get a nice bonus on domestic travel. I've been able to use the miles to get upgrades on certain flights. However, this usually only occurs during peak travel seasons (holidays, summer vacations, etc.).For accommodations I use Hilton HHonors, Marriott, and Hyatt. I’ve used my rewards to stay in luxury hotels in Hawaii, Europe, and California. My rewards have paid for all or part of hotel stays at The Conrad, The Westin, The Hyatt, The Marriott, the Waldorf-Astoria, the Intercontinental, and the Four Seasons.I've found this to be a great perk of these programs.It is my understanding that these programs are very good if your travel is international in nature, but not so useful if you are traveling domestically. If you find yourself in an area of the country with limited air service, you’re probably going to find these programs to be a bit of a pain.</s>

<s> I'm curious to know which credit card you believe offers the best combination of perks, low interest rates, and overall financial flexibility. It's definitely not a fair question. There is no "best credit card," and the best choice for you is different from the best choice for someone else.But if we are talking about a few particular cards that are really good, the two that stand out are the Chase Sapphire Reserve® and Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card.The Sapphire Reserve has long been praised by travel rewards experts. It has the highest annual fee of any of the premium credit cards currently available: $450 per year. But it is jam-packed with perks, such as a $300 annual travel credit, Priority Pass airport lounge membership, and a 50% rebate on TSA Precheck/Global Entry application fees.The $450 annual fee of the Sapphire Reserve is certainly a stumbling block for some, and the card's benefits may not be as valuable to some as to others. For example, the $300 annual travel credit may not be useful to those who do not travel much or prefer to rent a car instead of use ride-share services. If you travel at least three or four times a year, then you can probably take advantage of all the benefits of the Sapphire Reserve. The $300 credit, Priority Pass membership, TSA Precheck credit, $100 Global Entry credit, $100 Global Entry or TSA Precheck application fee credit, and 10x bonus points on Lyft and Uber rides should cover most people's travel-related expenses.You also get the Chase Sapphire Reserve's 50% rebate for Global Entry and TSA Precheck every four years when you pay the application fee. You can also earn 10x points on Lyft and Uber rides. Those who use these services for most or all of their travel needs could easily save a few hundred dollars a year with this benefit.But let's face it: The Sapphire Reserve's biggest benefit is the value of its 50% bonus points on all travel purchases. You get 50% back on every dollar you spend on travel, which you can redeem at 1.5 cents apiece as statement credits, cash, or transfer to frequent flyer miles. It's a very good deal. But it is not a no-cost benefit: Your rewards are worth $750 if you redeem for statement credits or cash, or $375 if you transfer to frequent flyer miles.You get a 50% bonus on points earned from groceries, gas stations, and restaurants, too. But those benefits are available only if you have the Chase Sapphire Preferred card and don't have the Sapphire Reserve card. In that case, you can earn a 10x bonus on your purchases. That's the main reason to get the Preferred card: its $95 annual fee.It's worth noting that the Chase Sapphire Preferred card offers the same 50% bonus points on all travel purchases as the Sapphire Reserve. This benefit does not require the Preferred card to be paid every year. You can still get it if you pay the Sapphire Reserve's $450 annual fee and cancel after the first year.The Sapphire Preferred card does not offer the Sapphire Reserve's 50% rebate for Global Entry and TSA Precheck. But it does have the same 10x points on Lyft and Uber rides, and you also get 2x points on dining and groceries (with a $1,000 quarterly limit).Which card is right for you depends on whether you think the $450 annual fee of the Sapphire Reserve is worth it. And it depends on whether you need or want the benefits of the Sapphire Reserve's 50% bonus on travel purchases.If you travel at least three times a year, the Sapphire Reserve is probably worth it. But if you don't travel very much, then you should consider the Sapphire Preferred. The Sapphire Preferred is a good card to use if you like to dine out or grocery shop regularly. The card's 2x points on these categories are worth 4% cash back, which beats the 3% cash back on dining and travel offered by the Sapphire Reserve. The Sapphire Reserve's 50% bonus is worth only 2% in the form of cash back.The Sapphire Reserve's 50% bonus is not worth 2%. It's worth much more than that.You can use the Sapphire Reserve's 50% bonus for any travel expenses you would incur, such as flights, hotels, car rentals, and food and drinks on the road. You can also use the bonus to pay your credit card bill. But there are many other uses as well.You can get the Chase Sapphire Reserve if you want to pay the $450 annual fee. But you can get the Sapphire Preferred if you don't need to spend more than $95.The best credit card for travel rewards depends on how you use it.What to do with your Chase Sapphire Reserve points?The Chase Sapphire Reserve card is a good choice for travelers who are interested in earning a lot of points for their spending.In the last couple of months, I've had the opportunity to use the card for travel to New York City, Boston, and Chicago. I was able to book my flights through the Chase Ultimate Rewards travel portal, and I used the card to cover my hotel stay and food expenses during my trip.I've also been able to use my points for other things like airline miles and merchandise. I've used the points for a couple of gifts, and I've been able to redeem the points for gift cards.In my opinion, the Chase Sapphire Reserve is one of the best travel rewards cards on the market today.What is the best credit card for business travel?The best credit card for business travel is one that gives you the most miles and points for the money you spend.There are a lot of good credit cards for business travel. But the best one is one that gives you the most miles and points for the money you spend.I've been traveling for business for over 25 years and have used several different cards.
